; PREFACE

[Page-ix+ 39]
<H>PREFACE
<P>It is with a sense of diffidence that I am placing my
<>{%Indian Epigraphical Glossary%} in the hands of the students of
<>Indian epigraphy and lexicography. Originally it was my
<>intention to insert it in my {%Indian Epigraphy%} as an Appendix
<>to the Chapter on “Technical Expressions”. But, as my collec-
<>tion of the material progressed, I felt that it would be rather too
<>big for an Appendix. At the same time, I also realised that
<>it was not possible for a single man to collect all interesting
<>words and expressions from all published epigraphic records
<>in the various Indian languages in a short period of time.
<>But I was eager to do as much as it was possible for me in the
<>limited time I could devote to the work, and the result of the
<>attempt is this nucleus now placed in the hands of readers
<>interested in inscriptions. I am fully conscious of my own
<>limitations as well as of the possibility of errors of judgment
<>and of omission and commission creeping into the work.
<>There may be cases wherein I have been misled by earlier
<>writers, or accepted their doubtful suggestion as correct, or
<>misunderstood them. It is hoped, nevertheless, that the work
<>may be of some help to the students and to the future compiler
<>of a fuller Glossary of this type.
<P>The majority of words collected in this Glossary occur
<>in inscriptions in Sanskrit or in the Sanskritic and Dravidian
<>languages. My aim has primarily been to collect Sanskrit
<>words, and generally the Prakrit and {%tadbhava%} words have been
<>given in their Sanskrit forms, although some Dravidian or
<>Deśī words have also been included. Sanskrit words used
<>in Tamil with {%ṉ%} and {%m%} suffixed to them have been ususally
<>quoted without the suffixes; e. g., {%varāhaṉ%} and {%liṅgam%} have
<>been recognised as {%varāha%} and {%liṅga.%} Likewise, the suffix {%mu%}
<>in Sanskrit words used in Telugu has been generally omitted.
<>Feminine words ending in {%a%} and {%i,%} as used in the Dravidian
<>languages, have often been quoted with the vowels lengthened.
<>In Tamil words, intervocalic {%k, c, ṭ, t%} and {%p%} have sometimes
<>been represented by {%g, j, d, d%} and {%b%} respectivly. It is felt that,
<>while weeding out words without special significance from my
<>original collection, some were left over. There are also some
<>words collected from sources other than epigraphic records.
[Page-x+ 40]
<P>There are three Appendices at the end of the volume,
<>the first of which contains passages indicating the privileges,
<>etc., enjoyed by the donees of rent-free (or partially rent-free)
<>holdings. Appendix II contains a list of various levies that
<>are known from inscriptions in Dravidian languages, especially
<>Tamil. These Appendices are expected to throw light on
<>the rights and obligations of the tenants of ancient and
<>medieval India and on the meanings of some of the Sanskritic
<>words in the Glossary. The third Appendix contains words
<>of numismatic interest.
<P>The words have been mostly taken from my {%Indian Epi-%}
<>{%graphy%} and the Indices and Glossaries appended to various
<>epigraphical publications, and references to these have been
<>indicated in short. Full references with the indication of
<>pages, etc., have, however, been provided in certain cases
<>especially when the words occur in the epigraphic texts, but
<>are not noticed in the Indices, etc., pertaining to the Volumes
<>in question. A key to the shortened references is supplied
<>below separately. The references cited under a word are of
<>course not exhaustive in all cases. The Index has been
<>prepared by Sri Dipak Ranjan Das, Lecturer, Sanskrit College,
<>Calcutta, to whom my sincere thanks are due.
<P>While it is a matter of satisfaction that I have probably
<>succeeded in explaining a number of expressions, which were
<>previously unintelligible or misunderstood, and in grouping
<>together connected items by cross-references in numerous cases,
<>I am sorry to feel that it is difficult to compile a work of this
<>type without errors, and even more difficult is to print it with-
<>out technical blemishes including misprints. I therefore crave
<>the indulgence of sympathic readers for all kind of mistakes
<>that might have crept into the book and request them to be
<>so kind as to draw my attention to the defects they may notice
<>in it.
{%Pramāṇa-siddhānta-viruddham = atra%}
<>{%yat = kiñcid = uktaṃ mati-māndya-doṣāt |%}
<>{%mātsaryam = utsārya tad = ārya-cittāḥ%}
<>{%prasādam = ādhāya viśodhayantu ||%}
<HS>D. C. SIRCAR
<>645, New Alipore, Culcutta-53,
<>November 15, 1965.
;

;

<H>SPECIAL ABBREVIATIONS TO THE SECTIONS OF
<>{%INDIAN EPIGRAPHY%} AND TO OTHER GLOSSARIES
<>AND INDICES
<HI>ASLV = {%Administration and Social Life under Vijayanagara%} by
<>T. V. Mahalingam, pp. 418-76 (Index).
<HI>BL = Bhandarkar's List = {%A List of Inscriptions of Northern%}
<>{%India in Brāhmī and its Derivative Scripts from about%}
<>200 {%A. C.%} by D. R. Bhandarkar, Appendix to the
<>{%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volumes XIX-XXIII, pp. 297-
<>365 (Index).
<HI>Chamba = {%Antiquities of Chamba State,%} Part II, by B. Ch.
<>Chhabra, pp. 180-93 (Index).
<HI>CII = {%Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum;%} e. g., CII 2-1 =
<>{%Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum,%} Volume II, Part i,
<>pp. 181-85 (Index); CII 3, 4 = Indices to {%Corpus%}
<>{%Inscriptionum Indicarum,%} Volumes III and IV.
<HI>CITD = {%Corpus of Inscriptions in the Telingana Districts of%}
<>{%H. E. H. the Nizam's Dominions%} by P. Sreenivasachar,
<>Part II, pp. 201-12 (Glossary).
<HI>EI = {%Epigraphia Indica;%} e. g., EI 1 = {%Epigraphia Indica,%}
<>Volume I, pp. 461-78 (Index); EI 2, 6, 12 =
<>Indices to {%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volumes II, VI and XII.
<HI>HA = {%Holy Abu%} by Muni Jayantavijaya, translated by
<>U. P. Shah, pp. 198-204 (Glossary).
<HI>HD = {%History of Dharmaśāstra%} by P. V. Kane, Volume
<>III, pp. 975-1007 (Glossary styled ‘Appendix--
<>Note 191’).
<HI>HRS = {%Hindu Revenue System%} by U. N. Ghoshal, pp. 289 ff.
<>(Glossary and Index).
<HI>IA = {%Indian Antiquary;%} e. g., IA 5 = {%Indian Antiquary,%} Volume
<>V, pp. 363-71 (Index); IA 8, 15, 20 = Indices to
<>{%Indian Antiquary,%} Volumes VIII, XV and XX.
<HI>IE = {%Indian Epigraphy,%} by D. C. Sircar; e. g., IE 8-2 =
<>{%Indian Epigraphy,%} Chapter VIII, Section ii; IE
<>7-1-2 = {%Indian Epigraphy,%} Chapter VII, Section i,
<>Subsection 2.
[Page-xii+ 20]
<HI>LL = Lüders' List = {%A List of Brāhmī Inscriptions%} by H.
<>Lüders, Appendix to the {%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volume
<>X, pp. 213-24 (Index).
<HI>LP = {%Lekhapaddhati,%} G. O. S., No. XXI, pp. 97-128
<>(Glossary).
<HI>ML = Majumdar's List = {%A List of Kharoṣṭhī Inscriptions%}
<>by N. G. Majumdar in the {%Journal of the Asiatic%}
<>{%Society of Bengal,%} New Series, Vol. XX, 1924, pp.
<>35-39 (Index).
<HI>PJS = {%Prācīna Jaina-lekha Sandoha%} by Muni Jayantavijaya,
<>p. 61 (Glossary).
<HI>SII = {%South Indian Inscriptions;%} e. g., SII 1 = {%South Indian%}
<>{%Inscriptions,%} Volume I, pp. 171-83 (Index); SII
<>11-2 = {%South Indian Inscriptions,%} Volume XI, Part ii,
<>pp. 267-72 (Index); SII 1, 3, 12-2 = Indices to
<>{%South Indian Inscriptions,%} Volumes I, III, and XII,
<>Part ii.
<HI>SITI = {%South Indian Temple Inscriptions%} by T. N. Subra-
<>manian, Volume III, Part ii, pp. i-civ (Glossary
<>in an ‘Annexure’ at the end of the volume).

; SYSTEM OF TRANSLITERATION
;
<H>SYSTEM OF TRANSLITERATION
<P>{#आ#} = ā, {#ई#} = ī, {#ऊ#} = ū,
<>{#ऋ#} = ṛ, {#ॠ#} = ṝ, {#ऌ#} = ḷ,
<>{#ॠ#} = ḹ, {#ए#} (long) = e, {#ए#} (short) = {%ĕ,%}
<>{#ओ#} (long) = o, {#ओ#} (short) = ŏ, {#ङ#} = ṅ,
<>{#च#} = c, {#ञ#} = ñ, {#ट#} = ṭ,
<>{#ड#} = ḍ, {#ण#} = ṇ, {#श#} = ś,
<>{#ष#} = ṣ, {#ड्२अ#} = ḏ {#ळ#} = ḻ,
<>Dravidian palatal alveolar {%n%} = ṉ,
<>Dravidian palatal alveolar {%r%} = ṟ,
<>Dravidian cerebral voiced fricative (i. e. voiced {%ṣ%}) = l13,
<>anusvāra = ṃ, visarga = ḥ,
<>upadhmānīya = ḣ, jihvāmūlīya = h
[Page-xvi+ 1]
<>NIL
;
; ENTRIES
;
[Page-001+ 37]
<H>A

<L>1<pc>001<k1>आबाध<k2>आबाध
{%ābādha%}¦ (CII 1), illness.
<LEND>

<L>2<pc>001<k1>आबाधा<k2>आबाधा
{%ābādhā%}¦ (EI 15), same as {%bādhā%} or {%vādhā;%} obstacle.
<LEND>

<L>3<pc>001<k1>अबातमाल<k2>अबातमाल, अबातमाला
{%abātamāla, abātamālā,%}¦ Prakrit; meaning doubtful (cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 272; {%ZDMG,%} Vol. XL, pp. 345-46); explained
<div n="lb">as a kind of sculptured slab (LL).
<LEND>

<L>4<pc>001<k1>अब्दप<k2>अब्दप
{%abdapa%}¦ (IA 16), the entrance of the sun into the
<div n="lb">Aries ({%Meṣa%}).
<LEND>

<L>5<pc>001<k1>अब्दपूजा<k2>अब्द-पूजा
{%abda-pūjā%}¦ (EI 32), a rite.
<LEND>

<L>6<pc>001<k1>आब्दार्खानह्<k2>आब्दार्खानह्
{%ābdārkhānah%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 31), Persian; ‘water-house’;
<div n="lb">cf. {%Pānīy-āgārika.%}
<LEND>

<L>7<pc>001<k1>अब्धि<k2>अब्धि
{%abdhi%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’; see {%sāgara.%}
<LEND>

<L>8<pc>001<k1>आब्दिकश्राद्ध<k2>आब्दिक-श्राद्ध
{%ābdika-śrāddha%}¦ (CII 4), an annual rite in honour of a
<div n="lb">dead person.
<LEND>

<L>9<pc>001<k1>आभाव्य<k2>आभाव्य
{%ābhāvya%}¦ (EI 11, 16), income or proceeds; cf. {%rāja-rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%puruṣ ādibhiḥ svaṃ svam = ābhāvyaṃ parihartavyam;%} see also {%rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāvya,%} etc. Cf. ‘the income ({%ābhāvya%}) derived from the
<div n="lb">loads on bullocks going on their way or coming to Nāḍlāi’
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 36).
<LEND>

<L>10<pc>001<k1>अभय<k2>अभय
{%abhaya%}¦ (EI 24), pose of hand ({%mudrā%}); see {%abhaya-mudrā.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), place of security to persons in distress; called
<div n="lb">{%añjinānpugal-idam%} in Tamil. Cf. {%abhaya-śāsana.%}
<LEND>

<L>11<pc>001<k1>अभयहस्त<k2>अभय-हस्त
{%abhaya-hasta%}¦ (SII 2), pose of hand known as {%abhaya-mudrā%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>12<pc>001<k1>अभयमुद्रा<k2>अभय-मुद्रा
{%abhaya-mudrā%}¦ (HA), pose of hand offering protection, in
<div n="lb">which the palm of the right hand, facing the devotee, is held
<div n="lb">with fingers upwards. Cf. {%abhaya-hasta.%}
<LEND>

<L>13<pc>001<k1>अभयशासन<k2>अभय-शासन
{%abhaya-śāsana%}¦ (EI 12, 27; SITI), ‘grant of shelter’,
<div n="lb">‘charter of security’; a deed offering protection; a grant
<div n="lb">recording the provision of shelter.
<LEND>

<L>14<pc>001<k1>आभिगामिकगुण<k2>आभिगामिक-गुण
{%ābhigāmika-guṇa%}¦ (CII 3, 4), certain attractive qualities.
<LEND>

<L>15<pc>001<k1>अभिघात<k2>अभिघात
{%abhighāta%}¦ (LP), an injury.
<LEND>

<L>16<pc>001<k1>अभिहार<k2>अभिहार
{%abhihāra%}¦ (CII 1), a reward.
<LEND>

<L>17<pc>001<k1>अभिज्ञान<k2>अभिज्ञान
{%abhijñāna%}¦ (LP), a token by which the identity of a
<div n="lb">person is recognised.
<LEND>

<L>18<pc>001<k1>अभिकार<k2>अभिकार
{%abhikāra,%}¦ cf. {%kṛt-ābhikāra%} (CII 1), probably, one who has
<div n="lb">committed an offence under the instigation of another.
<LEND>
[Page-002+ 40]

<L>19<pc>002<k1>अभिलेखितक<k2>अभिलेखितक
{%abhilekhitaka%}¦ (IE 8-8), probably, a written complaint.
<LEND>

<L>20<pc>002<k1>अभिनव<k2>अभिनव
{%abhinava%}¦ (EI 5; IA 18), name of a tax; cf. {%abhinava-mārga-%}
<div n="lb">{%ṇaka-prabhṛti-sarv-ādāyair = upetaḥ,%} epithet of the gift village. It
<div n="lb">may also mean ‘new’ and the reference may be to the new
<div n="lb">{%mārgaṇaka%} tax. See {%abhinava-mārgaṇaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>21<pc>002<k1>अभिनवमार्गणक<k2>अभिनव-मार्गणक
{%abhinava-mārgaṇaka%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. III, p. 264,
<div n="lb">note 1), name of a tax. See {%mārgaṇaka, mārg-ādāya,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>22<pc>002<k1>अभिप्रेत<k2>अभिप्रेत
{%abhipreta%}¦ (CII 1), intention.
<LEND>

<L>23<pc>002<k1>आभीर<k2>आभीर
{%Ābhīra%}¦ (IE 8-3), member of the cowherd community.
<LEND>

<L>24<pc>002<k1>अभिरक्त<k2>अभिरक्त
{%abhirakta%}¦ (CII 1), beloved one.
<LEND>

<L>25<pc>002<k1>अभिषेक<k2>अभिषेक
{%abhiṣeka%}¦ (EI 4), coronation; cf. {%abhiṣeka-kkāṇi, abhiṣeka-%}
<div n="lb">{%kkāṇikkai%} (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; presents offered to the
<div n="lb">king at the time of his coronation.
<LEND>

<L>26<pc>002<k1>अभिषेकमण्दप<k2>अभिषेक-मण्दप
{%abhiṣeka-maṇdapa%}¦ (SITI), a hall where ceremonial baths
<div n="lb">are taken; the coronation hall; also called {%tiru-mañjana-%}
<div n="lb">{%śālai%} and {%kuḻikkum-iḍam%} in Tamil.
<LEND>

<L>27<pc>002<k1>अभिषेकनामन्<k2>अभिषेक-नामन्
{%abhiṣeka-nāman%}¦ (SITI), the name or title assumed by a
<div n="lb">king at the time of his coronation.
<LEND>

<L>28<pc>002<k1>अभिषिक्त<k2>अभिषिक्त
{%abhiṣikta%}¦ (CII 1), cf. {%dvādaśa-varṣ-ābhiṣikta,%} ‘when one has
<div n="lb">been anointed twelve years’, ‘when twelve years have elapsed
<div n="lb">from one's coronation’. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, pp. 333 ff.
<LEND>

<L>29<pc>002<k1>अभीष्टदेवता<k2>अभीष्ट-देवता
{%abhīṣṭa-devatā%}¦ (IA 18), same as {%iṣṭa-devatā;%} the favourite
<div n="lb">deity; the tutelary deity.
<LEND>

<L>30<pc>002<k1>अभिस्थान<k2>अभिस्थान
{%abhisthāna,%}¦ correctly {%abhiṣṭhāna;%} used in the sense of
<div n="lb">{%adhiṣṭhāna,%} ‘the residence’, ‘a city’, or ‘the headquarters’.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 219.
<LEND>

<L>31<pc>002<k1>अभित्वरमाण<k2>अभित्वरमाण, अभित्वरमाणक
{%Abhitvaramāṇa, Abhitvaramāṇaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 31; HD),
<div n="lb">the letter-carrier or a special kind of messenger. Cf
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321 ({%dūta-praiṣaṇika-gamāgamik-ābhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%tvaramāṇaka%}); Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 125-26.
<LEND>

<L>35<pc>002<k1>आभ्यन्तर<k2>आभ्यन्तर

<div n="lb">426. But cf. also {%Ābhyantarika, Abhyantar-opasthāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>36<pc>002<k1>अभ्यन्तरभाण्डाराधिकारिन्<k2>अभ्यन्तर-भाण्डार्-आधिकारिन्

<div n="lb">(IE 8-3; EI 28).

<L>37<pc>002<k1>आभ्यन्तरादाय<k2>आभ्यन्तर्-आदाय
{%ābhyantar-ādāya,%}¦ cf. {%bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya%} (IE 8-5); internal
[Page-003+ 40]
<div n="lb">revenue income of a village; probably, taxes payable to the
<div n="lb">village authorities as against those payable to the king. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%antar-āya, abhyantara-siddhi, antaḥ-kara,%} etc. See {%bāhya.%}
<LEND>

<L>38<pc>003<k1>अभ्यन्तरसिद्धि<k2>अभ्यन्तर-सिद्धि, अभ्यन्तर-सिद्धिक
{%abhyantara-siddhi, abhyantara-siddhika%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 20, 22),
<div n="lb">same as {%ābhyantara-siddhi;%} internal income or revenue, or taxes
<div n="lb">payable to the village authorities as against those payable to the
<div n="lb">king; cf. {%tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ābhyantar-ādāya;%} also {%sarv-ābhyantara-siddhi%} (EI 20), and {%antaḥ-%}
<div n="lb">{%siddhika%} (CII 4), a privilege of the donee of rent-free land.
<div n="lb">According to some (CII 4), it refers to the privilege of the
<div n="lb">donee offering full power of adjudication in law-suits.
<div n="lb">But expressions like {%tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi%} (q. v.) render it
<div n="lb">doubtful. See {%bāhya, siddhi, siddh-āya.%}
<LEND>

<L>39<pc>003<k1>आभ्यन्तरसिद्धि<k2>आभ्यन्तर-सिद्धि
{%ābhyantara-siddhi%}¦ (CII 4), same as {%abhyantara-siddhi;%}
<div n="lb">explained by some as ‘the powers of adjudication’; probably,
<div n="lb">taxes payable to the village authorities as against those payable
<div n="lb">to the king. See {%abhyantara-siddhi,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>58<pc>004<k1>समे<k2>समे

<div n="lb">master’, i. e. ‘a master-mason’; cf. {%Ācāri%} (EI 17), an artisan.
<div n="lb">Pāli {%Ācariya%} is explained as ‘a master goldsmith’ in the {%P. T. S.%}
<div n="lb">{%Pāli-Eng. Dict.%}
<div n="P">({%LL%}), title of a sculptor.

<div n="lb">authoritatively.

<L>97<pc>006<k1>अधिकरण<k2>अधिकरण

<L>98<pc>006<k1>अधिकरणदण्ड<k2>अधिकरण-दण्ड

<div n="lb">or law-court.
<LEND>

<L>99<pc>006<k1>अधिकरणलेखक<k2>अधिकरण-लेखक
{%Adhikaraṇa-lekhaka%}¦ (EI 30), a scribe pertaining to a law-
<div n="lb">court or office.
[Page-007+ 40]
<div n="P">({%HD%}), the official recorder or scribe [who drew up deeds of
<div n="lb">sale and the like after having measured the land to be sold].
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VI. 38; {%Viṣṇu Dh. S.,%} VII, 3.
<LEND>

<L>100<pc>007<k1>अधिकरणिक<k2>अधिकरणिक, आधिकरणिक
{%Adhikaraṇika, Ādhikaraṇika%}¦ (IE 8-1; EI 28), an officer
<div n="lb">belonging to or in charge of an {%adhikaraṇa%} or office.
<LEND>

<L>101<pc>007<k1>अधिकारवर्त्तना<k2>अधिकार-वर्त्तना
{%adhikāra-varttanā%}¦ (SITI), customary payments made to
<div n="lb">an officer at stipulated periods; probably the same as Sanskrit-
<div n="lb">Tamil {%adhikāra-ppe%}ṟ{%u, adhikāra-ppŏn,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>102<pc>007<k1>अधिकारिक<k2>अधिकारिक, आधिकारिक
{%Adhikārika, Ādhikārika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 2, 23, 28; CII 4;
<div n="lb">BL; HD), ‘an officer’; same as {%Adhikārin, Niyogika, Adhyakṣa,%} etc.,
<div n="lb">regarded as meaning a minister, magistrate, superintendent,
<div n="lb">governor or director. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIV, p. 184.
<LEND>

<L>103<pc>007<k1>अधिकारिमुख्य<k2>अधिकारि-मुख्य
{%Adhikāri-mukhya%}¦ (EI 33), explained as ‘the chief minister’.
<LEND>

<L>104<pc>007<k1>अधिकारिन्<k2>अधिकारिन्
{%Adhikārin%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 28; BL), ‘an officer’; same as
<div n="lb">{%Ādhikārika;%} cf. Kannaḍa {%Vĕrgaḍĕ,%} etc., and Sanskrit {%Adhyākṣa,%}
<div n="lb">meaning a superintendent, governor or director.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), explained as ‘a special officer or royal agent’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7), explained as ‘a minister’.
<div n="P">({%SII%} 2), explained as ‘a magistrate’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Viḍaiy-adhikāri, Viḍaiyil-adhikāri%} (SITI), an officer issu-
<div n="lb">ing royal orders.
<LEND>

<L>172<pc>010<k1>अग्रहार<k2>अग्रहार
{%agrahāra%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 30; CII 4; SII 1; HRS; Chamba), rent-
<div n="lb">free land given to Brāhmaṇas; a rent-free village; a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">village; sometimes suffixed to names of localities especially
<div n="lb">in South India. It was primarily, ‘a rent-free village in
<div n="lb">the possession of Brāhmaṇas’; but there are occasional references
[Page-011+ 40]
<div n="lb">to {%dev-āgrahāra%} (rent-free holding in the possession of a deity),
<div n="lb">{%vaiśy-āgrahāra%} (rent-free holding in the possession of the
<div n="lb">Vaiśyas), etc.; sometimes spelt {%agrāhāra%} (CII 3). See {%mah-%}
<div n="lb">{%āgrahāra, brahmapurī, caturvedi-maṅgala,%} etc.; also {%aṅga-bhoga.%}
<LEND>

<L>173<pc>011<k1>अग्रहारप्रदेयांश<k2>अग्रहार-प्रदेय्-आंश
{%agrahāra-pradey-āṃśa%}¦ (EI 33), a small rent payable for
<div n="lb">land granted to Brāhmaṇas and declared rent-free.
<LEND>

<L>174<pc>011<k1>अग्रहारिक<k2>अग्रहारिक, आग्रहारिक
{%Agrahārika, Āgrahārika%}¦ (IE 3-8; EI 23; HD; CII 3; etc.),
<div n="lb">the owner of an {%agrahāra;%} sometimes probably, the superin-
<div n="lb">tendent of {%agrahāras;%} same as {%Agrahārin.%} Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XXIV, p. 127.
<LEND>

<L>175<pc>011<k1>अग्रहारिन्<k2>अग्रहारिन्, अग्रहारीण
{%Agrahārin, Agrahārīṇa%}¦ (EI 23, 24), the holder of an
<div n="lb">{%agrahāra;%} headman or owner of an {%agrahāra%} village. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Agrahārika.%}
<LEND>

<L>176<pc>011<k1>अग्रहारीणमहत्तर<k2>अग्रहारीण-महत्तर
{%Agrahārīṇa-mahattara%}¦ (EI 24), headman among the
<div n="lb">{%Agrahārīṇas,%} i. e. owners of an {%agrahāra%} (rent-free village in the
<div n="lb">possession of Brāhmaṇas).
<LEND>

<L>177<pc>011<k1>आग्रहायणी<k2>आग्रहायणी
{%āgrahāyaṇī%}¦ (EI 8), Mārgaśīrṣa su-di 15.
<LEND>

<L>178<pc>011<k1>अग्रज<k2>अग्रज
{%agraja%}¦ (EI 23), the elder brother (or cousin); rarely
<div n="lb">used wrongly in the sense of ‘the eldest son’ (EI 9).
<LEND>

<L>179<pc>011<k1>अग्रजन्मन्<k2>अग्रजन्मन्
{%agrajanman%}¦ (EI 9), same as {%agraja%} (q. v.); wrongly used to
<div n="lb">mean ‘the eldest son’ instead of ‘the elder brother’ (cf.
<div n="lb">{%agraja%}).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), a Brāhmaṇa.
<LEND>

<L>195<pc>012<k1>आहार<k2>आहार

<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), cf. {%s-āhāra%} in Buddhist literature explained as
<div n="lb">{%sa-janapada. Āhāra%} = [land for] food; cf. {%bhoga.%}

<L>205<pc>012<k1>आजिवककासु<k2>आजिवक-कासु
{%ājivaka-kāsu%}¦ (SITI), same as Tamil {%āśuva-kkāśu, āśuvikaḻ-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāśu, āśuva-kkaḍamai;%} tax payable by Ājīvakas or for the
<div n="lb">maintenance of Ājīvaka monks.
<LEND>

<L>206<pc>012<k1>आज्ञा<k2>आज्ञा
{%Ājñā%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 27; BL; CII 3), an order or command;
<div n="lb">same as {%ājñapti%} or {%ājñāpti%} supposed to be connected
<div n="lb">with giving the order for the drawing up of a charter; person
<div n="lb">receiving a king's order regarding the preparation of a charter;
<div n="lb">usually translated as ‘executor of a grant’; standing alone,
<div n="lb">the word is supposed to indicate the office of the {%Dūtaka,%}
<div n="lb">though the latter seems to have been additionally responsible
<div n="lb">for giving the donee the possession of the gift land. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XIV, p. 362 (of the Gaṅga year 149) where the words are
<div n="lb">{%ājñā mahāmahattara-Śivarmā;%} also {%svayam = ājñā%} ({%CII,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">III, p. 115; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVI, p. 19) taken to mean that
<div n="lb">the king employed no {%Dūtaka%} to convey the details of his grant
<div n="lb">to the local officers, but that he gave the details in person.
[Page-013+ 40]
<div n="lb">The expression {%sva-mukh-ājñā%} (literally, the oral order of the
<div n="lb">king) is also explained in the same way. The suggestion that
<div n="lb">{%Ājñādāpaka%} sometimes occurs as a synonym of {%Dūtaka%} is wrong.
<div n="lb">See {%Ājñapti, Ājñā-sañcārin,%} etc. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 143-44.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%āṇai%} (EI 23), sign; the insignia.
<LEND>

<L>207<pc>013<k1>आज्ञाभोगिक<k2>आज्ञा-भोगिक
{%Ājñā-bhogika%}¦ (EI 21; BL), {%Ājñā%} and {%Bhogika%} wrongly
<div n="lb">made into a single official designation. See {%Ājñā%} and {%Bhogika.%}
<LEND>

<L>208<pc>013<k1>आज्ञादापक<k2>आज्ञा-दापक
{%Ājñā-dāpaka%}¦ (BL; HD), wrongly taken as a compound
<div n="lb">expression meaning an officer ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XIV, p. 161).
<div n="lb">See {%Ājñā%} and {%Dāpaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>209<pc>013<k1>आज्ञाधारक<k2>आज्ञाधारक
{%Ājñādhāraka%}¦ (ASLV), an executor of the royal order;

<L>210<pc>013<k1>आज्ञापरिपालक<k2>आज्ञा-परिपालक

<div n="lb">cf. {%Ājñā-dhāraka.%}
<LEND>

<L>211<pc>013<k1>आज्ञप्ति<k2>आज्ञप्ति, आज्ञाप्ति
{%Ājñapti, Ājñāpti%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 24, 27, 30; SII 1; HD), ‘the
<div n="lb">agency that obtains the command’; the executor of a grant; one
<div n="lb">who communicates, at the order of the king, the details about a
<div n="lb">land grant to local officers; probably the same as {%Dūtaka.%} Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Ājñā;%} also Tamil {%Vāy-kkeḻvi, Vāy-kkeḻviyār.%} See {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 143-44;
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VII, p. 184; Vol. VIII, p. 146. Cf. {%Ājñā-sañcārin.%}
<LEND>

<L>212<pc>013<k1>आज्ञासञ्चारिन्<k2>आज्ञा-सञ्चारिन्

<L>234<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटल<k2>अक्षपटल

<L>235<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलादाय<k2>अक्षपटल्-आदाय

<L>236<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलाधिकृत<k2>अक्षपटल्-आधिकृत

<LEND>

<L>237<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलाधिपति<k2>अक्षपटल्-आधिपति
{%Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati%}¦ (BL), the head of the {%akṣapaṭala%}
<div n="lb">department; same as {%Akṣapaṭalin,%} etc.; also called {%Akṣapāla%}
<div n="lb">(cf. {%karaṇa%}).
<LEND>

<L>238<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलाध्यक्ष<k2>अक्षपटल्-आध्यक्ष
{%Akṣapaṭal-ādhyakṣa%}¦ (HD), the superintendent of records
<div n="lb">and accounts. Cf. {%Arthaśāstra,%} II. 7; {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 143.
<LEND>

<L>239<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलप्रस्थ<k2>अक्षपटल-प्रस्थ
{%akṣapaṭala-prastha%}¦ (IA 18; HRS), contributions paid by
<div n="lb">the villagers at the rate of a {%prastha%} of grain (probably, per
<div n="lb">standard measure) for the expenses of the {%akṣapaṭala%} department
<div n="lb">(probably for the maintenance of the {%Paṭvārī%}). Cf.
<div n="lb">{%akṣapaṭal-ādāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>240<pc>014<k1>अक्षपटलिक<k2>अक्षपटलिक
{%Akṣapaṭalika%}¦ (EI 30; CII 4; HD; BL), same as
<div n="lb">{%Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati,%} officer in charge of accounts and records.
<div n="lb">{%Akṣapaṭala%} means ‘accounts office’ (Stein) or ‘records office’
<div n="lb">(Bühler). There is {%Grām-ākṣapaṭalika%} in the {%Harṣacarita%} (VII, para.
<div n="lb">2) probably meaning the {%Paṭvārī,%} and a section on the superin-
<div n="lb">tendent of the {%akṣapaṭala%} in the {%Arthaśāstra%} (II. 7). See {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XX, p. 128; Vol. IX, p. 305. Cf. {%Mahākṣapaṭalika.%}
<LEND>

<L>241<pc>014<k1>आक्षपटलिक<k2>आक्षपटलिक
{%Ākṣapaṭalika%}¦ (HD), same as {%Akṣapaṭalika;%} officer in charge of
<div n="lb">the accounts and records office. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. I, pp. 316, 318.
<LEND>
[Page-015+ 40]

<L>242<pc>015<k1>अक्षपटलिन्<k2>अक्षपटलिन्
{%Akṣapaṭalin%}¦ (EI 19; BL), same as {%Akṣapaṭal-ādhipati,%}
<div n="lb">{%Akṣapaṭalika,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>243<pc>015<k1>अक्षर<k2>अक्षर
{%akṣara,%}¦ cf. {%hast-ākṣarāṇi%} (LP), a deed for borrowing money;
<div n="lb">also {%kṛṣṇ-ākṣarāṇi%} (LP), the record containing a censure; also
<div n="lb">{%ujjval-ākṣarāṇi%} (LP), a certificate of good conduct; also {%viśuddh-%}
<div n="lb">{%ākṣarāṇi%} (LP), an acknowledgement. Cf. {%uttar-ākṣarāṇi%} (LP),
<div n="lb">same as Marāṭhī {%utarāi;%} probably, a deed by which land is given
<div n="lb">at a favourable rent to merchants, etc., who helped the govern-
<div n="lb">ment with money.
<div n="P">{%Cf. guṇ-ākṣara,%} also called {%guṇa-patra;%} see also {%gupt-ākṣara.%}
<LEND>

<L>244<pc>015<k1>अक्षरपल्लि<k2>अक्षरपल्लि
{%akṣarapalli%}¦ (IA 11), the system of writing numbers by
<div n="lb">syllables; name applied to the system of writing numbers as
<div n="lb">found in inscriptions before the popularisation of the decimal
<div n="lb">system, though the symbols employed in the Brāhmī inscriptions
<div n="lb">do not appear to be {%akṣaras%} in all cases.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">hall’.

<L>270<pc>016<k1>अलीपक<k2>अलीपक
{%alīpaka,%}¦ also read as {%alīyaka%} (EI 32), a fiscal expression of
<div n="lb">uncertain import; see {%nidhān-ālīpaka.%} The word {%alipaka%} means
<div n="lb">‘a bee’. Thus {%ālipaka%} may refer to the right over wax, bee-hives,
<div n="lb">and honey. {%Alīyaka,%} from {%ali,%} ‘a bee’, would mean the same thing.
<LEND>

<L>280<pc>016<k1>अमान्त<k2>अमान्त
{%amānta%}¦ (CII 3), the technical name for the scheme of the
<div n="lb">lunar months in Southern India, according to which a month
<div n="lb">ends with the new-moon day, and the bright fortnight precedes
<div n="lb">the dark. According to Fleet, it is always this arrangement
[Page-017+ 40]
<div n="lb">that is taken for calculation in astronomical works, though, even
<div n="lb">in Southern India, the arrangement was not applied to the
<div n="lb">Śaka years, for the civil reckoning, till between 804 and 866
<div n="lb">A. D.; on the other hand, according to him, even in Northern
<div n="lb">India, this arrangement was used in Nepal with the years of
<div n="lb">the Newār era, though it was abandoned there when the Newār
<div n="lb">era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern
<div n="lb">variety. For its prevalence in Indonesia, see {%Sel. Ins.,%} p. 470.
<LEND>

<L>281<pc>017<k1>अमर<k2>अमर
{%amara%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘thirtythree’ [being the original
<div n="lb">number of the gods].
<div n="P">({%SITI;%} ASLV), land or revenue granted by a ruler to his
<div n="lb">retainers for military service; land assigned to military officers
<div n="lb">who were entitled to collect only certain revenues with the
<div n="lb">obligation to raise a contingent of army ready for service when-
<div n="lb">ever called upon and also to pay tribute to the king; same as
<div n="lb">{%amara-māgaṇi.%} Cf. {%Amara-nāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>282<pc>017<k1>अमरमागणि<k2>अमर-मागणि
{%amara-māgaṇi%}¦ (SITI; ASLV), same as {%amara;%} estate
<div n="lb">given to an {%Amara-nāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>283<pc>017<k1>अमरनायक<k2>अमर-नायक
{%Amara-nāyaka%}¦ (EI 16; SITI; ASLV), a retainer chief
<div n="lb">enjoying {%amara,%} i. e. land or its revenue, for military service
<div n="lb">to be rendered to his master.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">one’.
<LEND>

<L>328<pc>019<k1>अन्धारुवा<k2>अन्धारुवा, आन्धारुवा
{%andhāruvā, āndhāruvā%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12), variant readings
<div n="lb">of {%arthāruvā%} or {%ārthāruvā%} (q. v.); Oḏiyā name of a tax.
<LEND>

<L>329<pc>019<k1>आन्ध्रदण्ड<k2>आन्ध्र-दण्ड
{%Āndhra-daṇḍa%}¦ (IE 8-5), a tax; cf. {%Turuṣka-daṇḍa%} and
<div n="lb">{%Tiguḻa-daṇḍa.%} There is also reference to ‘an assembly of
<div n="lb">{%Āndhra-daṇḍa%}’, the meaning of which is doubtful unless {%daṇḍa%}
<div n="lb">is taken here in the sense of ‘an army’.
<LEND>

<L>330<pc>019<k1>अण्डिका<k2>अण्डिका
{%aṇḍikā,%}¦ weight equal to (1/4) of a {%māṣa%} ({%JNSI,%} Vol. XVI, p.
<div n="lb">48); same as the copper {%paṇa%} (ibid., Vol. II, p. 7); also called
<div n="lb">{%dhānaka%} and regarded as equal to 4 {%kārṣāpaṇas%} or to (1/12)th
<div n="lb">{%suvarṇa%} (ibid., p. 8).
<LEND>

<L>331<pc>019<k1>अनेकान्तमत<k2>अनेकान्त-मत
{%anekānta-mata%}¦ (SII 1), same as {%syādvāda-mata%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>332<pc>019<k1>अनेसाहिणिवेर्गड<k2>अनेसाहिणि-वेर्गड
{%Anĕsāhiṇi-vĕrgaḍa%}¦ ({%A. R. Ep.,%} 1958-59, p. 12), Kannaḍa;
<div n="lb">official designation; same as Sanskrit {%Gaja-sādhanik-ādhyakṣa.%}
<LEND>

<L>333<pc>019<k1>अङ्ग<k2>अङ्ग
{%aṅga%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘six’.
[Page-020+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 15), an abbreviation of {%aṅga-bhoga;%} cf. {%gātra%} (IA 11).
<LEND>

<L>334<pc>020<k1>अङ्गभोग<k2>अङ्ग-भोग
{%aṅga-bhoga%}¦ (EI 17; CITD), often associated with {%raṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} as {%aṅga-raṅga-bhoga,%} usually explained as ‘decora-
<div n="lb">tions and illuminations of a deity’. That {%aṅga-bhoga%} means
<div n="lb">decoration of the image of a deity is clear from the fact
<div n="lb">that a queen is known to have received a village as an {%agrahāra%}
<div n="lb">for her {%aṅga-bhoga,%} i. e. as her pin-money ({%Bomb. Gaz.,%} Vol. I,
<div n="lb">Part ii, p. 448). Sometimes the land granted for the {%aṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} of a deity came to be known as the deity's {%aṅga-bhoga%}
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, p. 182); cf. {%aṅga,%} same as {%gātra%}
<div n="lb">(IA 11).
<LEND>

<L>335<pc>020<k1>अङ्गडसिद्धाय<k2>अङ्गड-सिद्धाय
{%aṅgaḍa-siddhāya%}¦ (CITD), Telugu-Sanskrit; fixed revenue
<div n="lb">from shops.
<LEND>

<L>336<pc>020<k1>अङ्गदेवता<k2>अङ्ग-देवता
{%aṅga-devatā%}¦ (SITI), attendant deity of a superior god;
<div n="lb">same as {%parivāra-devatā.%}
<LEND>

<L>337<pc>020<k1>अङ्गज<k2>अङ्गज
{%Aṅgaja%}¦ (EI 16), same as the god Kāma.
<LEND>

<L>338<pc>020<k1>अङ्गमणि<k2>अङ्ग-मणि
{%aṅga-maṇi%}¦ (SITI), property owned by a woman; cf.
<div n="lb">{%aṅga-maṇi-dravya%} (SITI), dowry.
<LEND>

<L>339<pc>020<k1>अङ्गनिगूहक<k2>अङ्ग-निगूहक
{%Aṅga-nigūhaka%}¦ (BL), an official designation of uncertain
<div n="lb">import; probably, a kind of spies.
<LEND>

<L>340<pc>020<k1>अङ्गार<k2>अङ्गार, अङ्गारक
{%aṅgāra, aṅgāraka,%}¦ cf. {%a-carm-āṅgāraka%} (IE 8-5; EI 15);
<div n="lb">charcoal for cooking, which the villagers were obliged to supply
<div n="lb">to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers.
<LEND>

<L>341<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरचना<k2>अङ्ग-रचना
{%aṅga-racanā%}¦ (HA), adorning of the various limbs of an
<div n="lb">image of the Jina with marks of sandal paste or leaves of gold,
<div n="lb">silver, etc., and with additional ornaments.
<LEND>

<L>342<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरक<k2>अङ्गरक
{%Aṅgaraka%}¦ (SII 11-1), corruption of {%Aṅgarakṣa%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>343<pc>020<k1>अङ्गारकी<k2>अङ्गारकी
{%aṅgārakī%}¦ (IA 26), same as {%ba-di%} 4.
<LEND>

<L>344<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरक्ष<k2>अङ्गरक्ष, अङ्गरक्षक
{%Aṅgarakṣa, Aṅgarakṣaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 15, 29; SITI),
<div n="lb">body-guard; the king's body-guard, or the head of the body
<div n="lb">guards.
<LEND>

<L>345<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरङ्गभोग<k2>अङ्ग-रङ्ग-भोग
{%aṅga-raṅga-bhoga%}¦ (EI 23; SII 1), decorations and illumi-
<div n="lb">nations of a deity; various kinds of enjoyment provided for a
<div n="lb">deity; sometimes explained as ‘worship to include all kinds of
<div n="lb">enjoyments’ (SITI). Cf. {%aṅga-bhoga-raṅga-bhoga, raṅg-āṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhoga,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>346<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरङ्गभोगवैभव<k2>अङ्ग-रङ्ग-भोग-वैभव
{%aṅga-raṅga-bhoga-vaibhava%}¦ (EI 3; SII 1; SITI), enjoyments
<div n="lb">of all kinds provided for a deity; same as {%aṅga-raṅga-bhoga.%}
<LEND>

<L>347<pc>020<k1>अङ्गरङ्गवैभोग<k2>अङ्ग-रङ्ग-वैभोग
{%aṅga-raṅga-vaibhoga%}¦ (EI 3; SII 1; SITI), same as {%aṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%raṅga-bhoga,%} i. e. {%aṅga-bhoga%} and {%raṅga-bhoga.%}
<LEND>
[Page-021+ 40]

<L>348<pc>021<k1>अङ्गशाला<k2>अङ्ग-शाला
{%aṅga-śālā%}¦ (SITI), same as {%aṅka-śālā.%}
<LEND>

<L>349<pc>021<k1>अङ्गवैद्य<k2>अङ्ग-वैद्य

<div n="lb">physician.
<LEND>

<L>350<pc>021<k1>आङ्गीकरणिक<k2>आङ्गीकरणिक

<LEND>

<L>352<pc>021<k1>अङ्गुलि<k2>अङ्गुलि
{%aṅguli%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘ten’; sometimes used to indicate
<div n="lb">‘twenty’.
<LEND>

<L>353<pc>021<k1>अनिकेतोस्<k2>अनिकेतोस्
{%Aniketŏs%}¦ (IE 8-2), Greek; royal title; ‘unopposed’;

<L>355<pc>021<k1>अनिवर्तकनिवर्तयितृ<k2>अनिवर्तक-निवर्तयितृ

<L>358<pc>021<k1>अनियुक्त<k2>अनियुक्त
{%aniyukta%}¦ (IA 9), cf. {%niyukt-āniyukta-rājapuruṣa;%} probably
<div n="lb">refers to officials of the king, who were not actually appointed
<div n="lb">by the government, but occupied posts by virtue of heredity
<div n="lb">or election.
<LEND>

<L>359<pc>021<k1>अञ्जष्टसभा<k2>अञ्जष्ट-सभा, अञ्जष्ट-शत्तु-सभै

<div n="lb">village committee of five or eight members. Cf. {%pañca-kula%}
<div n="lb">and {%aṣṭa-kula.%}
<LEND>

<L>360<pc>021<k1>अञ्जुवण्णम्<k2>अञ्जुवण्णम्
{%añjuvaṇṇam%}¦ (SITI; EI 35), Tamil; Sanskrit {%pañca-varṇa;%} the
<div n="lb">five artisan classes; called {%hañjamāna%} in Kannaḍa inscriptions;
<div n="lb">sometimes regarded as a form of Persian {%anjuman.%}
<LEND>

<L>361<pc>021<k1>अङ्क<k2>अङ्क
{%aṅka%}¦ (IA 19), a name, appellation or {%biruda.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-12; CII 4), ‘nine’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṅke, aṅkena, aṅkataḥ%} (IA 15), ‘in figures’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṅka,%} abbreviation of Telugu-Kannaḍa {%aṅkakā%}ṟ{%a;%} same
<div n="lb">as Sanskrit {%gaṇḍa%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 270), ‘a hero,
<div n="lb">champion or warrior’. See {%aṅkakāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>362<pc>021<k1>अङ्कदण्डखण्डन<k2>अङ्क-दण्ड-खण्डन
{%aṅka-daṇḍa-khaṇḍana,%}¦ translated as ‘faults, fines and
<div n="lb">divisions’; cf. {%pañch-āṅga-prasāda.%}

<L>363<pc>021<k1>अङ्ककार<k2>अङ्ककार
{%aṅkakāra%}¦ (EI 3, 4), a champion; same as Telugu-Kannaḍa
<div n="lb">{%aṅkakā%}ṟ{%a,%} sometimes explained as ‘a soldier or warrior who took
<div n="lb">a vow to defend his master and fight in the latter's cause to
<div n="lb">death’ ({%Hyderabad Archaeological Series,%} No. 18, p. 34). See {%aṅka.%}
<LEND>

<L>364<pc>021<k1>अङ्कशाला<k2>अङ्क-शाला
{%aṅka-śālā%}¦ (SITI), probably, the place where duels were
<div n="lb">fought; cf. {%aṅga-śālā.%}

<L>365<pc>022<k1>अन्न<k2>अन्न
{%anna,%}¦ Anglicised form of {%āṇaka;%} (1/16)th of a {%rupee%} ({%JNSI,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XV, p. 142).
<LEND>

<L>366<pc>022<k1>अन्नक<k2>अन्नक, अन्निका
{%annaka, annikā,%}¦ cf. {%anaka, anikā.%}

<L>367<pc>022<k1>अण्णनसिंह<k2>अण्णनसिंह
{%Aṇṇanasiṃha%}¦ (IE 8-2), Kannaḍa; ‘the lion of the brother’;
<div n="lb">a subordinate title. Cf. {%Ayyanasiṃha.%}
<LEND>

<L>368<pc>022<k1>अन्त<k2>अन्त
{%anta%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 1), a state beyond the borders of one's
<div n="lb">territories, or a bordering district; also its people; cf. {%pratyanta.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), cf. {%Anta-mahāmātra,%} officer employed in districts
<div n="lb">bordering on the frontiers of one's kingdom.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 3), a neighbour.
<LEND>

<L>369<pc>022<k1>अन्तःकर<k2>अन्तः-कर
{%antaḥ-kara%}¦ (CII 4), explained as ‘excise duty’; probably,
<div n="lb">‘internal revenue’ or revenue income; same as {%antar-āya, antar-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādāya, abhyantar-ādāya,%} etc.; cf. {%antaḥ-kara-viṣṭika%} (EI 6), {%antara%}
<div n="lb">(EI 15), etc.
<LEND>

<L>370<pc>022<k1>अन्तःप्रतीहार<k2>अन्तः-प्रतीहार
{%Antaḥ-pratīhāra%}¦ (IE 8-3), officer in charge of defending the
<div n="lb">back gate of the palace or of the palace-gates as distinguished
<div n="lb">from the gates of the capital city.
<LEND>

<L>371<pc>022<k1>अन्तःपुर<k2>अन्तःपुर
{%antaḥpura,%}¦ cf. {%karaṇa%} (LP); the royal harem.
<div n="P">({%ML%}), the household; same as {%avarodhana%} in Aśoka's
<div n="lb">edicts.
<LEND>

<L>372<pc>022<k1>अन्तःपुराध्यक्ष<k2>अन्तःपुर्-आध्यक्ष
{%Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 13; SII 11-2), superinten-
<div n="lb">dent of the royal harem; same as {%Āntaḥpurika, Stryadhyakṣa,%} etc.,
<div n="lb">and Sanskrit-Kannaḍa {%Antaḥpura-vĕrgaḍĕ%} (IE 8-3); sometimes
<div n="lb">also called {%Mahāpradhāna, Mahāpasāyita, Hĕri-Lāḻa-Kannaḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%sandhivigrahin, Manĕ-vĕrgaḍĕ,%} etc., additionally.
<LEND>

<L>373<pc>022<k1>आन्तःपुरिक<k2>आन्तःपुरिक
{%Āntaḥpurika%}¦ (EI 13, 14, 18, 19, 23; HD), officer in charge
<div n="lb">of the royal harem; cf. {%Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa,%} etc. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. IX, p. 305.

<L>374<pc>022<k1>अन्तःपुरमहामात्र<k2>अन्तःपुर-महामात्र
{%Antaḥpura-mahāmātra%}¦ (HD), officer in charge of the royal
<div n="lb">harem, mentioned in the Masulipatam plates of Amma II
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIV, p. 276). Cf. {%Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra%}
<div n="lb">of Rock Edict XII of Aśoka (CII 1).

<L>375<pc>022<k1>अन्तःसिद्धिक<k2>अन्तः-सिद्धिक
{%antaḥ-siddhika%}¦ (CII 4), same as {%abhyantara-siddhika.%}
<LEND>

<L>376<pc>022<k1>अन्तमहामात्र<k2>अन्त महामात्र
{%Anta mahāmātra%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 1), executive officers in
<div n="lb">charge of the bordering districts of an empire and probably not
<div n="lb">ambassadors at the courts of neighbouring kings. Cf. {%Antapāla.%}
<LEND>

<L>377<pc>022<k1>अन्तपाल<k2>अन्तपाल
{%Antapāla%}¦ (EI 9), frontier guard; explained by some as
<div n="lb">‘an officer in charge of the boundaries’ (HD). Cf. {%Arthaśāstra,%}
<div n="lb">I. 12 (one of the 18 {%tīrthas%}); II. 21; V, 1; Kāmandaka, XII.
<div n="lb">5; {%Mālavikāgnimitra,%} Act. I. See {%Anta-mahāmātra.%}
<LEND>
[Page-023+ 40]

<L>378<pc>023<k1>अन्तर<k2>अन्तर
{%antara%}¦ (CII 1), a period of time.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 15), name of a tax; cf. {%antar-ādāya, antaḥ-kara,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>379<pc>023<k1>अन्तरा<k2>अन्तरा
{%antarā%}¦ (CII 1), ‘in the interval’.

<L>380<pc>023<k1>अन्तरादाय<k2>अन्तर्-आदाय

<L>381<pc>023<k1>अन्तराल<k2>अन्तराल

<L>382<pc>023<k1>अन्तरालमण्डप<k2>अन्तराल-मण्डप

<L>383<pc>023<k1>अन्तरङ्ग<k2>अन्तरङ्ग
{%Antaraṅga%}¦ (IE 8-3; BL), explained as ‘a privy councillor
<div n="lb">or a physician’, though the same person is known to be called
<div n="lb">{%Rāja-vaidya%} (i. e. the royal physician) and {%Antaraṅga;%} probably
<div n="lb">a private secretary; but mentioned along with {%Vaiśvāsika%}
<div n="lb">(EI 3); regarded by some as a class of royal servants very
<div n="lb">intimate with the king, probably the same as {%Ābhyantara%} (HD).
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 286; Vol. XII, p. 99.
<LEND>

<L>384<pc>023<k1>आन्तरावड्डि<k2>आन्तरावड्डि
{%āntarāvaḍḍi%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12; 33), a variant reading of
<div n="lb">{%āturāvaḍḍi%} (q. v.); name of a tax; cf. {%rintakābaḍḍi.%}
<LEND>

<L>385<pc>023<k1>अन्तरविनियोग<k2>अन्तर-विनियोग
{%antara-viniyoga%}¦ (SITI), individual share to make up the
<div n="lb">shortage in the total revenue occasioned by the grant of exemp-
<div n="lb">tion of {%antar-āya%} or {%uḻvari.%}
<LEND>

<L>386<pc>023<k1>अन्तराय<k2>अन्तर्-आय
{%antar-āya%}¦ (EI 22, 23; SII 1, 2), explained as ‘a tax’,
<div n="lb">‘revenue’ or ‘a kind of revenue’; same as {%antar-ādāya;%} also
<div n="lb">explained as internal revenue or taxes levied by local bodies,
<div n="lb">called {%uḻvari%} in Tamil (SITI).
<LEND>

<L>387<pc>023<k1>अन्तरायक्काशु<k2>अन्तराय-क्काशु, अन्तराय-प्पाट्टम्
{%antarāya-kkāśu, antarāya-ppāṭṭam%}¦ (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil;
<div n="lb">explained as ‘internal taxes or minor taxes like the profession
<div n="lb">tax, etc., payable to the village assembly’.
<LEND>

<L>388<pc>023<k1>अन्तरिका<k2>अन्तरिका
{%antarikā%}¦ (CII 1), a period of time passed.
<LEND>

<L>389<pc>023<k1>अन्तरिक्ष<k2>अन्तरिक्ष
{%antarikṣa%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘cypher’.

<L>390<pc>023<k1>अन्तरीप<k2>अन्तरीप
{%antarīpa%}¦ (EI 12), an island.

<L>391<pc>023<k1>अन्तर्वंशिक<k2>अन्तर्वंशिक
{%Antarvaṃśika%}¦ (HD), officer in charge of the inner apart-
<div n="lb">ments or harem. See {%Arthaśāstra,%} I. 12 (mentioned among
<div n="lb">the 18 {%tīrthas%}); {%Kādambarī%} (para. 88); {%Daśakumāracarita,%} III;
<div n="lb">cf. {%Antarveśika%} in the {%Amarakośa,%} Kṣatriya-varga, 8.
<LEND>

<L>392<pc>023<k1>अन्तेवासिन्<k2>अन्तेवासिन्

<L>555<pc>030<k1>अष्ट<k2>अष्ट
{%aṣṭa,%}¦ cf. {%aṣṭa-bhoga,%} probably ‘all kinds of enjoyment’
<div n="lb">(and not merely ‘eight’ kinds) ensuring {%tejaḥ-svāmya%} or owner-
<div n="lb">ship endowed with complete authority. Cf. {%aṣṭādaśa,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>556<pc>030<k1>आष्टभागिक<k2>आष्ट-भागिक
{%āṣṭa-bhāgika%}¦ (CII 1), ‘[a village] paying one-eighth
<div n="lb">of the produce [instead of the usual rate of one-sixth or so]’.
<LEND>

<L>557<pc>030<k1>अष्टभोग<k2>अष्ट-भोग
{%aṣṭa-bhoga%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 14, 17), privileges of the donee
<div n="lb">of a rent-free holding, believed to be grouped into eight
<div n="lb">classes which are sometimes enumerated as {%nidhi, nikṣepa, jala,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha%} and {%sādhya.%} Cf. {%aiśvary-āṣṭaka%}
<div n="lb">and {%aṣṭa-bhūti%} (EI 33); also {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya.%}
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), the eight privileges associated with the enjoy-
<div n="lb">ment of rent-free land, also enumerated as (1) {%nidhi%} (a
<div n="lb">treasure or a hoard, i. e. a natural hoard such as a mine),
[Page-031+ 40]
<div n="lb">(2) {%nikṣepa%} (a treasure hidden or stored up by some one),
<div n="lb">(3) {%akṣīṇa%} (permanent or lasting benefits), (4) {%āgāmin%} (future
<div n="lb">benefits); (5) {%sañcita%} (benefits already stored up), (6) {%jala%}
<div n="lb">(waters); (7) {%taru%} (trees) and (8) {%pāṣāṇa%} (stones). See
<div n="lb">{%JAHRS,%} Vol. X, p. 124. {%Pāṣāṇa%} seems to mean ‘hilly area’.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), eight kinds of rights in enjoying landed property;
<div n="lb">mentioned sometimes as {%vikraya, dāna, vinimaya, jala, taru,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, nidhi%} and {%nikṣepa,%} and also as {%nidhi, nikṣepa, jalāmṛta,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha%} and {%sādhya.%}
<LEND>

<L>558<pc>031<k1>अष्टभोगतेजःस्वाम्य<k2>अष्टभोग-तेजःस्वाम्य
{%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%}¦ (IA 8), unbridled ownership
<div n="lb">endowed with all the rights associated with the enjoyment of
<div n="lb">property; translated as ‘with the eight rights of full possession’
<div n="lb">though {%aṣṭa%} probably means ‘all’ and not merely ‘eight’ (cf.
<div n="lb">{%aṣṭādaśa,%} etc.); cf. {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmyaṃ ca krayeṇ = ādāya%} (EI
<div n="lb">23), ‘having secured the {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%} rights by pur-
<div n="lb">chase’; (IA 19), translated as ‘the proprietorship of all the
<div n="lb">glory of the {%aṣṭa-bhoga%}’, and {%aṣṭa-bhoga%} explained as ‘the
<div n="lb">deposits of buried treasure ({%nidhi-nikṣepa%}), water, stones, the
<div n="lb">{%akṣīṇī,%} that which may accrue, that which has been made
<div n="lb">property, that which may be made property, and augmen-
<div n="lb">tation’. But there is probably no justification for taking
<div n="lb">{%nidhi-nikṣepa%} as a single unit.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmya-daṇḍaśulka-yukta%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 102), mentioned along with {%nidhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%nikṣepa-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣ-prakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita.%} The
<div n="lb">separate mention of these two groups shows that {%aṣṭa-bhoga%}
<div n="lb">vaguely indicated all kinds of proprietary rights.
<LEND>

<L>559<pc>031<k1>अष्टभूति<k2>अष्ट-भूति
{%aṣṭa-bhūti%}¦ (EI 33), same as {%aṣṭa-bhoga.%}
<LEND>

<L>560<pc>031<k1>अष्टादश<k2>अष्टादश
{%aṣṭādaśa,%}¦ cf. {%aṣṭādaśa-jāti-parihāra%} (IE 8-5); literally,
<div n="lb">‘eighteen’; actually, ‘all’ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 115). Cf.
<div n="lb">Oḏiyā {%aṭhara-gaḍajāta%} (EI 26). See {%aṣṭa, ṣaṭtriṃśat, ṣaṭpañcāśat,%}
<div n="lb">{%bāhattara,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>561<pc>031<k1>अष्टादशदोष<k2>अष्टादश-दोष
{%aṣṭādaśa-doṣa%}¦ (SII 1), the eighteen or all sins.
<LEND>

<L>562<pc>031<k1>अष्टादशजाति<k2>अष्टादश-जाति
{%aṣṭādaśa-jāti%}¦ (CITD), same as {%aṣṭādaśa-prajā;%} the 18
<div n="lb">castes. Kittel enumerates the 18 castes of the Kannaḍa-
<div n="lb">speaking area as the Brāhmaṇa, Kṣatriya, Vaiśya, Liṅgavanta,
<div n="lb">Baṇajige, Gaṅgaḍikāra-vokkaliga, Maḍivāli, Kelasiga, Kuṟuba,
<div n="lb">Kumbāṟa, Kaṭuka, Baḍagi, Akkasālĕ, Toreya, Uppāra, Besta,
<div n="lb">Holeya and Mādiga. But really the number 18 means ‘all’
<div n="lb">in such cases. The number 36 has the same meaning in the
[Page-032+ 40]
<div n="lb">Bengali expression {%chatriś-jāti,%} ‘36 castes’. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XXX, p. 115.
<LEND>

<L>563<pc>032<k1>अष्टादशप्रजा<k2>अष्टादश-प्रजा
{%aṣṭādaśa-prajā%}¦ (CITD), same as {%aṣṭādaśa-jāti, aṣṭādaśa-%}
<div n="lb">{%prakṛti.%}
<LEND>

<L>564<pc>032<k1>अष्टादशप्रकृति<k2>अष्टादश-प्रकृति
{%aṣṭādaśa-prakṛti,%}¦ cf. {%s-āṣtādaśa-prakṛty = opeta%} (EI 2);
<div n="lb">all classes of tenants; tenants belonging to all communities.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), ‘the eighteen (i. e. all) officials (i. e. classes of
<div n="lb">officials)’.
<LEND>

<L>565<pc>032<k1>अष्टदिग्गज<k2>अष्ट-दिग्गज
{%aṣṭa-diggaja%}¦ (EI 33), eight poets at king Kṛsṇadevarāya's
<div n="lb">court at Vijayanagara.
<LEND>

<L>566<pc>032<k1>अस्तगिरि<k2>अस्त-गिरि
{%asta-giri%}¦ (IA 22), the mythical Sun-set mountain.
<LEND>

<L>567<pc>032<k1>आष्टाहिका<k2>आष्ट्-आहिका
{%āṣṭ-āhikā%}¦ (EI 8), Jain festival; same as {%aṣṭ-āhnika%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>568<pc>032<k1>अष्टाह्निक<k2>अष्ट्-आह्निक, अष्ट्-आह्निका
{%aṣṭ-āhnika, aṣṭ-āhnikā%}¦ (EI 8, 33), Jain festival held in the
<div n="lb">months of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika; also called {%aṣṭ-%}
<div n="lb">{%āhnika-parvan;%} same as {%aṭṭhāi-mahotsava.%} See the Halsi plates
<div n="lb">of Kadamba Ravivarman (c. 490-538 A. D.) in {%Ind. Ant.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. VI, pp. 25-26. Cf {%The Successors of the Sātavāhanas,%}
<div n="lb">p. 271; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, p. 47 and note; cf. p. xvi.
<LEND>

<L>569<pc>032<k1>अष्टक<k2>अष्टक
{%aṣṭaka%}¦ (EI 7), same as {%ba-di%} 8; worship of the manes
<div n="lb">with oblations to them.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṭṭagam%} (SII 13), division of land, and {%aṭṭagattār%}
<div n="lb">(SII 13), share-holders in a land. See {%dvādaśaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>570<pc>032<k1>अष्टकुल<k2>अष्ट-कुल
{%aṣṭa-kula,%}¦ cf. Tamil {%ūr-ĕṭṭu%} (SITI); the committee of eight
<div n="lb">members of the village assembly ({%ūr%}); taxes payable for the
<div n="lb">expenses of the committee (cf. {%eṇ-per-āyam%} which may also refer
<div n="lb">to the eight major items of revenue). See {%añjaṣṭa-sabhā.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa%} (IE 8-3; EI 31), an administrative
<div n="lb">board (like the {%Pañcāyat%}) consisting of eight (or more)
<div n="lb">members representing various classes or communities of people;
<div n="lb">cf. {%grām-āṣṭa-kul-ādhikaraṇa; mahattar-ādy-aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>571<pc>032<k1>अष्टमीपक्ष<k2>अष्टमी-पक्ष
{%aṣṭamī-pakṣa%}¦ (CII 1), used to indicate {%pakṣ-āṣṭamī,%} i. e.
<div n="lb">the eighth {%tithi%} of each fortnight.
<LEND>

<L>572<pc>032<k1>अस्तम्ब<k2>अस्तम्ब
{%astamba,%}¦ cf. {%samudaya-bāhy-ādy-astamba%} (EI 23), ‘land
<div n="lb">originally devoid of vegetation which does not yield any
<div n="lb">revenue to the State’.
<LEND>

<L>573<pc>032<k1>अष्टमिका<k2>अष्टमिका
{%aṣṭamikā,%}¦ same as {%śalamāna%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>574<pc>032<k1>अष्टाङ्ग<k2>अष्टाङ्ग
{%aṣṭāṅga%}¦ (CITD), the eight constituents of {%yoga%} consisting
<div n="lb">of (1) {%niyama%} (restraint of the mind), (2) {%āsana%} (a parti-
<div n="lb">cular posture or mode of sitting), (3) {%prāṇāyāma%} (restraining or
<div n="lb">suspending the breath during the mental recitation of the names
[Page-033+ 40]
<div n="lb">or attributes of a deity), (4) {%yama%} (self-control), (5) {%pratyā-%}
<div n="lb">{%hāra%} (restraining the organs), (6) {%dhāraṇa%} (the faculty of
<div n="lb">retaining in the mind, steady abstraction of mind), (7)
<div n="lb">{%dhyāna%} (abstract contemplation, religious meditation), and
<div n="lb">(8) {%samādhi%} (perfect absorption of thought in the one object
<div n="lb">of meditation, i. e. the Supreme Spirit); mentioned in connec-
<div n="lb">tion with obeisance, it means the 8 parts of the body, viz., the
<div n="lb">two hands, chest, forehead, two knees and two feet (cf. {%aṣṭāṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%namaskāra%}).
<LEND>

<L>575<pc>033<k1>अष्टाङ्गभक्तिक्रम<k2>अष्टाङ्ग-भक्ति-क्रम
{%aṣṭāṅga-bhakti-krama%}¦ (EI 19), eight forms of worship;
<div n="lb">same as {%aṣṭa-vidh-ārcana,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>576<pc>033<k1>अष्टाङ्गनमस्कार<k2>अष्टाङ्ग-नमस्कार
{%aṣṭāṅga-namaskāra%}¦ (HA), obeisance with the eight
<div n="lb">limbs (viz. forehead, chest, two hands, two knees and two feet)
<div n="lb">done by lying straight on the ground, face downwards. See
<div n="lb">{%pañc-āṅga-namaskāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>577<pc>033<k1>अष्टपरिपालन<k2>अष्ट-परिपालन
{%aṣṭa-paripālana%}¦ (SITI), deities of the eight cardinal
<div n="lb">points; same as {%aṣṭa-dikpāla.%}
<LEND>

<L>578<pc>033<k1>अष्टप्रहारिक<k2>अष्टप्रहारिक
{%Aṣṭaprahārika%}¦ (IA 17), probably an official designation;
<div n="lb">may be derived from {%aṣṭa-prahara;%} probably ‘a watchman’.
<div n="lb">The correct form would, in that case, be {%āṣṭaprāharika,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>579<pc>033<k1>अष्टप्राहरिका<k2>अष्टप्राहरिका, अष्टप्रहरिक्या
{%aṣṭaprāharikā, aṣṭapraharikyā%}¦ (LP), ‘within 24 hours’.
<LEND>

<L>580<pc>033<k1>अष्टपुष्पिका<k2>अष्ट-पुष्पिका
{%aṣṭa-puṣpikā%}¦ (EI 15), ‘eightfold offering of flowers’.
<LEND>

<L>581<pc>033<k1>अष्टावधान<k2>अष्टावधान
{%Aṣṭāvadhāna%}¦ (IA 11), one who has the power of
<div n="lb">listening and grasping eight things at a time; epithet of a poet.
<LEND>

<L>582<pc>033<k1>आष्टवर्गिक<k2>आष्टवर्गिक
{%Āṣṭavargika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 7), probably, the superintendent
<div n="lb">of eight departments; mentioned as a {%Pātra.%}
<LEND>

<L>583<pc>033<k1>अष्टविधभक्तिक्रिया<k2>अष्ट-विध-भक्ति-क्रिया
{%aṣṭa-vidha-bhakti-kriyā%}¦ (SITI), eight aspects of worship
<div n="lb">including {%arcanā, vandana, smaraṇa, pāda-sevana, stava, pradakṣiṇa,%}
<div n="lb">{%sakhya%} and {%ātma-nivedana%} or {%ātm-ārpaṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>584<pc>033<k1>अष्टविधार्चन<k2>अष्ट-विध्-आर्चन, अष्ट-विध्-आर्चना
{%aṣṭa-vidh-ārcana, aṣṭa-vidh-ārcanā%}¦ (EI 19), same as {%aṣṭāṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhakti-krama,%} the eight forms of worship.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 14; SITI), explained as ‘worship with eight
<div n="lb">materials, e. g., {%jala%} (water), {%gandha%} (scent), {%puṣpa%} (flower),
<div n="lb">{%akṣatā%} (grains), {%dhūpa%} (incense), {%dīpa%} (lamps), {%naivedya%} (food)
<div n="lb">and {%tāmbula%} (betel)’.
<LEND>

<L>585<pc>033<k1>आस्थानमण्डप<k2>आस्थान-मण्डप
{%āsthāna-maṇḍapa%}¦ (EI 4), an assembly hall.
<LEND>

{%Āsthāyika-puruṣa%}¦ (IA 8), official designation; probably
<div n="lb">the same as {%Sthāyin;%} may be ‘hereditary village officials’.
<LEND>

<L>587<pc>033<k1>अस्ति<k2>अस्ति
{%asti%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol XXVIII, p. 302, note 2), a mere
<div n="lb">particle used to introduce the narration of a grant.
<LEND>
[Page-034+ 40]

{%aśv-āḍḍāṇaka-patra%}¦ (LP), deed for mortgaging a horse.

<L>599<pc>034<k1>अश्वाध्यक्ष<k2>अश्व्-आध्यक्ष
{%Aśv-ādhyakṣa%}¦ (EI 18), superintendent of stables or
<div n="lb">cavalry officer; cf. {%Aśva-sādhanika, Aśvapati.%}
<LEND>

<L>600<pc>034<k1>अश्वघासकायस्थ<k2>अश्व-घास-कायस्थ
{%Aśva-ghāsa-kāyastha%}¦ (HD), a petty officer in charge
<div n="lb">of the fodder for horses. Cf. {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} III. 489.
<LEND>

<L>601<pc>034<k1>अश्वमेध<k2>अश्वमेध
{%aśvamedha%}¦ (CII 3, 4), a sacrificial ceremony centering
<div n="lb">in a horse, generally performed by independent monarchs.
<div n="lb">Kings celebrating the sacrifice sometimes assumed suitable
<div n="lb">titles (cf. {%Aśvamedha-parākrama%} and {%Aśvamedha-Mahendra%} claimed
<div n="lb">respectively by Samudragupta and Kumāragupta I on their
<div n="lb">coins). Some kings performed two, four or more horse-sacri-
<div n="lb">fices. For a list of the performers of {%aśvamedha%} known form
<div n="lb">epigraphic and numismatic records, see {%Sundaram Pillai Com.%}
<div n="lb">{%Vol.,%} pp. 93 ff.
<LEND>

<L>602<pc>034<k1>आश्वमेध<k2>आश्वमेध
{%āśvamedha%}¦ (EI 12), same as {%āśvamedhika.%}

<L>603<pc>034<k1>अस्वामिक<k2>अस्वामिक
{%asvāmika%}¦ (EI 19), anarchy.
<LEND>

<L>604<pc>034<k1>अश्वपति<k2>अश्वपति
{%Aśvapati%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII 4)), cf. {%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Nara-%}
<div n="lb">{%pati-rāja-tray-ādhipati;%} royal title; the king as ‘the leader of the
<div n="lb">cavalry’; title of the Vijayanagara kings on account of their
<div n="lb">strength in horses (ASLV); title assumed by the rulers of
<div n="lb">some royal families.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9, 21; CII 3; HD), an official title meaning either the
<div n="lb">master of the stables or the commander of the cavalry; cavalry
<div n="lb">officer; cf. {%Aśv-ādhyakṣa%} (EI 18). See {%CII,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 259.
<LEND>

<L>605<pc>034<k1>अश्वपतिगजपतिनरपतिमूवरुरायरगण्ड<k2>अश्वपति-गजपति-नरपति-मूवरु-रायर-गण्ड
{%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-mūvaru-rāyara-gaṇḍa%}¦ (IE 8-2),
[Page-035+ 40]
<div n="lb">title of the Vijayanagara kings; Kannaḍa translation of
<div n="lb">the title {%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-rāja-tray-ādhipati.%}
<LEND>

<L>606<pc>035<k1>अश्वपतिगजपतिनरपतिराजत्रयाधिपति<k2>अश्वपति-गजपति-नरपति-राज-त्रय्-आधिपति
{%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-rāja-tray-ādhipati%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII
<div n="lb">4), holder (or, lord of the holders) of the three royal titles,
<div n="lb">viz., leader of the cavalry, leader of the elephant corps and
<div n="lb">leader of infantry; title assumed by the rulers of certain
<div n="lb">dynasties. Cf. {%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Narapati-muvaru-rāyara-gaṇḍa.%}
<LEND>

<L>607<pc>035<k1>अश्वारोह<k2>अश्वारोह
{%Aśvāroha%}¦ (EI 18), a trooper.

<L>610<pc>035<k1>अश्वशालाकरण<k2>अश्वशाला-करण

<L>619<pc>035<k1>आटविक<k2>आटविक

<L>620<pc>035<k1>अठगानी<k2>अठ-गानी
{%aṭha-gānī,%}¦ a coin equal to a {%ṭaṅka;%} there are {%do-gānī%}
<div n="lb">((1/4) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%cau-gānī%} ((1/2) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%cha-gānī%} ((3/4) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%bārah-%}
<div n="lb">{%gānī%} (1(1/2) {%ṭaṅkas%}), {%caubīs-gānī%} (3 {%ṭaṅkas%}), {%aḍatālīs-gānī%}

<L>621<pc>035<k1>अथर्ववेद<k2>अथर्व-वेद
{%Atharva-veda%}¦ (CII 3; etc.), one of the four Vedas.
<div n="lb">See {%Veda.%}
<LEND>

<L>622<pc>035<k1>अतिब्रह्मण्य<k2>अति-ब्रह्मण्य
{%Ati-brahmaṇya%}¦ (CII 3), probably meaning ‘extremely
<div n="lb">friendly to the Brāhmaṇas’ and not ‘a devout worshipper
<div n="lb">of the god Brahman’. See {%Parama-brahmaṇya.%}
<LEND>

<L>623<pc>035<k1>अतिधृति<k2>अतिधृति
{%atidhṛti%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘nineteen’.
<LEND>

{%atijagalī%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘thirteen’.

{%atipara%}¦ (EI 24), an inveterate foe.

<L>626<pc>036<k1>अतिप्रसङ्ग<k2>अतिप्रसङ्ग
{%atiprasaṅga%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 347, note 5), a
<div n="lb">case in which a grammatical rule exceeds its sphere.

<L>627<pc>036<k1>अतिरात्र<k2>अतिरात्र
{%atirātra%}¦ (CII 3), name of a particular sacrifice.

<L>628<pc>036<k1>अतिरेक<k2>अतिरेक
{%atireka%}¦ (CII 1), excess; cf. {%mano-'tireka,%} ‘enthusiasm’.

{%atisattra%}¦ (EI 27), name of a sacrifice.

<L>630<pc>036<k1>अतीत<k2>अतीत
{%atīta%}¦ (IA 17), ‘expired’; cf. {%Śaka-nṛpa-kāl-ātīta-%}
<div n="lb">{%saṃvatsareṣu.%} The word {%gateṣu,%} sometimes additionally used,
<div n="lb">refers to the expiry of the expired years.
<LEND>

<L>631<pc>036<k1>अतीलराज्य<k2>अतील-राज्य
{%atīla-rājya%}¦ (IA 19), indicates that so many years
<div n="lb">‘since [the commencement of] the reign have [now] passed’;
<div n="lb">used in connection with the regnal reckoning of Govindapāla
<div n="lb">and Lakṣmaṇasena and rarely with the years of an era (e. g.
<div n="lb">the Vikrama-saṃvat associated with the reign of a legendary
<div n="lb">king named Vikramāditya). See also {%gata-rājya%} and {%vinaṣṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%rājya.%} Cf. {%JAS,%} Letters, Vol. XX, 1954, pp. 43 ff.
<LEND>

<L>632<pc>036<k1>अतिथि<k2>अतिथि
{%atithi%}¦ (EI 10; CII 3, 4), reception of guests; one
<div n="lb">of the five daily rites ({%mahāyajñas%}) of a Brāhmaṇa.
<div n="lb">See {%sattra.%}
<LEND>

<L>633<pc>036<k1>आतिथ्य<k2>आतिथ्य
{%ātithya%}¦ (HRS), land assigned to government officers for
<div n="lb">public charities, as indicated by the {%Arthaśāstra.%}

<L>708<pc>040<k1>आवसथिक<k2>आवसथिक
{%Āvasathika%}¦ (IE 8-3), variously explained as ‘the superin-
<div n="lb">tendent of {%avasathas,%} i. e. colleges or {%dharma-śālās%}’, ‘the super-
<div n="lb">visor of the royal palace and other government buildings’
<div n="lb">({%Hist. Beng.,%} I, ed. Majumdar, p. 284); ‘one who keeps the
<div n="lb">domestic fire ({%āvasathya%}) burning with daily offerings’
<div n="lb">(D. Bhattacharya, {%Halāyudha's Brāhmaṇasarvasva,%} p. xx); etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9, 11, 24), title or family name of Brāhmaṇas. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Āvasathin.%}
<LEND>

<L>709<pc>040<k1>आवसथिन्<k2>आवसथिन्
{%Āvasathin%}¦ (EI 23), explained as ‘one who keeps the sacred
<div n="lb">fire called {%āvasathya%}’; cf. {%Āvasathika.%}
<LEND>

<L>710<pc>040<k1>अवष्कर<k2>अवष्कर

<L>714<pc>040<k1>आवात<k2>आवात
{%āvāta%}¦ (IE 8-5), same as {%vāta,%} storm; cf. {%udvāta.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 32; CII 3; etc.), a fiscal term referring to the
<div n="lb">income from lands as a result of changes caused by natural
<div n="lb">agencies; an income probably resulting from storms. See
<div n="lb">{%vāta,%} probably meaning ‘a storm or tempest’; also {%āvāt-āya.%}

<L>730<pc>041<k1>आय<k2>आय
{%āya%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33; CII 3; SII 1, 2), a fiscal term meaning ‘revenue’,
<div n="lb">‘tax’.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), literally, income; a general term denoting
<div n="lb">‘taxes’; cf. {%va%}l13{%iy-āyam%} (SITI), tolls on the roadway.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), revenue in general according to the {%Arthaśāstra%}
<div n="lb">and other authorities; a special branch of revenue according to
<div n="lb">the inscriptions of the Uccakalpa kings and later epigraphs.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), profit, income, receipt; tribute; corn given
<div n="lb">by the well-to-do villagers to the hereditary servants of the
<div n="lb">village as their established fees of office.
<LEND>

<L>764<pc>043<k1>बदि<k2>ब-दि
{%ba-di%}¦ (IE 8-1; CII 3; etc.), contraction of {%bahula-pakṣa-dina%}
<div n="lb">or {%ºdivasa;%} also spelt {%va-di,%} cf. {%śu-di;%} abbreviations of separate
<div n="lb">words (see {%ba, di, śu%} and {%va%}) and not words in themselves,
<div n="lb">{%ba-di%} or {%va-di%} referring to the dark fortnight and {%śu-di%} the
<div n="lb">bright fortnight; they denote the fortnight and the solar
<div n="lb">or civil day, with reference to the lunar {%tithi,%} in the fortnight.
<LEND>

<L>779<pc>043<k1>बाह्य<k2>बाह्य
{%bāhya,%}¦ cf. {%bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya%} (IE 8-5; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
[Page-044+ 40]
<div n="lb">XVI, p. 276, text line 14); ‘income from the sale of things
<div n="lb">imported in a village’, same as Tamil {%pu%}ṟ{%av-āyam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">‘revenue from external sources (collected mainly in cash)’ or
<div n="lb">Tamil {%pu%}ṟ{%a-kaḍamai%} (SITI), ‘external taxes’, explained as
<div n="lb">taxes and fees payable to the State. But {%pu%}ṟ{%a-kaḍamai%} is the
<div n="lb">same as {%pu%}ṟ{%av-āyam. Bāhya%} and {%ābhyantatra%} may thus mean
<div n="lb">respectively taxes payable to the king and those payable to
<div n="lb">the village authorities. See {%ābhyantara.%} Cf. {%samudaya-bāhy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādya-stamba%} (EI 23), ‘land covered with original shrubs,
<div n="lb">i. e. waste which does not yield any revenue to the State’.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), a class of royal servants distinguished from
<div n="lb">{%Antaraṅga.%} See {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VIII. 426, 680, 1542.
<LEND>

{%balaharaṇa,%}¦ cf. {%balaharaṇena%} (LP), same as Gujarātī {%lāine.%}

<L>790<pc>044<k1>बालकमहाराजकुमार<k2>बालक-महाराजकुमार
{%Bālaka-mahārājakumāra%}¦ (EI), a young prince.

{%Balakauṣṭhika,%}¦ cf. {%Valatkauṣan.%}

<L>792<pc>044<k1>बालालय<k2>बाल्-आलय
{%bāl-ālaya%}¦ (SITI) temporary shrine to lodge the images
<div n="lb">of gods when repairing a temple; small shrine probably consist-
<div n="lb">ing of a single room wherein the images of all the gods
<div n="lb">are lodged; same as Tamil {%iḻaṅ-koyil.%}
<LEND>

<L>793<pc>044<k1>बलानक<k2>बलानक
{%balānaka%}¦ (HA), a {%maṇḍapa%} above the entrance of a Jain
<div n="lb">shrine or the courtyard of a shrine, later known as {%ṭhākorkhānā.%}
<div n="P">({%BL%}), a stone seat.
[Page-045+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 8), same as Marāṭhī {%balāṇī,%} ‘a raised seat along the
<div n="lb">walls of the {%gābhāra%} or {%sabhā-maṇḍapa%} of a temple.’

<L>794<pc>045<k1>बलयष्टि<k2>बल-यष्टि
{%bala-yaṣṭi%}¦ (EI 33; CII 4), a stout memorial pillar.

<L>795<pc>045<k1>बल्हरा<k2>बल्हरा
{%Balharā%}¦ (IE 8-2), Arabic corruption of {%Vallabha-rāja%}
<div n="lb">through Prakrit {%Ballaha-rāa.%}
<LEND>

<L>796<pc>045<k1>बलि<k2>बलि
{%bali%}¦ (IE 8-5; HRS), voluntary gift (afterwards, com-
<div n="lb">pulsory contribution) and tribute from the subjects as indicated
<div n="lb">by Vedic literature; later, tax in general as suggested by the
<div n="lb">standard lexicons; king's grain share, identical with {%bhāga%}
<div n="lb">but different from {%kara%} according to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} but not
<div n="lb">the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman (cf. {%bali-śulka-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāga%} in line 14). The Rummindei inscription of Aśoka also
<div n="lb">distinguishes between {%bali%} and {%bhāga%} and seems to identify
<div n="lb">{%bali%} with {%kara%} (or with pilgrims' tax). See {%Select Inscriptions,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 71, 173.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 10, 23, 32; CII 3, 4), an offering to creatures; one
<div n="lb">of the five {%mahāyajñas%} or sacrificial rites. Cf. {%bali-caru-vaiśvadev-%}
<div n="lb">{%āgnihotra-kratu%} (EI 26), the five rites of a Brāhmaṇa.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), offering of flowers, fruits, uncooked rice, etc.,
<div n="lb">to the gods; same as {%śrībali.%} Cf. {%Nārāyaṇa-baly-upahāra%} in the
<div n="lb">sense of {%Nārayaṇa-pūjā%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. VI, p. 363).
<div n="P">{%Cf. varāha-bali,%} ‘pig sacrifice’ ({%Ep Ind.,%} Vol. XXXVI,
<div n="lb">p. 39). Cf. {%śrī-bali, havir-bali.%}
<LEND>

<L>797<pc>045<k1>बलीवर्द<k2>बलीवर्द
{%balīvarda,%}¦ cf. {%a-paramparā-balīvarda,%} etc. (IE 8-5); a
<div n="lb">pair of bullocks (which the villagers were obliged to provide
<div n="lb">for the cart of the royal officers when they camped or toured
<div n="lb">in their villages). See also {%vara-balīvarda.%}

<L>816<pc>046<k1>बसिलेओस्<k2>बसिलेओस् बसिलेओन् मेगलोउ
{%Basilĕos Basilĕon Mĕgalŏu%}¦ (IE 8-2), Greek; ‘of the great

<div n="lb">Parthian kings; adapted from old Persian {%Khshyāthiya Khshāya-%}

<div n="lb">{%rajasa Rajarajasa%} (or {%Rajadirajasa%}) {%mahalasa%} (Sanskrit {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%rājasya Rājarājasya mahataḥ%} or {%Rājātirājasya mahataḥ%}).

<L>817<pc>046<k1>बसिलेओस्<k2>बसिलेओस् मेगलोउ

<div n="lb">found in the legend on the coins of Indo-Greek kings at first
<div n="lb">translated in Prakrit as {%Rajasa mahatakasa%} (Sanskrit {%Rājñaḥ%}

<L>823<pc>046<k1>बेण्टकार<k2>बेण्टकार
{%Beṇṭakāra%}¦ (CITD), same as {%Beṭakāra, beṭa%} (Telugu-
<div n="lb">Kannaḍa) meaning ‘the separation of lovers’. As an epithet of
<div n="lb">a ruler, {%Beṇṭakāra%} means ‘one who causes the separation of his
[Page-047+ 40]
<div n="lb">enemies’ wives from their husbands’; cf. {%ripu-nārī-vaidhavya-vidhā-%}

<L>834<pc>047<k1>भद्रघट<k2>भद्र-घट

{%bhadr-āsana%}¦ (EI 25), a throne.

<L>838<pc>047<k1>भाग<k2>भाग
{%bhāga%}¦ (IE 8-5; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HRS), the king's share
<div n="lb">of the produce, distinguished from {%bali%} in the Rummindei
<div n="lb">inscription and the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman and
<div n="lb">from {%kara%} in many other records; later, tax in general,
<div n="lb">identical with {%bali%} and {%kara%} (according to lexicons); cf.
<div n="lb">references in the {%Arthaśāstra%} to (1) {%lavaṇa-bhāga%} (king's share
<div n="lb">of salt sold by private merchants), (2) {%udaka-bhāga%} (king's
<div n="lb">grain share levied as water-tax upon irrigated fields),
<div n="lb">(3) king's share of the produce of mines leased out to private
<div n="lb">persons; (4) share paid to the king by merchants for selling
<div n="lb">the royal merchandise.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), dues (see {%kara%}); generally, the king's share of
<div n="lb">grains, which was originally one-sixth.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4), a subdivision of a district or a territory.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23, 33), an allotment; a share.
<LEND>

<L>839<pc>047<k1>भागभोग<k2>भाग-भोग
{%bhāga-bhoga%}¦ (CII 3; etc.), a fiscal expression in which
[Page-048+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%bhāga%} means the king's share of the produce and {%bhoga%} the
<div n="lb">periodical supplies made by tenants to the king; cf. {%bhāga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhog-ādika, bhāga-bhoga-kara-hirany-ādika%} ({%EI%} 23), meaning
<div n="lb">‘royal dues’; see {%bhāga,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>840<pc>048<k1>भागभोगकर<k2>भाग-भोग-कर
{%bhāga-bhoga-kara%}¦ (HRS), taken by some as a single levy
<div n="lb">and explained as the king's grain-share, identical with {%bhāga%}
<div n="lb">of the {%Arthaśāstra%} and {%bali%} of the Smṛtis, though distinguished
<div n="lb">from {%dhānya%} in a Maitraka record, where it has been supposed
<div n="lb">to mean a fixed contribution in kind as distinguished from
<div n="lb">the contribution consisting of a share of the produce. If
<div n="lb">{%bhāgabhogakara%} was a single levy (and did not indicate
<div n="lb">{%bhāga, bhoga%} and {%kara%}), it may have really been a tax collected
<div n="lb">in lieu of {%bhāga%} (grain share) and {%bhoga%} (periodical offerings).
<LEND>

<L>841<pc>048<k1>भागदुघ<k2>भागदुघ
{%Bhāgadugha%}¦ (HD), an official title; probably the same
<div n="lb">as {%Bhāgahāra.%} See Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 9.
<LEND>

<L>842<pc>048<k1>भागहर<k2>भागहर
{%Bhāgahara%}¦ (EI 24), same as {%Bhāgin;%} a collector of the
<div n="lb">king's grain share. Cf. {%Bhāgahāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>843<pc>048<k1>भागहार<k2>भागहार
{%Bhāgahāra%}¦ (HD), ‘he who recovers the [king's] share
<div n="lb">[of the produce of land]’; one of the six officers of each
<div n="lb">village, according to Śukra, II. 120. Cf. {%Bhāgahara.%}

<L>844<pc>048<k1>भागलाग<k2>भागलाग
{%bhāgalāga,%}¦ cf. {%bhāgalāg-ādika%} (LP), payments in kind or taxes.

<L>845<pc>048<k1>भागकर्षण<k2>भाग-कर्षण

{%bhagaṇa%}¦ (IA 19), a bangle.

<L>847<pc>048<k1>भगवद्भक्त<k2>भगवद्-भक्त
{%Bhagavad-bhakta%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a Vaiṣṇava sectarian
<div n="lb">title indicating ‘a follower of the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu)’.
<LEND>

<L>848<pc>048<k1>भगवत्<k2>भगवत्
{%Bhagavat%}¦ (ML; CII 3, 4), ‘the lord’ or ‘the divine’; an
<div n="lb">epithet of divinities such as Viṣṇu, Buddha, Jinendra, Nārāyaṇa,
<div n="lb">Śiva, the Sun-god, Kārttikeya, etc; also applied to sages, etc.
<div n="lb">in the sense of ‘venerable’, e. g. to Vyāsa, the arranger of the
<div n="lb">Vedas; rarely applied to kings apparently on account of their
<div n="lb">saintliness (cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 19).
<LEND>

<L>849<pc>048<k1>भागवत<k2>भागवत
{%Bhāgavata%}¦ (LL), a votary of the Bhagavat (Viṣṇu).
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3; etc.), a Vaiṣṇava sect.
<LEND>

<L>850<pc>048<k1>भगवती<k2>भगवती
{%Bhagavatī%}¦ (CII 3, 4; etc.), feminine form of {%Bhagavat%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.); often applied to goddesses, etc.
<LEND>

<L>851<pc>048<k1>भगवत्पादाचार्य<k2>भगवत्पाद्-आचार्य
{%Bhagavatpād-ācārya%}¦ (EI 6), epithet of a Vaiṣṇava religious
<div n="lb">teacher.
<LEND>

<L>852<pc>048<k1>भगवत्पादकर्मकर<k2>भगवत्पाद-कर्मकर
{%Bhagavatpāda-karmakara%}¦ (CII 4), ‘a servant of the feet
<div n="lb">of the Bhagavat’; epithet of a temple official.
<LEND>
[Page-049+ 40]

<L>853<pc>049<k1>भागिक<k2>भागिक
{%Bhāgika%}¦ ({%IE%} 8-3; HD), probably, the collector of the
<div n="lb">king's grain share; same as {%Bhāgahāra.%} See Vogel, {%Ant. Ch.%}
<div n="lb">{%St.,%} p. 166. Cf. {%Bhāgin.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 13), mentioned along with {%Bhogika;%} probably, one
<div n="lb">getting a share [in a free-holding]. See {%Aṃśa-bṛhadbhogika.%}

<L>854<pc>049<k1>भागिन्<k2>भागिन्

<div n="lb">grain share.

<L>855<pc>049<k1>भग्न<k2>भग्न
{%bhagna%}¦ (CII 1), ‘departed’, ‘lost’, i. e. ‘inferior’; cf.
<div n="lb">the Hindī verb {%bhāgnā,%} Bengali {%bhāgā.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. bhagna-viśīrṇa-samāracana,%} repairs to the rents in and
<div n="lb">the wornout parts of a building ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p.

<L>856<pc>049<k1>भग्नक्रिया<k2>भग्न-क्रिया

<L>857<pc>049<k1>भाग्यरेखा<k2>भाग्य-रेखा

<L>859<pc>049<k1>भैक्षक<k2>भैक्षक

<L>860<pc>049<k1>भैत्र<k2>भैत्र

<L>861<pc>049<k1>भक्षण<k2>भक्षण
{%bhakṣaṇa,%}¦ Tamil {%pakkiṇam%} (SITI), confection.

<L>898<pc>051<k1>भट<k2>भट
{%Bhaṭa%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HD), same as {%Bhaṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%manuṣya;%} probably derived from {%bhṛta%} which is sometimes used
<div n="lb">in its place. Generally used along with {%cāṭa%} or {%chātra;%} literally,
<div n="lb">‘a soldier’; but really a {%Pāik, Barkandāz%} or {%Piāda,%} i. e. a constable.
<div n="lb">It is spelt as {%bhaṭṭa%} in the medieval inscriptions of Eastern
<div n="lb">India, though rarely the two are distinguished. See {%Bhaṭṭa.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a personal servant or soldier.

<L>910<pc>052<k1>भट्टारक<k2>भट्टारक
{%Bhaṭṭāraka%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII 3; EI 30), title used in Sanskrit
<div n="lb">but really Prakrit derived from Sanskrit {%bhartṛ%} through the
<div n="lb">plural form {%bhartāraḥ%} = Prakrit {%bhaṭṭāra%} (see {%Svāmin%}); often
<div n="lb">suffixed to the personal names of paramount sovereigns as
<div n="lb">well as of feudatory {%Mahārājas,%} or {%Yuvarājas%} (crown-princes);
<div n="lb">applied to gods and priests in the sense of ‘worthy of worship
<div n="lb">or sacred’. Cf. {%bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta, bhaṭṭāraka-%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāsena-parigṛhīta,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33), the king.
<div n="P">({%SII%} 1), title of Jain religious teachers.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), title of Śaiva ascetics, etc.
<div n="P">({%LP%}), a respected man.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 11), probably, epithet of the chief priest of a temple.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a deity; a spiritual preceptor.
<LEND>

<L>911<pc>052<k1>भट्टारकपादानुध्यात<k2>भट्टारक-पाद्-आनुध्यात

<L>956<pc>054<k1>भित्वरमान्य<k2>भित्वरमान्य

<L>957<pc>054<k1>भोग<k2>भोग
{%bhoga%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 3; EI 23, 33), literally, ‘enjoyment’
<div n="lb">(cf. {%bhukti%}); a {%jāgīr%} (cf. {%Mahārāja-Sarvanātha-bhoga, Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāmantādhipati-Śrīdhara-bhoga,%} etc.); possession (cf. {%bhog-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhīnā gṛhītā%}). Originally ‘enjoyment’; then ‘property’,
<div n="lb">‘a {%jāgīr%}’; then also a territorial unit which was generally the
<div n="lb">subdivision of a district (IE 8-4; EI 25; 28; CII 4). See
<div n="lb">{%bhukti, āhāra.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. Kaivarta-bhoga%} (IE 8-4; EI 2; CII 1), the fishermen's
<div n="lb">preserve.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5; EI 29, 30; HRS), periodical supplies of fruits,
<div n="lb">firewood, flowers and the like which the villagers had to
<div n="lb">supply to the king; sometimes explained as ‘tax in kind’
<div n="lb">(CII 4).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 1), [an object of] enjoyment.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), tax-free land set apart for the enjoyment of a
<div n="lb">person for the performance of specified services; same as
<div n="lb">{%mānya.%} See {%bhogottara, Bhogin,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. bhoge%} (LP), ‘for the right of enjoyment’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. sa-bhoga%} (IA 9), privilege of the donee of rent-free
<div n="lb">land; probably refers to {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%} (q. v.).
<LEND>
[Page-055+ 40]

<L>958<pc>055<k1>भोगभाग<k2>भोग-भाग
{%bhoga-bhāga%}¦ (CII 3, etc.,), the same as {%bhāga-bhoga.%} Cf.
<div n="lb">{%bhoga-bhāga-kara-hiraṇy-ādi%} (EI 23), royal dues; see {%bhoga,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>959<pc>055<k1>भोगजनपद<k2>भोग-जनपद
{%bhoga-janapada%}¦ (EI 12), probably, a free-holding in the
<div n="lb">country-side, or a rent-free area.
<LEND>

<L>961<pc>055<k1>भोगपति<k2>भोगपति
{%Bhogapati%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 25, 27; HD), an {%Ināmdār%} or {%Jāgīr-%}
<div n="lb">{%dār,%} or an officer in charge of {%inām%} lands or {%jāgīrs,%} or the
<div n="lb">officer in charge of a territorial unit called {%bhoga.%} The last
<div n="lb">alternative is more probable; cf. {%Bhogika,%} etc. See also
<div n="lb">{%Mitākṣarā%} on the {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} I. 320; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX,
<div n="lb">p. 298. See {%Bhuktipati, Bhogikapāla,%} etc.

{%Bhogapatika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23), same as {%Bhogapati.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">mortgage.
<LEND>

<L>968<pc>055<k1>भोगिजन<k2>भोगि-जन
{%Bhogi-jana%}¦ (EI 33), explained as ‘a village headman’.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Bhogika,%}
<LEND>

<L>969<pc>055<k1>भोगिक<k2>भोगिक
{%Bhogika%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3; HD; BL), the owner of a
<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} or {%jāgīr;%} a {%Jāgīrdār%} or {%Ināmdār;%} same as {%Bhogin.%} See
<div n="lb">{%Bhoktṛ.%} Explained by some as the head of a district, or the
<div n="lb">collector of the State's share of the produce of lands taken in
<div n="lb">kind ({%Bomb. Gaz.,%} Vol. I, Part i, p. 82). See {%CII,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">pp. 96, 104.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3); EI 18; 23), a groom or horse-keeper, accord-
<div n="lb">ing to lexicons; cf. its Telugu modification {%Bhoi,%} ‘a palanquin-
<div n="lb">bearer’. But these meanings may have been derived from the
<div n="lb">first as the people appear to have enjoyed rent-free land for
<div n="lb">their services.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33), same as {%Bhojaka%} meaning a {%Jāgīrdār%} or {%Ināmdār.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), explained as ‘the head of a {%bhoga%}’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 5), explained as ‘a village proprietor’.
<LEND>

<L>970<pc>055<k1>भोगिकपाल<k2>भोगिकपाल, भोगिकपालक

<div n="lb">tendent of the {%jāgīrs%} and cess collector; cf. {%Bhogapati.%}

<L>1000<pc>057<k1>भुजङ्ग<k2>भुजङ्ग
{%bhujaṅga%}¦ (IA 20), an ogre. The word {%bhujaṅga%} was
<div n="lb">adopted in Javanese in the sense of a ‘pupil, disciple, scholar;
<div n="lb">a philologist, poet, literary councillor; an officially appointed
<div n="lb">professional usually residing at or near the court’. It has been
<div n="lb">suggested on this basis that Bhavadeva-bhaṭṭa's title
<div n="lb">{%Bālavalabhī-bhujaṅga%} may really mean ‘the pupil of the
<div n="lb">Bālavalabhī school’. See {%IHQ,%} Vol. XXVII, pp. 80-82.
<LEND>

<L>1001<pc>057<k1>भुजिष्यपत्र<k2>भुजिष्य-पत्र

<L>1004<pc>057<k1>भुक्ति<k2>भुक्ति
{%bhukti%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 28, 33), a province including a group
<div n="lb">of districts called {%viṣaya%} or {%maṇḍala;%} small territorial unit
<div n="lb">like a Pargana in South India; cf. {%bhoga.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3; 8-4; CII 3), literally, ‘enjoyment’; same as
<div n="lb">{%bhoga;%} a {%jāgīr;%} originally meaning ‘enjoyment’; then ‘property’
<div n="lb">or ‘a {%jāgīr%}’; then ‘a province’. See {%bhoga.%}
<div n="P">({%BL%}), personal property.
[Page-058+ 40]
<div n="P">{%Cf. putti, pukti%} (SITI), the enjoyment of a property.
<LEND>

<L>1005<pc>058<k1>भुक्तिमण्डल<k2>भुक्ति-मण्डल
{%bhukti-maṇḍala%}¦ (IE 8-4), originally a {%bhukti%} but later on
<div n="lb">a {%maṇḍala;%} cf. {%Daṇḍabhukti-maṇḍala, āhāra-viṣaya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1006<pc>058<k1>भुक्तिपति<k2>भुक्तिपति
{%Bhuktipati%}¦ (IE 8-3), a {%Jāgīrdār;%} or, the officer in charge
<div n="lb">of a territorial unit called {%bhukti.%} See {%Bhogapati.%}
<LEND>

<L>1009<pc>058<k1>भूमि<k2>भूमि, भूमी
{%bhūmi, bhūmī%}¦ (EI 3; CII 3), a particular land measure;
<div n="lb">sometimes also called {%bhū%} and regarded as equal to four {%bhū-%}
<div n="lb">{%māṣakas%} (cf. {%bhū%}).
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a territorial division.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7-1-2), ‘one’.
<LEND>

<L>1010<pc>058<k1>भूमिच्छिद्र<k2>भूमिच्छिद्र
{%bhūmicchidra%}¦ ({%IE%} 8-5), sometimes explained as ‘unculti-
<div n="lb">vable land’. See {%bhūmicchidra-nyāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1011<pc>058<k1>भूमिच्छिद्रन्याय<k2>भूमिच्छिद्र-न्याय
{%bhūmicchidra-nyāya%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HRS),
<div n="lb">literally, ‘the maxim of the fallow land’; the principle of the
<div n="lb">rent-free enjoyment of land by one who brings it under cultiva-
<div n="lb">tion for the first time. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol XXIX, p. 86. The
<div n="lb">maxim is based on the old custom of allowing a person, who
<div n="lb">first brings a plot of fallow or jungle land under cultivation
<div n="lb">for the first time, to enjoy it without paying rent. {%Bhūmi-%}
<div n="lb">{%cchidra%} gradually came to mean ‘uncultivable land’. See
<div n="lb">{%bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya, avanirandhra-nyāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1012<pc>058<k1>भूमिच्छिद्रपिधानन्याय<k2>भूमिच्छिद्रपिधान-न्याय
{%bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 11), the same as
<div n="lb">{%bhūmicchidra-nyāya;%} but it means ‘the maxim of covering up the
<div n="lb">hole in the land’ referring probably to the reclamation of
<div n="lb">fallow land for the first time; cf. {%bhūmicchidra%} understood
<div n="lb">in the sense of {%kṛṣy-ayogyā bhū,%} ‘land unfit for cultivation’.
<div n="lb">See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIX, p. 86.
<LEND>

<L>1013<pc>058<k1>भूमिच्छिद्रविधानन्याय<k2>भूमिच्छिद्रविधान-न्याय
{%bhūmicchidravidhāna-nyāya%}¦ (EI 24); same as {%bhūmicchidra-%}
<div n="lb">{%nyāya, bhumicchidrapidhāna-nyāya. Chidra-vidhāna = furrowing.%}
<LEND>

{%bhūmipeṇḍe%}¦ (ASLV), a mark of honour.
<LEND>

<L>1019<pc>059<k1>भूत<k2>भूत
{%bhūta%}¦ (CII 1), a living being.

<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘five’.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3, etc.), a fiscal term; cf. {%sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya,%}
<div n="lb">in which we have sometimes {%pātta%} (mistake for {%upātta%}), {%upātta,%}
<div n="lb">{%āvāta%} or {%vāta.%} See {%bhūta-pāta,%} etc.

<L>1022<pc>059<k1>भूतपात<k2>भूत-पात
{%bhūta-pāta,%}¦ cf. {%sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya%} (IE 8-5); often written
<div n="lb">as {%bhūta-vāta%} and {%bhūt-opātta;%} probably, an event relating to
<div n="lb">the elements, such as an earthquake. See {%bhūta-pāta-pratyāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1023<pc>059<k1>भूतपातप्रत्याय<k2>भूत-पात-प्रत्याय
{%bhūta-pāta-pratyāya%}¦ (CII 4), explained by some as ‘excise
<div n="lb">and octroi duties’; but really, ‘the income resulting from storms,
<div n="lb">earthquakes, changes in the course of a river, etc’. See {%bhūta-%}
<div n="lb">{%vāta-pratyāya,%} etc. {%Pāta%} may be a mistake for {%upātta%} or {%vāta.%}

<L>1024<pc>059<k1>भूतप्रत्याय<k2>भूत-प्रत्याय

<div n="lb">changes in the land. See {%bhūta-vāta-pratyāya,%} etc.

<L>1025<pc>059<k1>भूतपूर्व<k2>भूतपूर्व

<L>1026<pc>059<k1>भूतवातप्रत्याय<k2>भूत-वात-प्रत्याय
{%bhūta-vāta-pratyāya%}¦ (EI 23; CII 4; HRS), ‘the income
<div n="lb">derived from the elements and the winds’; explained by some
<div n="lb">as ‘excise and octroi duties’; but really, ‘the income resulting

<L>1062<pc>061<k1>ब्रह्मक्षत्र<k2>ब्रह्म-क्षत्र, ब्रह्म-क्षत्रिय
{%Brahma-kṣatra, Brahma-kṣatriya%}¦ (EI 5, 12, 24), a Kṣatriya
<div n="lb">family claiming descent from a Brāhmaṇa parent; a family in
<div n="lb">which the blood of the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas has been
<div n="lb">mixed. See {%Vishveshvaranand Ind. Journ.,%} Vol. I, pp. 87 ff., etc.
<div n="lb">In one record ({%Journ. Karnatak Univ.,%} Vol. II, No 2, January
<div n="lb">1959, p. 47), the Nāgavaṃśa, to which a Kadamba king's
<div n="lb">minister Māyideva belonged, is called {%Brahma-kṣatra%} because it
<div n="lb">originated from the intercourse of its progenitor Nāgarāja with
<div n="lb">a Brāhmaṇa girl. {%Brahma-vaiśya%} should be likewise explained.
<LEND>

<L>1063<pc>061<k1>ब्रह्ममहाराज<k2>ब्रह्म-महाराज
{%Brahma-mahārāja,%}¦ cf. {%pirama-mārāya%}ṉ (SITI), title of Brāh-
<div n="lb">maṇa ministers. See {%Brahm-ādhirāja, Brahmarāja.%}
