<L>1136<pc>065<k1>चक्रवर्तिक्षेत्र<k2>चक्रवर्ति-क्षेत्र
{%cakravarti-kṣetra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 33), the sphere of influence
<div n="lb">of an Indian imperial ruler lying between the Himalayas and
<div n="lb">the three seas, viz. Bay of Bengal, Indian Ocean and
<div n="lb">Arabian Sea; sometimes regarded as conterminous with
<div n="lb">{%Āryāvarta%} or {%Dākṣiṇātya.%} See Sircar, {%Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 1 ff.
<LEND>

<L>1137<pc>065<k1>चक्रवर्तिन्<k2>चक्रवर्तिन्
{%Cakravartin%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 21, 28; CII 3, 4), a title of para-
<div n="lb">mount sovereignty; the title of an emperor. See {%Saptama-%}
<div n="lb">{%cakravartin;%} also {%Cakreśvara, Cakrin.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), often suffixed to expressions like {%Pratāpa, Prau-%}
<div n="lb">{%ḍhapratāpa, Bhujabalapratāpa, Niḥśaṅkapratāpa,%} etc., and some-
<div n="lb">times also to dynastic names like {%Yādava.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 31), epithet of the Buddha.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), cf. {%cakravarti-kṣetra.%}
<LEND>

<L>1138<pc>065<k1>चक्रेश्वर<k2>चक्रेश्वर

<L>1140<pc>065<k1>चक्षुस्<k2>चक्षुस्
{%cakṣus%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘two’; cf. {%netra.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Pali {%cakkhu%} (EI 5), Buddhist; vision, five in number.
<div n="P">{%Cf. cakṣur-vadha,%} ‘killing at sight’, ‘killing instantaneously’;
<div n="lb">or probably ‘blinding of the eyes’. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII,
<div n="lb">p. 307 and note 1.

<L>1141<pc>065<k1>चलमर्तिगण्ड<k2>चलमर्तिगण्ड
{%Calamartigaṇḍa%}¦ (CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a title of the
<div n="lb">Kākatīya kings; from Kannaḍa {%gaṇḍa%} meaning ‘the husband,
<div n="lb">lord, master,’ i. e. ‘one who can control or punish’, and Telugu
<div n="lb">{%calam%} meaning ‘obstinacy, rudeness, overbearing’; translated
<div n="lb">as ‘one who is the controller or punisher of spiteful men or
<div n="lb">men of overbearing conduct’.
<LEND>

<L>1181<pc>067<k1>चट्<k2>चट्
{%caṭ,%}¦ cf. {%alīkaṃ caṭāpitam%} (LP), ‘circulated a false rumour’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. caṭanti%} (LP); ‘to accumulate’; also cf. Gujarātī {%ca%}ḏ{%hśe.%}
<LEND>

<L>1182<pc>067<k1>चाट<k2>चाट
{%Cāṭa%}¦ (HD), irregular soldiers according to Fleet and
<div n="lb">Bühler. Vogel ({%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 130-32) points out that
<div n="lb">Chamba is the only place where the ancient word {%Cāṭa%} is still
<div n="lb">extant in the modern form {%Cā%}ḏ meaning ‘the head of a Parganā’.
<div n="lb">An important privilege of a gift village was ‘not to be entered
<div n="lb">by {%Cāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas%}’. Inscriptions ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI,
<div n="lb">p. 221) often specify that the granted land was not to be entered
<div n="lb">by {%Cāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas%} except for seizing robbers and those guilty
<div n="lb">of harm or treason to the king (cf. {%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśyaṃ cora-%}
<div n="lb">{%drohaka-varjam%} in op. cit., Vol. VIII, p. 287). Sometimes we
<div n="lb">have {%bhaṭa-cāṭa-sevak-ādīn%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 211) and
<div n="lb">{%caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-jātīyān janapadān%} (ibid., Vol. XIV, p. 160).
[Page-068+ 40]
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3; CII 3, 4), generally mentioned along with
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭa;%} sometimes replaced by {%cāra%} (spy) and {%chātra%} (literally,
<div n="lb">‘umbrella-bearer’, but really, a constable, i. e. a {%Pāik%} or {%Piāda%});
<div n="lb">probably indicates the leader of a group of {%Bhaṭas,%} i. e. {%Pāiks%}
<div n="lb">and {%Piādas;%} a policeman leading a group of {%Pāiks.%} See {%caṭṭa.%}
<div n="lb">Yājñavalkya, I. 336, speaks of the duty of the king to
<div n="lb">protect people from the harassment caused by {%cāṭas,%} robbers
<div n="lb">and {%Kāyasthas%} and the {%Mitākṣarā%} explains {%cāṭa%} as persons
<div n="lb">who deprive people of their wealth after creating false confi-
<div n="lb">dence in them. According to Bṛhaspati quoted by Aparārka,
<div n="lb">‘dangers common to all are those arising from the {%cāṭas%} and
<div n="lb">thieves’. The word {%cāṭa%} in the passage {%tārkika-cāṭa-bhaṭa-rāj-%}
<div n="lb">{%āpraveśya%} in Śaṅkara's {%Bhāsya%} on the {%Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad%}
<div n="lb">is explained by Ānandagiri by saying that the {%cāṭas%} are those
<div n="lb">that transgress the rules of conduct for decent people and that
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭas%} are servants telling falsehood ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p. 296).
<div n="lb">But {%cāṭa%} is used in inscriptions in the sense of a royal official.
<LEND>

<L>1183<pc>068<k1>चटापक<k2>चटापक
{%caṭāpaka%}¦ (LP), ‘increasing [the rent already fixed]’; cf.
<div n="lb">Gujarātī {%ca%}ḏ{%hāvo.%}

<L>1200<pc>069<k1>चतुर्धरप्रतीहार<k2>चतुर्धर-प्रतीहार

<div n="lb">of the royal guards’. {%Caturdhara%} is modern {%Caudhari,%} written
<div n="lb">in Kannaḍa as {%Saudore, Saudare, Caudore, Cavudore%} and {%Cavudari%}

<L>1206<pc>069<k1>चातुर्मासी<k2>चातुर्मासी

<L>1207<pc>069<k1>चातुर्मासीपक्ष<k2>चातुर्मासी-पक्ष
{%cāturmāsī-pakṣa%}¦ (IA 18), the fortnight ending in a {%cātur-%}
<div n="lb">{%māsī%} (i. e. the full-moon of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika).
<LEND>

<L>1208<pc>069<k1>चातुर्मास्य<k2>चातुर्मास्य
{%cāturmāsya%}¦ (SII 11-1, CITD), the season consisting of 4
<div n="lb">months, viz. {%grīṣma%} consisting of the {%pūrṇimānta%} months of Caitra,
[Page-070+ 40]
<div n="lb">Vaiśākha, Jyeṣṭha and Āṣāḍha, {%varṣā%} consisting of Śrāvana,
<div n="lb">Bhādrapada, Āśvina and Kārttika; and {%hemanta%} consisting of
<div n="lb">Mārgaśīrṣa, Pauṣa, Māgha and Phālguna. This was the
<div n="lb">official division of the year which was popularly divided into six
<div n="lb">seasons, viz. {%grīṣma%} (Jyeṣṭha-Āṣāḍha), {%varṣā%} (Śrāvaṇa-Bhādra-
<div n="lb">pada), {%śarad%} (Āśvina-Kārttika), {%hemanta%} (Mārgaśīrṣa-Pauṣa),
<div n="lb">{%śīta%} (Māgha-Phālguna) and {%vasanta%} (Caitra-Vaiśākha). Some
<div n="lb">times, the word {%cāturmāsya%} specially means the four months of
<div n="lb">the year, containing the two seasons of {%varṣā%} and {%śarad,%} i. e.
<div n="lb">from Śrāvaṇa to Kārttika. During this period, Viṣṇu is
<div n="lb">supposed to sleep, so that religious celebrations are avoided.
<div n="lb">During the period, religious mendicants desisted from roving.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7; BL), related to the {%cāturmāsī%} or the full-moon day
<div n="lb">of Phālguna, Āshāḍha and Kārttika; a rite; same as {%cātur-%}
<div n="lb">{%māsya-vrata.%}
<LEND>

<L>1209<pc>070<k1>चातुर्मास्यव्रत<k2>चातुर्मास्य-व्रत
{%cāturmāsya-vrata%}¦ (EI 32), a rite. See {%cāturmāsya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1210<pc>070<k1>चतुर्मुखबिम्ब<k2>चतुर्मुख-बिम्ब
{%caturmukha-bimba%}¦ (EI 2), Jain; a four-sided slab with
<div n="lb">images on all the sides.
<LEND>

{%caturtha%}¦ (IE 8-8), one-fourth of the standard measure [of
<div n="lb">liquids like liquor].

<L>1215<pc>070<k1>चतुर्वर्णिन्<k2>चतुर्वर्णिन्
{%caturvarṇin%}¦ (LL), Jain; ‘consisting of four classes’; an
<div n="lb">epithet of the Jain community.
<LEND>

<L>1216<pc>070<k1>चतुर्वेदिभट्टत्तानप्पेरुमक्कल्<k2>चतुर्वेदि-भट्ट-त्तान-प्पेरुमक्कल्
{%caturvedi-bhaṭṭa-ttāna-pperumakkaḻ%}¦ (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil;
<div n="lb">general assembly of the Vedic scholars in a Brāhmaṇa village.
<LEND>

<L>1217<pc>070<k1>चतुर्वेदिमङ्गल<k2>चतुर्वेदि-मङ्गल
{%caturvedi-maṅgala%}¦ (IE 8-4; SITI), same as {%agrahāra;%} a
<div n="lb">village owned by Brāhmaṇas, generally tax-free; also called
<div n="lb">{%maṅgala;%} written as {%śaruppeṭi-maṅgalam%} in Tamil; sometimes suffix-
<div n="lb">ed to names of localities especially in the Tamil-speaking area.
<LEND>

<L>1218<pc>070<k1>चतुर्वेदिन्<k2>चतुर्वेदिन्

<div n="lb">versed in the four Vedas; one who has studied the four Vedas;
<div n="lb">later stereotyped as a family name among Brāhmaṇas.
<LEND>

<L>1219<pc>070<k1>चातुर्वीद्य<k2>चातुर्वीद्य
{%cāturvīdya%}¦ (EI 23, 32), cf. {%Caturvedin;%} ‘relating to the
<div n="lb">{%Caturvedin%}’, a community of Brāhmaṇas; cf. {%cāturvidya-grāma,%}
<div n="lb">{%cāturvidy-āgrahāra, cāturvidya-sāmānya%} (EI 22).

{%catur-upāya%}¦ (SII 1), the four expedients. Cf. {%upāya.%}

<L>1227<pc>071<k1>चौकडिका<k2>चौकडिका
{%caukaḍikā%}¦ (EI 11), a variety of the {%Pañcāyat%} system; cf.
<div n="lb">{%caturjātaka%} or {%cauthiā.%}
<div n="P">({%BL%}), explained as ‘a method of recovering stolen property’.
<LEND>

<L>1228<pc>071<k1>चौमुख<k2>चौमुख
{%caumukha%}¦ (HA), Sanskrit {%caturmukha%} (cf. {%caturmukha-bimba%});
<div n="lb">a quadruple image called {%pratimā sarvatobhadrikā%} (LL) in the
<div n="lb">Mathurā inscriptions of the Kuṣāṇa period, showing one Jina
<div n="lb">or several Jinas on each of the four faces; also seen on the top
<div n="lb">or in the centre of representations of the {%samavasaraṇa%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>1229<pc>071<k1>चौरचरट<k2>चौर-चरट
{%Caura-caraṭa%}¦ (LP), cf. Marāṭhī {%Cor-cilaṭāṃcā upadrav.%}
<LEND>

<L>1230<pc>071<k1>चौरासी<k2>चौरासी
{%caurāsī%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 3, 4), literally, ‘eightyfour’; same as
<div n="lb">{%caturaśīti%} (q. v.); a group of eightyfour villages; a Parganā
<div n="lb">consisting of eightyfour villages; sometimes the name of a
<div n="lb">Parganā and often suffixed to its name.
<LEND>

<L>1231<pc>071<k1>चौरवर्जम्<k2>चौर-वर्जम्
{%caura-varjam%}¦ (CII 3; HRS), cf. {%cora-varjam, coradaṇda-%}
<div n="lb">{%varjam, cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam;%} ‘with immunity from the
<div n="lb">police tax’ according to some; may really mean ‘without any
<div n="lb">right to inflict punishment on thieves and persons committing
<div n="lb">the crime of treason or to levy fines from them’; may also be
<div n="lb">connected with {%a-bhaṭa-praveśa%} so as to indicate that the {%bhaṭas%}
<div n="lb">should not enter except for catching thieves and persons
<div n="lb">committing the crime of treason; cf. {%Cāṭa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1232<pc>071<k1>चौरि<k2>चौरि
{%cauri%}¦ (ASLV), spelt {%chowrie%} in English; a flywhisk; some-
<div n="lb">times the right of its use was granted to persons as a mark
<div n="lb">of honour. See {%cāmara, cavarālu.%}
<LEND>

<L>1233<pc>071<k1>चौरिक<k2>चौरिक
{%Caurika%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XIX, p. 71), official designation.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Cāmara-kumāra, Caur-oddharaṇika.%}
<LEND>

<L>1234<pc>071<k1>चौरिका<k2>चौरिका
{%caurikā,%}¦ cf. {%carma-caurikā%} (LP), ‘theft of skin’.
<LEND>

<L>1235<pc>071<k1>चौरोद्धरण<k2>चौर्-ओद्धरण
{%caur-oddharaṇa%}¦ (EI 33; HRS), according to some, the
<div n="lb">right to punish or levy fines from thieves; probably, the right
<div n="lb">to recover stolen property; recovery of stolen property; cf.
<div n="lb">{%sa-chauroddharaṇa%} (IE 8-5; EI 23).
<LEND>
[Page-072+ 40]

<L>1236<pc>072<k1>चौरोद्धरणिक<k2>चौर्-ओद्धरणिक
{%Caur-oddharaṇika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23; CII 3), an official desig-
<div n="lb">nation indicating an officer in charge of the recovery of stolen
<div n="lb">property; a police officer; same as {%Cor-oddharaṇika, Caur-oddhartṛ.%}
<div n="P">({%HD; CII,%} Vol. III, p. 216), explained as ‘the thief-catcher
<div n="lb">or one who exterminates thieves’. But cf. {%Daṇḍ-odddharaṇika.%}
<LEND>

<L>1237<pc>072<k1>चौरोद्धर्तृ<k2>चौर्-ओद्धर्तृ

<div n="lb">{%valkyasmṛti,%} II. 271; also Kātyāyana quoted by Aparārka).

<L>1238<pc>072<k1>चौथिआ<k2>चौथिआ

<L>1256<pc>073<k1>छत्र<k2>छत्र
{%chatra,%}¦ an umbrella; cf. {%pañcāṅga-prasāda.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 27), an attendant or {%Piāda;%} cf. {%Chātra.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. Varāha-kṣetra = Barāh-chatra%} (Sircar, {%Studies in the%}
<div n="lb">{%Geography of Ancient and Medieval India,%} p. 221); corruption of
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%kṣetra.%}
<LEND>

<L>1257<pc>073<k1>छात्र<k2>छात्र
{%Chātra%}¦ (IE 8-3, 8-8; EI 23, 30), cf. {%a-bhaṭa-cchātra-%}
<div n="lb">{%prāveśya%} (IE 8-5); literally, ‘one bearing an umbrella’ or ‘the
<div n="lb">king's umbrella-bearer’; but probably the same as the {%Cāṭa%}
<div n="lb">or the leader of a group of {%Bhaṭas%} ({%Pāiks%} or {%Piādas%}) as in {%a-cāṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭa-prāveśya;%} a peon of the law-court. See {%Chatracchāyika.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), used in composition with {%bhaṭa%} and also singly;
<div n="lb">literally, ‘an umbrella-bearer’; but actually, a constable like
<div n="lb">a {%Pāik%} or {%Piāda.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), celibate ({%Brahmacārin%}) in charge of a temple
<div n="lb">and the {%śālai%} attached to it; also called {%Śaṭṭar, Śāttirar.%}
<LEND>

<L>1258<pc>073<k1>छत्रभङ्ग<k2>छत्र-भङ्ग
{%chatra-bhaṅga%}¦ (IA 8), ‘the breaking of the umbrella [of
<div n="lb">sovereignty]’; sometimes interpreted as ‘an interregnum’.
<LEND>

<L>1259<pc>073<k1>छत्राभोग<k2>छत्र्-आभोग
{%chatr-ābhoga%}¦ (IA 17), corrected from {%ṣatr-ābhoga%} and
<div n="lb">explained as ‘the expanse of the royal umbrella’; but really,
<div n="lb">‘the {%ābhoga%} (a territorial unit) called Ṣa(Kha)tra’.
<LEND>

<L>1260<pc>073<k1>छत्रच्छायिक<k2>छत्रच्छायिक

<div n="lb">{%Chātra.%}

<L>1274<pc>074<k1>छुट्<k2>छुट्

<L>1305<pc>075<k1>चोर<k2>चोर
{%cora%}¦ (IE 8-5), same as {%caura%} and {%cora-daṇḍa;%} probably,
<div n="lb">the power of punishing thieves and realising fines from them;
<div n="lb">cf. {%cora-varja;%} also {%Cāṭa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1306<pc>075<k1>चोरदण्डवर्जम्<k2>चोरदण्ड-वर्जम्
{%coradaṇḍa-varjam%}¦ (HRS), same as {%caura-varjam%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>1307<pc>075<k1>चोरदण्डवर्ज्य<k2>चोर-दण्ड-वर्ज्य
{%cora-daṇḍa-varjya%}¦ (CII 3), a fiscal term which means either
<div n="lb">that no fines for theft should be collected from the gift village
<div n="lb">or, more probably, that the donee was not entitled to fines
<div n="lb">realisable on thieves in the gift villages. But see also {%caura-varjam.%}
<LEND>

<L>1308<pc>075<k1>चोरद्रोहकवर्ज<k2>चोर-द्रोहक-वर्ज
{%cora-drohaka-varja%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a fiscal term which is
<div n="lb">similar to {%coradaṇḍa-varja.%} The word {%drohaka%} means one
<div n="lb">committing a crime against the king. See {%caura-varjam, Cāḷa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1309<pc>075<k1>चोरग्राह<k2>चोर-ग्राह
{%Cora-grāha%}¦ (HD), a thief-catcher (cf. Nārada, Pariśiṣṭa,
<div n="lb">verse 18; also Kātyāyana quoted by Aparārka).
<LEND>

<L>1310<pc>075<k1>चोरराजापथ्यकारिवर्जम्<k2>चोर-राजापथ्यकारि-वर्जम्
{%cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam%}¦ (HRS), ‘with immunity from
<div n="lb">the police tax’, according to some; seems to mean ‘without any
[Page-076+ 40]
<div n="lb">right to inflict punishment on or levy fines from thieves and
<div n="lb">rebels’. But see {%caura-varjam;%} also {%Cāṭa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1311<pc>076<k1>चोररज्जू<k2>चोर-रज्जू
{%cora-rajjū%}¦ (HRS), ‘the rope for binding thieves’; supposed
<div n="lb">to be the dues collected by the superintendent of the bound-
<div n="lb">aries of villages.
<LEND>

<L>1312<pc>076<k1>चोररज्जुक<k2>चोररज्जुक
{%Corarajjuka%}¦ (HD), probably the same as {%Dāṇdapāśika,%} an
<div n="lb">officer whose duty it was to secure robbers with ropes (cf.
<div n="lb">{%Arthaśāstra,%} IV. 13; II. 6 referring to {%cora-rajjū%} as a constituent
<div n="lb">of the {%rāṣṭra%}).
<LEND>

{%corāsī%}¦ (IE 8-4), same as {%caurāsī%} (q. v.).

<div n="lb">term which is the same as {%coradaṇḍa-varjya%} (q. v.). See also

<L>1370<pc>078<k1>दानादायदानीभोग<k2>दानादाय-दानीभोग
{%dānādāya-dānībhoga%}¦ (LP), explained as ‘local cess or road-
<div n="lb">cess’; {%dāya%} is explained as ‘a gift to Brāhmaṇas or temples’,
[Page-079+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%dānī%} as ‘land tax’ and {%bhoga%} as ‘right of enjoyment’; but probably,
<div n="lb">{%dāṇ-ādāya%} means excise or customs duties and {%dāni-bhoga%} a
<div n="lb">tax for the maintenance of the tax-collector.
<LEND>

<L>1371<pc>079<k1>दानाधिकारिन्<k2>दान्-आधिकारिन्
{%Dān-ādhikārin%}¦ (EI 12), officer in charge of gifts, mentioned
<div n="lb">along with the {%Śāsan-ādhikārika,%} ‘officer in charge of grants
<div n="lb">(or their writing)’. See {%Dharm-ādhikārin.%} It may also mean
<div n="lb">‘a tolls-collector’ (cf. {%dāna, Dānin%}).
<LEND>

<L>1372<pc>079<k1>दणाइक्<k2>दणाइक्
{%Daṇāik%}¦ (ASLV), corrupt form of {%Daṇdanāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">as {%deya-dharma.%}

{%dāna-palaṃ%}¦ (IA 11), actually {%dāna(ṃ*)palaṃ,%} i. e. ‘the {%dāna%}
<div n="lb">(levy) is one {%pala%}’.

<L>1381<pc>079<k1>दण्ड<k2>दण्ड
{%daṇḍa%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12), fine or tax, mentioned along with
<div n="lb">{%suṅka (śulka);%} a levy or free service (cf. {%prayāṇa-daṇda%}).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), fines; authority.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), fines; distinguished from {%atyaya%} in the {%Artha-%}
<div n="lb">{%śāstra.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), punishment.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), judicial punishment; sometimes possibly also
<div n="lb">‘administration’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 25), ‘five’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 30; LP), contraction of {%Daṇdanāyaka.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28), Oḏiyā; a path (cf. {%daṇḍā%}).
<div n="P">{%Cf. taṇḍu (SITI),%} a palanquin; a pole for carrying the
<div n="lb">vehicle on which the image of a deity is set up.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daṇḍu, taṇḍu%} (SITI), an army; going on a military
<div n="lb">expedition.
<div n="P">{%Cf. taṇdam%} (SII 1; CITD); fine, penalty or punishment;
<div n="lb">a punitive tax; a fine or tax payable as penalty.
<LEND>
[Page-080+ 40]

<L>1396<pc>080<k1>दण्डनाथ<k2>दण्डनाथ
{%Daṇḍanātha%}¦ (EI 16; CII 4; SII 1), commander of an
<div n="lb">army. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. V, p. 31. Cf. {%Daṇḍanāyaka,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>1397<pc>080<k1>दण्डनायक<k2>दण्डनायक
{%Daṇḍanāyaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 4; BL), probably a
<div n="lb">translation of Greek {%Strategos;%} a general; a leader of forces,
<div n="lb">an army officer; a military commander; also called {%Daṇḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%nātha, Daṇdanetṛ,%} etc.; sometimes also called {%Mahāsāmanta,%}
<div n="lb">{%Senādibāhattaraniyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpasāyita,%} etc., additionally; see {%Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Sarva-%}
<div n="lb">{%daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka.%}
[Page-081+ 40]
<div n="P">({%LP%}), generally, the viceroy or governor of a province;
<div n="lb">representative of the king.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), the commander of forces and officer in charge
<div n="lb">of administration; title of the provincial governors; similar to
<div n="lb">the {%Mansabdār%} of the Mughal period.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), a prefect of the police, according to Stein ({%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%taraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 951); ‘a General or Magistrate’, according to
<div n="lb">some (cf. Kielhorn's Southern List, Nos. 291, 292, 296). In
<div n="lb">the {%Bṛhatsaṃhitā%} (7. 2-4), the queen, {%Yuvarāja, Senāpati%} and
<div n="lb">{%Daṇḍanāyaka%} are placed on the same level in the matter of the
<div n="lb">staff ({%daṇḍa%}) to be prepared for them.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Taḍeya-daṇḍanāyaka,%} explained as ‘the general in
<div n="lb">charge of reserves’, from Kannaḍa, {%taḍĕ,%} ‘far, restraint’.
<LEND>

<L>1398<pc>081<k1>दाण्डनायक<k2>दाण्डनायक
{%Dāṇḍanāyaka%}¦ (EI 23; HD), same as {%Daṇdanāyaka.%} See
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XIX, p. 269.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a leader of forces; cf. {%Daṇḍanāyaka,%} etc.

<L>1403<pc>081<k1>दण्डपाशिक<k2>दण्डपाशिक

<div n="lb">an official who was probably the leader of a group of {%Dāṇḍikas;%}

<L>1438<pc>083<k1>दापक<k2>दापक

<div n="lb">{%Dūtaka;%} but really ‘one who causes another to give’, i. e. the

<L>1444<pc>084<k1>दर्शन<k2>दर्शन
{%darśana%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 32, 33), a levy; same as Persian
<div n="lb">{%nazrāna.%} Cf. Tamil {%tariśana-kāṇikkai%} (SITI), presents offered to a
<div n="lb">king or a chief when one meets him.

<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘six’; cf. {%dṛṣti,%} ‘two’.

<L>1449<pc>084<k1>दशबन्ध<k2>दशबन्ध
{%daśabandha%}¦ (SITI), variously explained as (1) one-tenth
<div n="lb">of the revenue set apart for repairs to the tanks and wells for
<div n="lb">irrigation purposes; (2) land, the income from which would
<div n="lb">be equal to the amount thus set apart; (3) the right of collect-
<div n="lb">ing one-tenth of the produce of lands irrigated from the waters
<div n="lb">of a tank or well by the person who repairs the water source;
<div n="lb">also explained as tax equal to one-tenth of the income of the
<div n="lb">subject (Ray, {%DHNI,%} Vol. II, p. 1113). See {%daśavandha.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}) tax or cess levied to keep the source of water
<div n="lb">supply like the tanks, etc., in good repair.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), rent-free land or probably land paying only
<div n="lb">one-tenth of the actual rent.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 20), one-tenth share.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daśa-bandhe%} (LP), ‘at 10 per cent’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daśavandha%} (SII 3), a tax.
<LEND>

<L>1450<pc>084<k1>दाशबन्ध<k2>दाशबन्ध-विसतिअ (विंशतिक) त्त्रिप्रस्थ

<L>1457<pc>085<k1>दशापचार<k2>दश्-आपचार
{%daś-āpacāra%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 29), same as {%daś-āparādha.%}
<LEND>

<L>1458<pc>085<k1>दशापराध<k2>दश्-आपराध
{%daś-āparādha%}¦ (CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the ten offences’; but
<div n="lb">really, the fines for the ten offences; cf. {%sa-daś-āparādha%} (IE 8-5);
<div n="lb">power to punish and realise fines for the ten offences; also
<div n="lb">called {%daś-āpacāra.%} According to the Buddhists, the ten sins
<div n="lb">were murder, theft, adultery, lying, calumny, insult, idle
<div n="lb">talk, hatred, covetousness and dogmatic error (A. Getty, {%The%}
<div n="lb">{%Gods of Northern Buddhism,%} p. xxv, note). For a Brahmanical
<div n="lb">list, see {%Dāśāparādhika;%} cf. {%pañca-mahāpātaka, pañc-āparādha.%}
<LEND>

<L>1459<pc>085<k1>दाशापराधिक<k2>दाशापराधिक
{%Dāśāparādhika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 29; HD), a judge dealing
<div n="lb">with the ten offences (viz. theft, murder of women, adultery, use
<div n="lb">of abusive language, violation of order, mixing of castes, illegal
<div n="lb">pregnancy, obscenity, assault and abortion, according to some).
<div n="lb">It has been said that the ten offences or {%aparādhas%} are those
<div n="lb">of which the king could take cognisance {%suo moto.%} For the ten
<div n="lb">{%aparādhas,%} see Kane, {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. III, p. 264; cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321.
<LEND>

<L>1460<pc>085<k1>दसरा<k2>दसरा
{%Dasarā%}¦ (EI 5), Āśvina su-di 10.
<LEND>

{%Daśaratha-strī%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘three’.

<div n="lb">same as {%Samayācāra%} or {%Samayācārya.%}

<L>1463<pc>085<k1>दशवन्ध<k2>दशवन्ध
{%daśavandha,%}¦ cf. {%daśavanna%} (IA 30), explained as ‘land
<div n="lb">granted to a person for repairing or building a tank on condi-
<div n="lb">tion of paying in money or kind one-tenth or some small
<div n="lb">share of the produce’ and as ‘land granted at one-tenth of the
<div n="lb">usual rates to a person in consideration of his constructing or
<div n="lb">repairing a tank’. See {%daśabandha.%}

<L>1478<pc>086<k1>देश<k2>देश
{%deśa%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 3, 4), a territorial term meaning a
<div n="lb">small area or a group of villages in some cases but a kingdom,
<div n="lb">district, tract or country in others.

<div n="lb">{%sthala,%} etc.

<div n="lb">officer in charge of a village or district.

<L>1505<pc>088<k1>देवाध्यक्ष<k2>देव्-आध्यक्ष
{%Dev-ādhyakṣa,%}¦ superintendent of religious foundations.
<div n="lb">See Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 99.
<LEND>

<L>1506<pc>088<k1>देवदि<k2>देवदि
{%devadi%}¦ (IA 19), ‘the establishment of a temple’.
<LEND>

<L>1507<pc>088<k1>देवद्रोणी<k2>देव-द्रोणी
{%deva-droṇī%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 10), usually taken to mean ‘a pro-
<div n="lb">cession of the images of gods’, or ‘procession or ablution of
<div n="lb">images’; but probably, ‘rent-free property of a temple’ ({%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV pp. 143-44); cf. {%deva-droṇī-sambaddha%} (EI
<div n="lb">23). A Prakrit inscription ({%A.R. Ep.,%} 1959-60, No. B 173)
<div n="lb">has {%deva-doṇi data%} = Sanskrit {%deva-droṇī dattā.%}
<LEND>

<L>1508<pc>088<k1>देवद्रोणीसम्बद्ध<k2>देवद्रोणी-सम्बद्ध
{%Devadroṇī-sambaddha%}¦ (IE 8-3), same as {%Devadroṇy-adhikṛta;%}
<div n="lb">officer in charge of temple property ({%devadroṇī,%} usually taken
<div n="lb">in the sense of ‘a procession of the images of gods)’.
<LEND>

<L>1509<pc>088<k1>देवद्रोण्यधिकृत<k2>देवद्रोण्य्-अधिकृत
{%Devadroṇy-adhikṛta%}¦ (IE 8-3; BL), explained as ‘the superin-
<div n="lb">tendent of the procession of idols’; but probably, the superin-
<div n="lb">tendent of the property of a temple or of temple property in
<div n="lb">general; same as {%Devadroṇī-sambaddha;%} cf. {%deva-droṇī%} (EI 13).
<LEND>

<L>1510<pc>088<k1>देवागार<k2>देव्-आगार
{%dev-āgāra,%}¦ cf. {%tevāram, devāram%} (SITI), a temple.
<LEND>

<L>1511<pc>088<k1>देवाग्रहार<k2>देव्-आग्रहार
{%dev-āgrahāra%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 23, 25, 30; SITI), rent-free
<div n="lb">village granted to a temple; same as {%deva-bhoga,%} etc.; see {%agra-%}
<div n="lb">{%hāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>1512<pc>088<k1>देवगृह<k2>देव-गृह
{%deva-gṛha%}¦ (EI 24), a temple.

<L>1513<pc>088<k1>देवगृहजगती<k2>देवगृह-जगती

<div n="lb">ground’ or ‘a temple with the buildings attached to it.’ But
<div n="lb">cf. {%jagatī.%}

{%devaka%}¦ (IA 23), the guardian spirit or a god.

<L>1546<pc>090<k1>देयधर्म<k2>देय-धर्म
{%deya-dharma%}¦ (EI 1; CII 3; ML), a pious gift; an appro-
<div n="lb">priate religious gift; an expression used in numerous donative
<div n="lb">inscriptions. A deity installed for worship was also called
<div n="lb">{%deya-dharma%} (sometimes {%deva-dharma%}) in medieval records. Same
<div n="lb">as {%dharma-deya, dharma-dāya, dharma-dāna.%}
<LEND>

<L>1570<pc>091<k1>धरण<k2>धरण

<div n="P">(IE 8-8), a silver coin weighing 24 {%ratis%} (cf. {%JNSI,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">II, pp. 28-29) or the half of a {%gadyāṇaka%} according to the {%Līlāvatī;%}
<div n="lb">silver coin of 32 {%ratis%} according Manu, etc.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-8), same as {%kārṣāpaṇa%} or {%purāṇa.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 3), a gold coin or weight (320 {%ratis%}).

<L>1572<pc>091<k1>धारणी<k2>धारणी
{%dhāraṇī%}¦ (IA 9; BL), a magic litany usually of the Bud-
<div n="lb">dhists; an occult Indian charm, especially Buddhistic; a short
<div n="lb">formula intended to represent a particular Tantra text, the
<div n="lb">recitation of the {%dhāraṇī%} being regarded as equally meritorious
<div n="lb">as that of the Tantra itself ({%Univ. Cey. Rev.,%} January-April,
<div n="lb">1960, p. 62, note 42).
<LEND>

<L>1573<pc>091<k1>धारणिक<k2>धारणिक
{%dhāraṇika%}¦ (LP), a debtor.

<L>1575<pc>091<k1>धर्म<k2>धर्म
{%dharma%}¦ (SII 1), the sacred law; religious merit; a meri-
<div n="lb">torious gift, a pious work, a charity; moral precept.
[Page-092+ 40]
<div n="P">(EI 24), law or law and order.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, p. 116) virtue or religious merit.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), sometimes prefixed to the titles of kings
<div n="lb">and crown-princes; cf. {%Dharma-mahārāja,%} etc.

<L>1576<pc>092<k1>धर्मबद्ध<k2>धर्म-बद्ध

<L>1577<pc>092<k1>धर्मबान्धव<k2>धर्म-बान्धव
{%dharma-bāndhava,%}¦ ‘one whose only friend is his religious
<div n="lb">faith’ or ‘a person who has become the friend of another on an
<div n="lb">oath in the name of his religious faith’ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV,
<div n="lb">p. 144).
<LEND>

<L>1578<pc>092<k1>धर्मचक्र<k2>धर्म-चक्र
{%dharma-cakra%}¦ (CII 3; LL), Buddhist; the wheel of Dharma
<div n="lb">which was the symbol representing the Buddha on early
<div n="lb">Buddhist sculptures, on stone inscriptions and on seals attached
<div n="lb">to copperplate grants.
<div n="P">({%HA%}) Jain; the wheel of law supposed to move in
<div n="lb">the sky in front of a Jina when he goes on his wanderings from
<div n="lb">place to place; one of the members of the {%parikara%} of a Jina
<div n="lb">image.
<LEND>

<L>1579<pc>092<k1>धर्मचक्रमुद्रा<k2>धर्मचक्र-मुद्रा
{%dharmacakra-mudrā%}¦ (EI 29), seal bearing the emblem of
<div n="lb">the Buddhist wheel of law.
<LEND>

<L>1580<pc>092<k1>धर्मदान<k2>धर्म-दान
{%dharma-dāna%}¦ (ML; SITI), a religious gift; a gift for religious
<div n="lb">merit; grant of tax-free land; same as {%deya-dharma.%}
<LEND>

<L>1581<pc>092<k1>धर्मदेय<k2>धर्म-देय
{%dharma-deya%}¦ (IA 9; HRS), same as {%deya-dharma, dharma-%}
<div n="lb">{%dāya,%} etc.; a religious grant in general.

<L>1582<pc>092<k1>धर्मदेशना<k2>धर्म-देशना
{%dharma-deśanā%}¦ (SII 1), a discourse on the sacred law.
<LEND>

<L>1583<pc>092<k1>धर्माधिकार<k2>धर्म्-आधिकार
{%dharm-ādhikāra%}¦ (EI 15; IA 9), court of law; an office
<div n="lb">relating to the civil and criminal courts as well as to religious
<div n="lb">and charitable institutions. See {%Dharmādhikārin.%}
<LEND>

<L>1584<pc>092<k1>धर्माधिकरण<k2>धर्म्-आधिकरण
{%dharm-ādhikaraṇa%}¦ (EI 18, 23, 25; CII 4; LP), a law-
<div n="lb">court; a court of justice. See {%Dharm-ādhikaraṇin.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. karaṇa%} (LP); the department of justice.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), a judge. See {%Viṣṇudharmottara,%} II. 24. 24-25.
<LEND>

<L>1585<pc>092<k1>धर्माधिकरणिक<k2>धर्म्-आधिकरणिक
{%Dharm-ādhikaraṇika%}¦ (IE 8-3), a judge; mentioned as a
<div n="lb">{%Pātra.%}

<L>1586<pc>092<k1>धर्माधिकरणिन्<k2>धर्म्-आधिकरणिन्

<div n="lb">215. 24. The reading is {%Dharm-ādhikaraṇa%} in some
<div n="lb">manuscripts.

<L>1587<pc>092<k1>धर्माधिकारिन्<k2>धर्म्-आधिकारिन्
{%Dharm-ādhikārin%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 33), cf. {%dharm-ādhikāra%} (IA
<div n="lb">9); an officer in charge of civil and criminal justice as well as
<div n="lb">charitable and religious institutions; same as {%Bṛhat-tantra-%}
[Page-093+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%pati,%} according to a Kashmirian commentator; usually explained
<div n="lb">as ‘a judge’; same as {%Dharmakarm-ādhikārin%} and {%Dharm-ādhyakṣa.%}
<div n="lb">Cf. the Muslim official designations ş{%adru%}Ş-Ş{%udūr, Dādbak,%}
<div n="lb">etc., explained as ‘the chief judge and grand almoner, or custo-
<div n="lb">dian of the king's bequests and charities’ ({%Journ. As. Soc. Pak.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. IV, pp. 53-54).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">judge’; but he was probably also the superintendent of charities,
<div n="lb">etc.; cf. {%Dharm-ādhikārin.%}

<L>1657<pc>097<k1>दि<k2>दि
{%di%}¦ (IE 8-1; CII 3), abbreviation of {%dina, dine, divasa%}
<div n="lb">or {%divase;%} used in connection with {%śu%} or {%su%} and {%ba%} in the case
<div n="lb">of lunar months and by itself in the case of solar months.
<LEND>

<L>1658<pc>097<k1>दिबिर<k2>दिबिर
{%Dibira,%}¦ same as {%Divira%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>1659<pc>097<k1>दिगम्बर<k2>दिगम्बर
{%Digambara%}¦ (IA 7), a Jain sect.
<LEND>

<L>1660<pc>097<k1>दिग्गज<k2>दिग्गज
{%diggaja%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’. Eight poets patronised by
<div n="lb">Kṛṣṇadevarāya were called the {%aṣṭa-diggaja.%}
<LEND>

<L>1661<pc>097<k1>दिग्विजय<k2>दिग्-विजय
{%dig-vijaya,%}¦ used in Kannaḍa inscriptions in the sense of
<div n="lb">‘going in state; going in a triumpal procession; making a state
<div n="lb">progress through one's dominions’ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. V, p. 223,
<div n="lb">note 5; Vol. VI, p. 51, note 5). See {%vijaya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1662<pc>097<k1>दिकैओस्<k2>दिकैओस्
{%Dikaios%}¦ (IE 8-2) Greek; royal title; ‘pious’; translated in
<div n="lb">Prakrit as {%Dhramika%} (Sanskrit {%Dhārmika%}).
<LEND>

<L>1663<pc>097<k1>दीकोला<k2>दीकोला
{%dīkolā%}¦ (LP), same as {%dāsī.%}

<L>1664<pc>097<k1>दिक्पाल<k2>दिक्पाल
{%Dikpāla%}¦ (HD), probably, officers in charge of the borders
<div n="lb">of a kingdom. See Nārada, Jolly's ed., Pariśiṣṭa, verse 17;
<div n="lb">{%Mitākṣarā%} on {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} II. 271; Kātyāyana (v. 813)
<div n="lb">quoted by Aparārka. (IE 7-1-2), ‘eight’.

<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘fifteen’.

<L>1669<pc>097<k1>दिनार<k2>दिनार
{%dināra%}¦ (SITI), name of a coin; same as {%dīnāra;%} derived
<div n="lb">from the Roman coin name {%denarius;%} a cowrie-shell according
<div n="lb">to the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī%} (Stein's trans., Vol. II, pp. 308 ff.).
<LEND>

<L>1670<pc>097<k1>दीनार<k2>दीनार
{%dīnāra%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 9, 23, 30; CII 3; SITI), a gold coin,
<div n="lb">the name being derived from the Roman {%denarius;%} gold coin
<div n="lb">equal to 16 silver {%rūpakas%} in the Gupta age ({%JNSI,%} Vol. II,
<div n="lb">p. 5); sometimes called {%kāśu%} in Tamil records; sometimes
<div n="lb">regarded as half of a {%satera%} or {%sateraka%} (Greek {%stater%}); men-
<div n="lb">tioned as a silver coin (K. V. Rangaswami Aiyanger, {%Kṛtya-%}
<div n="lb">{%kalpataru,%} Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, p. 125); also spelt {%dīnnāra,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>1671<pc>097<k1>दिनारि<k2>दिनारि
{%dināri%}¦ (IE 8-8), name of a coin probably modified from
<div n="lb">the Roman {%denarius;%} cf. {%dīnāra%} and {%dināri-māṣaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>1691<pc>098<k1>दित्य<k2>दित्य
{%ditya%}¦ (EI 9, 12, 28; CII 4; HRS), known from Maitraka
<div n="lb">records; name of a tax, according to some; probably, the
<div n="lb">same as {%datti,%} i. e. a gift or occasional present to be offered
<div n="lb">to the landlord; cf. {%sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna%} or
<div n="lb">{%ºparihṛta%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VI, p. 298, text line 20); also cf.
<div n="lb">{%sa-ditya-dāna-karaṇa%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p. 301, text line 14),
<div n="lb">an epithet of the gift land. {%Ditya%} is probably derived from
<div n="lb">Prakrit {%dijja%} = Sanskrit {%deya,%} ‘to be given’, ‘an object that has
<div n="lb">been given away’ in the sense of ‘customary presents’. For
<div n="lb">{%ditta,%} cf. {%Bhār. Vid.,%} Vol. XVII, Nos. 3-4 pp. 125-26. See
<div n="lb">{%Dity-odgrāhaka.%}
<LEND>
[Page-099+ 40]

<L>1692<pc>099<k1>दित्योद्ग्राहक<k2>दित्य्-ओद्ग्राहक
{%Dity-odgrāhaka%}¦ (CII 4), probably, ‘an officer in charge
<div n="lb">of collecting customary presents’; cf. {%ditya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1693<pc>099<k1>दिव<k2>दिव
{%diva%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), abbreviation of {%divasa%} or {%divase;%} used
<div n="lb">to denote the solar or, more properly, civil day.

<div n="lb">or lunar days.

<L>1697<pc>099<k1>दिवस<k2>दिवस
{%divasa%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a day; sometimes used for the week-
<div n="lb">day, instead of the usual term {%vāra;%} generally used to denote the
<div n="lb">solar or, more properly, civil day; sometimes used in connec-
<div n="lb">tion with words denoting {%tithis%} or lunar days. See also {%di, dina,%}
<div n="lb">{%diva.%}
<LEND>

<L>1698<pc>099<k1>दिविर<k2>दिविर
{%Divira%}¦ (HD), same as Persian {%Dabīr,%} ‘a clerk’. See
<div n="lb">{%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VIII. 131, mentioning {%Divira%} as distinct from
<div n="lb">{%Kāyastha;%} also {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 122. Cf. {%Divirapati.%}

<L>1699<pc>099<k1>दिविरपति<k2>दिविरपति, दिवीरपति

<div n="lb">chief secretary or the chief of the clerks; cf. {%Divira.%} See {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 180 ({%Sandhivigrahādhikṛta-Divirapati%}); Vol.
<div n="lb">XXII, p. 117 ({%Divirapati%} also called {%Sandhivigrahika, Mahā-%}

<L>1710<pc>100<k1>दोष<k2>दोष
{%doṣa%}¦ (LP), doing anything wrongly.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘three’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9), black or red spots on the tongue supposed to be a
<div n="lb">foreboding of death.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daṇḍa-doṣa;%} fines; see also {%pradhān-āpradhāna-doṣa-%}

<L>1719<pc>100<k1>द्रंक्षण<k2>द्रंक्षण
{%draṃkṣaṇa,%}¦ same as {%tolaka%} (q. v.); a weight of 8 {%māṣas,%} also
<div n="lb">spelt {%drakṣaṇa, drakṣuṇa,%} etc.; cf. {%maṃkṣūṇa,%} equal to 7 {%māṣas.%}
<LEND>

<L>1720<pc>100<k1>द्रम्म<k2>द्रम्म
{%dramma%}¦ (EI 25, 30; CII 4; SITI; BL), name of a coin;
<div n="lb">originally derived from Greek {%drachma.%}
<div n="P">(IE 8-8), a silver coin, equal to one-sixteenth of a gold
<div n="lb">{%niṣka%} according to the {%Līlāvalī.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. pañciyaka-dramma%} (EI 30), {%Śrīmadādivarāha-dramma,%}
<div n="lb">{%Vigraha-dramma, Vigrahapāla-dramma, Vigrahapāla-satka-dramma,%}
<div n="lb">{%Vigrahapālīya-dramma, Vigrahatuṅgīya-dramma%} (IE 8-8; EI 1);
<div n="lb">{%Bhīmapriya-dramma%} (IE 8-8); {%poruttha-dramma%} (EI 23).--(IE 8-8),
<div n="lb">cf. {%gara-dramma, dāya-dramma, belliya-dramma%} (i. e. silver {%dramma%}),
<div n="lb">etc., of Kannaḍa inscriptions; the name {%dramma%} was also applied
<div n="lb">to the silver coin called {%purāṇa, dharaṇa%} or {%kārṣāpaṇa,%} though it
<div n="lb">was often used as the name of copper coins; money. For gold
<div n="lb">and ordinary (copper) {%dramma,%} cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 111.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vāśal-tiramam%} (SITI), door tax.
<LEND>

<L>1721<pc>100<k1>द्रम्मार्ध<k2>द्रम्म्-आर्ध
{%dramm-ārdha%}¦ (CII 4), ‘half of a dramma’; name of a coin.
<LEND>

<L>1722<pc>100<k1>द्रम्मत्रिभाग<k2>द्रम्म-त्रिभाग
{%dramma-tribhāga%}¦ (CII 4), ‘three-fourths of a dramma’;
<div n="lb">name of a coin.
<LEND>

<L>1723<pc>100<k1>द्रङ्ग<k2>द्रङ्ग
{%draṅga%}¦ (EI 32), used to indicate {%dramma;%} name of a coin.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 10), cf. {%Navagrāma-draṅga,%} ‘the {%draṅga%} of Nava-
<div n="lb">grāma’; possibly ‘a station for the collection of revenue’.
[Page-101+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 8-3), a town or watch-station; possibly also a station
<div n="lb">for the collection of revenue; also called {%udraṅga%} which may
<div n="lb">thus indicate both revenue and the station for its collection.
<LEND>

<L>1724<pc>101<k1>द्रङ्गपाल<k2>द्रङ्गपाल
{%Draṅgapāla%}¦ (EI 28), same as {%Drāṅgika%} official design-
<div n="lb">ation. See {%draṅga.%}
<LEND>

<L>1725<pc>101<k1>द्राङ्गेश<k2>द्राङ्गेश
{%Drāṅgeśa%}¦ (EI 20; HD), supposed to be the designation of
<div n="lb">a guardian of the frontiers (cf. Stein, {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} Vol. II,
<div n="lb">pp. 291-92 for {%draṅga%} or {%draṅgā%}); cf. {%Draṅgapāla%} and {%Drāṅgika.%}
<LEND>

<L>1726<pc>101<k1>द्राङ्गिक<k2>द्राङ्गिक
{%Drāṅgika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 10, 30; CII 3, 4; HD), probably, an
<div n="lb">officer in charge of a city-station or watch-tower for collection
<div n="lb">of customs duties. {%Draṅga%} means either ‘a town’ (Bhandarkar's
<div n="lb">List, No. 810) or ‘a watch-station’ ({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VIII. 2010).
<div n="lb">{%Drāṅgika%} was an officer in charge of a {%draṅga%} probably mean-
<div n="lb">ing a watch station or a station for revenue collection; similar
<div n="lb">to {%Audraṇgika%} in the latter sense; mentioned along with the
<div n="lb">{%Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇa%} or ‘the collector of the king's grain-
<div n="lb">share’. Cf. {%draṅga, Draṅgapāla,%} etc. See {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 169.
<LEND>

<L>1727<pc>101<k1>द्रव<k2>द्रव
{%drava%}¦ (EI 20), a kind of dancing.
<LEND>

<L>1728<pc>101<k1>द्राविडी<k2>द्राविडी
{%Drāviḍī,%}¦ name applied to the South Indian variety of the
<div n="lb">Brāhmī alphabet.
<LEND>

<L>1729<pc>101<k1>द्रव्यभाण्डारकरण<k2>द्रव्यभाण्डार-करण
{%dravyabhāṇḍāra-karaṇa,%}¦ cf. {%karaṇa%} (LP); the department
<div n="lb">of stores.
<LEND>

<L>1730<pc>101<k1>द्रोण<k2>द्रोण
{%droṇa%}¦ (IE 8-6; Chamba), a grain measure; often regarded
<div n="lb">as equal to four {%āḍhakas;%} between one maund fourteen seers
<div n="lb">and two maunds, according to Bengali authors.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-1; EI 24, 29, 30), name of a land measure derived
<div n="lb">from that of a measure of capacity; shortened form of
<div n="lb">{%droṇavāpa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1731<pc>101<k1>द्रोणागीक<k2>द्रोणागीक
{%Droṇāgīka%}¦ (EI 33), official disignation; possibly a mistake
<div n="lb">for {%Droṇāgraka.%}
<LEND>

<L>1732<pc>101<k1>द्रोणाग्रक<k2>द्रोणाग्रक
{%Droṇāgraka%}¦ (EI 27), official disignation; probably an
<div n="lb">officer in charge of a {%droṇamukha%} or an important city, or one who
<div n="lb">collected the king's grain-share fixed per {%droṇa%} measure.
<LEND>

<L>1733<pc>101<k1>द्रोणमापक<k2>द्रोणमापक
{%Droṇamāpaka,%}¦ measurer of the king's grain-share
<div n="lb">(Ghoshal, {%Ag. Syst. Anc. Ind.,%} pp. 26-27).
<LEND>

<L>1734<pc>101<k1>द्रोणवाप<k2>द्रोणवाप
{%droṇavāpa%}¦ (IE 8-6; EI 30), ‘an area of land requiring one
<div n="lb">{%droṇa%} measure of seed grains to be sown’; a land measure which
<div n="lb">was not the same in different ages and localities.
<LEND>

<L>1735<pc>101<k1>द्रोणि<k2>द्रोणि, द्रोणी
{%droṇi, droṇī%}¦ (CH 4; IA 11), treasury; property (cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 144--‘the {%droṇī%} of Śrī-Somanāthadeva’ to
[Page-102+ 40]
<div n="lb">which a piece of land was attached); see {%devadroṇī%} probably
<div n="lb">meaning ‘rent-free property of a temple’.

<L>1737<pc>102<k1>दृश्<k2>दृश्

<div n="lb">rally, ‘to show one's belley’; but actually ‘to ask for the means

<L>1739<pc>102<k1>दृष्ट<k2>दृष्ट
{%dṛṣṭa%}¦ (EI 3, 23; CII 3; etc.), Prakrit {%diṭṭham,%} ‘has been seen’,
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘found correct and approved’, found on some copper-
<div n="lb">plate grants indicating the approval of the proper authorities
<div n="lb">endorsed on the original document later engraved on the plates.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%ni%} (an abbreviation of {%nibaddha%} or {%nirīkṣiṭa%}) in certain
<div n="lb">medieval copper-plate grants of Eastern India. In {%dṛṣṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%pañcāśat-padāti%} (LP), {%dṛṣṭa-ghoṭaka%} (LP), etc., the word {%dṛṣṭa%}
<div n="lb">indicates that money should be paid after actually seeing the
<div n="lb">foot-soldiers and horses in question.
<LEND>

{%dṛṣṭ-ādṛṣṭa%}¦ (IA 20), dimly seen.

<L>1770<pc>103<k1>दूत<k2>दूत
{%Dūta%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 1; HD), a messenger or
<div n="lb">envoy. See {%Viṣṇudharmottara,%} II. 24. 13-14, 28; {%CII,%} Vol. I,
<div n="lb">p. 67.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23; CII 3, 4), an occasional substitute for {%Dūtaka,%}
<div n="lb">the executor of a grant.
<LEND>

<L>1771<pc>103<k1>दूतक<k2>दूतक
{%Dūtaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; HD), messenger; conveyor of a request
<div n="lb">or message; cf. the Khalimpur plate of Dharmapāla ({%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 250), according to which the king was reques-
<div n="lb">ted to make a grant by a {%Mahāsāmantādhipati%} through prince
[Page-104+ 40]
<div n="lb">Tribhuvanapāla as the {%Dūtaka.%} His function is called {%dūtya%}
<div n="lb">in the Nalanda plate of Devapāla ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII,
<div n="lb">318 ff., text line 51).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 3, 4), according to some, the
<div n="lb">technical title of an officer connected with royal charters,
<div n="lb">whose duty it was to carry the king's orders to the local officials
<div n="lb">by whom the charter was then drawn up and delivered. But
<div n="lb">the {%Dūtaka%} seems to have been responsible for putting the
<div n="lb">document and also perhaps the gift land in the donee's possession.
<div n="lb">There are instances of more {%Dūtakas%} than one (IA 19). See
<div n="lb">also {%Ājñā, Dūta,%} and {%sva-mukh-ājñā.%} Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 143-44.
<LEND>

<L>1772<pc>104<k1>दूतप्रैषणिक<k2>दूत-प्रैषणिक
{%Dūta-praiṣaṇika%}¦ (HD), officer in charge of sending
<div n="lb">envoys; same as {%Dūta-preṣaṇika.%} See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p.
<div n="lb">321; {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, p. 306. Cf. {%Preṣaṇika.%}
<LEND>

<L>1773<pc>104<k1>दूतप्रेषणिक<k2>दूत-प्रेषणिक
{%Dūta-preṣaṇika%}¦ (CII 4), also called {%Duta-saṃpreṣaṇika%}
<div n="lb">and {%Dūta-praiṣaṇika;%} the officer who despatched {%Dūtas.%}
<LEND>

<L>1774<pc>104<k1>दूत्य<k2>दूत्य
{%dūtya,%}¦ same as {%dautya;%} function of the {%Dūtaka%} (q. v.).

<L>1780<pc>104<k1>द्वार<k2>द्वार
{%dvāra%}¦ (CII 1), a way or means.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘nine’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), the mouth of a river.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), cf. ‘the lord of the {%dvāra%}’ which was the desig-
<div n="lb">nation of a commander of forces in Kashmir; possibly, a pass
<div n="lb">[leading into the Kashmir valley].
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%vāśal-paṇam,%} ‘door-tax’; periodical payment
<div n="lb">due to the palace. Cf. {%dvār-ādeya.%}

<L>1781<pc>104<k1>द्वारादेय<k2>द्वार्-आदेय
{%dvār-ādeya%}¦ (HRS), ‘gate-dues’; explained as a surcharge
<div n="lb">over and above the tolls on goods imported into a city. See
<div n="lb">Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 60, note. But cf. Tamil {%vāśal-paṇam%}
<div n="lb">explained as ‘door-tax’, i. e. the periodical payment due to
<div n="lb">the palace.’

<L>1807<pc>106<k1>एडूक<k2>एडूक
{%eḍūka,%}¦ cf. {%eḍuo%} (CII 2-1), supposed to be ‘a wall into which
<div n="lb">bones (meaning planks and other hard substances) have been
<div n="lb">inserted in order to strengthen the structure’, because it is
<div n="lb">explained in a commentary as {%asthy-aṅkita kuḍya;%} but {%asthy-%}
<div n="lb">{%aṅkita-kuḍya%} seems to mean a Buddhist {%stūpa%} raised on cor-
<div n="lb">poreal relics which were an object of worship. Although
<div n="lb">the word {%kuḍya%} is reckoned in the lexicons in the sense of a wall,
<div n="lb">it seems to mean ‘a mound’ in this case. The word {%aidūka%}
<div n="lb">derived from {%eḍūka%} is used in Buddhist Sanskrit in the
<div n="lb">sense of a Buddhist {%stūpa.%} See {%IHQ,%} Vol. XXIX, pp.
<div n="lb">302-03.
<LEND>

<L>1808<pc>106<k1>एकभोग<k2>एक-भोग
{%eka-bhoga%}¦ (EI 16; SITI; ASLV), a tenure indicating
<div n="lb">exclusive ownership of a property invested in a single indivi-
<div n="lb">dual; sole possession and enjoyment of a village by a single
<div n="lb">person (without any joint owner); cf. {%ekabhoga-i%}ṟ{%aiyili,%} tax-free
<div n="lb">land or village in the sole enjoyment of a single owner. Same
<div n="lb">as {%eka-bhogya.%} Cf. {%gaṇa-bhoga.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), single crop; same as Tamil {%oru-pū.%}
<LEND>

<L>1809<pc>106<k1>एकभोग्य<k2>एक-भोग्य

<L>1843<pc>107<k1>गद्याण<k2>गद्याण
{%gadyāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 27, 30), also called {%gadyāṇaka,%} often
<div n="lb">contracted as {%ga%} or {%gadyā;%} sometimes called {%pon-gadyāṇa%} or
<div n="lb">{%gadyāṇa-ponnu%} indicating that it was a gold coin; sometimes
[Page-108+ 40]
<div n="lb">called {%suvarṇa;%} cf. {%bhairava-gadyāṇa, lokki-gadyāṇa%} (SII 11-2),
<div n="lb">{%aṅka-gadyāṇa, gāva-gadyāṇa, komarina-gadyāṇa, priyaśrāha-gaja-%}

<div n="lb">{%a%}ṟ{%u-gadyāṇa%} (IA 12) and {%kula-gadyāṇa%} (EI 17), names of coins.

<div n="P">({%SITI%}), name of a coin, probably equal to a {%varāha%} or
<div n="lb">{%pagoda;%} cf. {%bṛhad-bhairava-gadyāṇa%} (EI 30); also {%kaṭhāri-%}
<div n="lb">{%aṅkuśa-gadyāṇa%} (EI 8), name of a coin with the representation

<L>1941<pc>113<k1>गौरीवराटिका<k2>गौरी-वराटिका
{%gaurī-varāṭikā,%}¦ ‘virgin-money’. {%Gaurī%} means ‘a virgin’
<div n="lb">and {%varāṭikā%} is used primarily in the sense of {%varāṭa%} or {%varāṭaka,%}
<div n="lb">‘a cowrie-shell’, and secondarily in that of ‘money’. In the
<div n="lb">records of Mithilā, {%gaurī-varāṭikā%} means ‘money to be paid
<div n="lb">to the master of a slave girl of marriageable age by the master
<div n="lb">of her bridegroom’. See {%JNSI,%} Vol. XVI, pp. 264 ff.
<LEND>

<L>1942<pc>113<k1>गौतमीपुत्र<k2>गौतमी-पुत्र
{%Gautamī-putra%}¦ (IE 2-8), metronymic meaning ‘the son of
<div n="lb">a lady born in a family belonging to the Gautama {%gotra%}’. Such
<div n="lb">metronymics refer to the absence of {%gotr-āntara%} (i. e. the change
<div n="lb">of the bride's paternal {%gotra%} to that of her husband at the time
<div n="lb">of marriage) in a popular form of ancient Indian marriage.
<LEND>

<L>2047<pc>119<k1>गोष्ठिक<k2>गोष्ठिक

<div n="lb">ber of a committee like that of the trustees.
<LEND>

<L>2048<pc>119<k1>गोत्र<k2>गोत्र
{%gotra%}¦ (CII 3; IA 19; CITD), a family or clan, a tribe or
<div n="lb">lineage; a caste. No Hindu can marry a girl of his own {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">or stock, though some forms of ancient Indian marriages did
<div n="lb">not involve the {%gotr-āntara,%} i. e. the change of the wife's {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">to that of the husband at the time of marriage ({%Proc. IHC,%}
<div n="lb">Annamalainagar, 1945, pp. 48 ff.). Cf. {%Gautamī-putra,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33), abbreviation of {%gotra-śailikā,%} a memorial pillar
<div n="lb">raised for the dead members of one's family.
<LEND>

<L>2049<pc>119<k1>गोत्रान्तर<k2>गोत्र्-आन्तर
{%gotr-āntara%}¦ (IE 8-2), the change of the wife's paternal {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">to that of her husband, which was absent in some popular forms
<div n="lb">of marriage in ancient India ({%Proc. IHC,%} Annamalainagar,
<div n="lb">1945, pp. 48 ff.).
<LEND>

<L>2050<pc>119<k1>गोत्रशैलिका<k2>गोत्र-शैलिका
{%gotra-śailikā%}¦ (EI 33), a pillar raised in memory of the
<div n="lb">dead members of one's family.
<LEND>

<L>2051<pc>119<k1>गोउड्<k2>गोउड् (अस्ल्व्
{%Gouḍ (ASLV),%}¦ Anglicised spelling of {%Gauḍa%} or {%Gavuḍa%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.).

<L>2054<pc>119<k1>गोयूथी<k2>गो-यूथी

<div n="lb">is the same as {%yūti%} (or {%pūti%}) used in the same context in many
<div n="lb">other records in the compound {%tṛṇa-yūti%} (or {%tṛṇa-pūti%}). {%Goyūthī-%}

<L>2060<pc>119<k1>ग्राम<k2>ग्राम
{%grāma%}¦ (IE 8-4), ‘a village’; often suffixed to the names of
<div n="lb">localities.
[Page-120+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), a village assembly.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4), sometimes used to indicate the number of villages
<div n="lb">in a territory or geographical unit; but the number was often
<div n="lb">either exaggerated or traditional without relation to reality;
<div n="lb">sometimes wrongly interpreted as ‘a unit of revenue assess-
<div n="lb">ment’. Cf. {%navanavati-sahasra-grāma-bhāj%} (IE 8-4), epithet of
<div n="lb">a territory. See Sircar, {%Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind.,%} pp. 200 ff.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, pp. 146-47), a villager; same as
<div n="lb">{%Grāmeyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>2061<pc>120<k1>ग्रामभर्तृ<k2>ग्रामभर्तृ
{%Grāmabhartṛ%}¦ (HD), same as {%Grāmapati%} ({%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%}
<div n="lb">II. 271).
<LEND>

<L>2062<pc>120<k1>ग्रामभोगिक<k2>ग्राम-भोगिक
{%Grāma-bhogika%}¦ (EI 24, 29; CII 4), probably the {%Jāgīrdār%}
<div n="lb">of a village or one who enjoys a village as a free-holding. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%rāja-sāmanta-viṣayapati-grāmabhogika-purillaka-cāṭa-bhaṭa-sevak-ādīn%}
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIX, pp. 114-15).
<LEND>

<L>2074<pc>120<k1>ग्रामकूट<k2>ग्रामकूट
{%Grāmakūṭa%}¦ (EI 8-3); EI 30; CII 4; HD), cf. {%Grāmamahattara;%}
<div n="lb">the headman of a village (or probably, a member of the
[Page-121+ 40]
<div n="lb">village council). Paiṭhīnasi and Kauṭilya (IV 5) use the
<div n="lb">word, and the commentary on the {%Kāmasūtra%} (V. 55) explains
<div n="lb">{%Grāmakūṭa%} as {%halottha-vṛtti.%} Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 285; {%Ind.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ant.,%} Vol. XVI, p. 24. See {%Rāṣṭrakūṭa, Deśakūṭa.%}

<L>2115<pc>123<k1>गुडान्तपत्र<k2>गुडान्त-पत्र
{%guḍānta-patra%}¦ ({%Journal of the Bihar Research Society,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XL, Part 2, pp. 96-97), name of a type of document, the exact
<div n="lb">nature of which is doubtful; probably, a kind of lease deed.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%guṇa-patra.%}

<L>2207<pc>128<k1>हस्त्यश्वोष्ट्रनौबलव्यापृतक<k2>हस्त्य्-अश्व्-ओष्ट्र-नौ-बल-व्यापृतक

<div n="lb">HD), military officer or officers in charge of the elephant force,
<div n="lb">cavalry, camel corps and navy. See Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%}
<div n="lb">p. 166; {%Ep. Ind.%} Vol. XVII, p. 321. Cf. {%Hasty-aśv-oṣṭra-go-%}
<div n="lb">{%mahiṣ-āj-āvik-ādhyakṣa.%} It has to be noted that these two are
<div n="lb">never mentioned together while, on the other hand, one is used
<div n="lb">in place of the other. See {%Naubala-hasty-aśva-go-mahiṣ-ājāvik-ādi-%}
<div n="lb">{%vyāpṛtaka,%} etc.

<L>2293<pc>131<k1>जगति<k2>जगति, जगती
{%jagati, jagatī%}¦ (EI 11), explained variously as ‘ground’;
<div n="lb">(EI 3), ‘lower ground or compound’; (EI 1), ‘a kind of build-
<div n="lb">ing’; also as ‘railed parapet’ (R. Narsimhachar, {%The Keśava%}
<div n="lb">{%Temple at Somanāthapura,%} p. 2). Cf. {%devagṛha-jagatī%} (IA 14);
<div n="lb">also {%jagati-ppaḍai%} (SII 2), the upper tier of the basement.
<div n="lb">See {%jagatī%} below.
<LEND>

<L>2294<pc>131<k1>जगती<k2>जगती
{%jagatī%}¦ (HA), same as {%bhamatī;%} the corridor of a shrine
[Page-132+ 40]
<div n="lb">on the four sides of its open court, used for circumambulation
<div n="lb">of the main shrine.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘twelve’; sometimes also ‘fortyeight’; rarely
<div n="lb">used in the sense of ‘the earth’ to indicate ‘one’.
<LEND>

<L>2295<pc>132<k1>जगतीपुर<k2>जगतीपुर
{%jagatīpura%}¦ (EI 3), supposed to be the same as {%brahma-%}
<div n="lb">{%purī%} or Kannaḍa {%jagati-kaṭṭĕ%} which is ‘the raised square seat
<div n="lb">around a tree before a village’.
<LEND>

<L>2296<pc>132<k1>जागीर्<k2>जागीर्
{%jāgīr%}¦ (EI 33; BL), Persian; a fief; a tenure under
<div n="lb">Muhammadan rule, in which the public revenues of a given
<div n="lb">tract of land were made over, either conditionally or uncondi-
<div n="lb">tionally, to persons like a servant of the State together with
<div n="lb">the powers required to enable them to collect and appropriate
<div n="lb">such revenues and administer the general government of the
<div n="lb">tract. Cf. Wilson's Glossary. See {%Jāgīrdār.%}
<LEND>

<L>2297<pc>132<k1>जागीर्दार्<k2>जागीर्दार्
{%Jāgīrdār%}¦ (EI 33), Persian; a fief-holder. Cf. {%jāgīr.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">would succeed in accomplishing [your duty]’.

<L>2361<pc>135<k1>जेमक<k2>जेमक
{%jemaka%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 25, 28), melas or food which the
<div n="lb">villagers were obliged to provide to the royal officers on tour;
<div n="lb">the obligation of the villagers to provide food to such officers;
<div n="lb">wrongly explained by some as ‘a tax for the boarding of touring
<div n="lb">royal officers’ (CII 4). Cf. Marāṭhī {%jevā,%} ‘a feed, a meal; sub-
<div n="lb">sistence which the villagers were bound to provide for the
<div n="lb">subordinate servants or Peons when sent to receive the collec-
<div n="lb">tions’ (Wilson's Glossary, s. v.).
<LEND>

<L>2362<pc>135<k1>जेन<k2>जेन
{%jena%}¦ (CITD), Telugu; a span (about 7 inches).

<div n="lb">a title of nobility; later stereotyped as a family name in Orissa.

{%jhampin%}¦ (EI 12), ‘excelling’.

<L>2365<pc>135<k1>झाट<k2>झाट

<div n="lb">Bengali {%jhā%}ḏ; a bush; used in {%sa-jhāṭa-viṭapa%} (EI 27).

<div n="lb">Tīrthaṅkara, there being five such events, viz. {%cyavana%} or des-
<div n="lb">cent from heaven, {%janma%} or birth, {%dīkṣā%} or initiation as monk,
<div n="lb">{%jñāna%} or attainment of {%kevala-jñāna,%} and {%mokṣa%} or {%nirvāṇa,%} i. e.

<div n="lb">of a Jina. See {%kalyāṇikā.%}

<L>2558<pc>144<k1>कर<k2>कर
{%kara%}¦ (IE 8-5), explained by a commentator as ‘the dues
[Page-145+ 40]
<div n="lb">({%bhāga%}) to be realised by the king for the enjoyment of royal
<div n="lb">land by using it for cultivation and for grazing cattle’; tax in
<div n="lb">general.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5) rent or tax to be paid in grains when mentioned
<div n="lb">side by side with {%hiraṇya.%}
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), tax in general, according to the lexicons; accord-
<div n="lb">ing to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} (1) periodical tax over and above the
<div n="lb">king's customary grain-share; (2) emergency tax levied upon
<div n="lb">the villagers over and above the normal grain-share; (3)
<div n="lb">tax upon merchants' profits.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 29; Chamba; CITD), a tax or impost; royal revenue;
<div n="lb">rent, dues; toll, tribute.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘two’.
<LEND>

<L>2564<pc>145<k1>कराकरकरण<k2>कराकर-करण

<L>2565<pc>145<k1>करण<k2>करण
{%Karaṇa%}¦ (EI 4), an accountant.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28; HD), a clerk; a scribe. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXII,
<div n="lb">p. 155.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 19), same as Marāṭhī {%Kulkarṇī.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a type of law-court lower in rank than an
<div n="lb">{%adhikaraṇa.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-1, 8-8; EI 28, 30), same as or a shortened form of
<div n="lb">{%adhikaraṇa;%} a court of law.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), an office or department.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a committee.
<div n="P">({%LP%}), a department, according to the editors of the
<div n="lb">{%Lekhapaddhati,%} the thirtytwo {%karaṇas%} or departments being the
<div n="lb">following; {%śrī-karaṇa, vyaya-karaṇa, dharm-ādhikaraṇa, maṇḍapikā-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, velākula-karaṇa, jala-karaṇa, [sthala] patha-karaṇa, ghaṭi-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāgṛha-karaṇa, ṭaṅkaśālā-karaṇa, dravya-bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, aṃśuka-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, vārigṛha-karaṇa, devaveśma-karaṇa, gaṇikā-karaṇa,%}
[Page-146+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, hastiśālā-karaṇa, aśvaśālā-karaṇa, kalabhaśālā-karaṇa, śreṇi-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, vyāpāra-karaṇa, tantra-karaṇa, koṣṭhāgāra-karaṇa, upakrama-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, karākara-karaṇa, sthāna-karaṇa, deva-karaṇa, sandhi [vigraha]-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, mahākṣapāla-karaṇa, mahārasa-karaṇa, jayanaśālā-karaṇa.,%}
<div n="lb">{%sattrāgāra-karaṇa, antaḥpura-[karaṇa]%} and {%koṣṭhikā-[karaṇa].%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3, 4), a document.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Karaṇam%} (SII 1; SITI), Tamil; also spelt {%Karṇam;%}
<div n="lb">a document; an accountant, also called {%Kaṇakka%}ṉ or {%Karaṇikka.%}
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), name of the half of a {%tithi.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">accountant.

<L>2617<pc>149<k1>कर्ष<k2>कर्ष
{%karṣa%}¦ (IE 8-8; CII 4), name of a weight equal to 80
<div n="lb">{%ratis;%} same as {%tolā;%} sometimes regarded as 100 or 120 {%ratis%}
<div n="lb">in weight ({%JNSI,%} Vol. II, p. 3).
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 309), a measure of capacity for
<div n="lb">liquids.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), name of a coin; cf. {%kārṣāpaṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>2618<pc>149<k1>कार्षापण<k2>कार्षापण
{%kārṣāpaṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 29; CII 4), name of a gold, silver
<div n="lb">or copper coin one {%karṣa%} (80 {%ratis%}) in weight; name of a
<div n="lb">silver coin of 32 {%ratis,%} same as {%purāṇa%} or {%dharaṇa;%} name applied
<div n="lb">to the gold {%gaṇḍa-māḍa%} also called {%niṣka%} or {%gaṇḍa-niṣka%} ({%JNSI,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XVI, p. 43). The weight of a copper or gold {%kārṣāpaṇa%}
<div n="lb">was 80 or 100 {%ratis%} ({%JNSI,%} Vol XV, p. 143); copper {%kārṣāpaṇa%}
<div n="lb">was also called {%paṇa.%} Cf. {%kāhāpaṇa%} (EI 8), Prakrit for
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%kārṣāpaṇa;%} see {%kāhāṇa, kāhaṇa.%}

<L>2627<pc>149<k1>कारुक<k2>कारुक

<div n="lb">be the carpenter, the blacksmith, the potter, the barber and
<div n="lb">the washerman.

<div n="lb">as {%kāru-deya.%}

<L>2644<pc>150<k1>काशु<k2>काशु
{%kāśu%}¦ (SII 1), Tamil; money; a coin; ‘a tax’; cf. {%kāśu-%}
<div n="lb">{%kaḍamai,%} tax payable in cash.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-8), name of a coin; sometimes called {%dīnāra%} (q. v.);
<div n="lb">cf. {%ūr-kāśu%} (EI 28), {%vīrapañcālaṅ-kāśu%} (SITI), {%sambiraṇippalaṅ-%}
<div n="lb">{%gāśu;%} also {%ī%}l13{%a-kkāśu%} (EI 28), ‘the Ceylonese coin’; {%śo%}l13{%iya-kkāśu%}
<div n="lb">(SITI), name of a copper coin believed to have been intro-
<div n="lb">duced by the Col13as; {%palaṅ-kāśu, nat-kāśa, nal-kāśu%} (SII 12);
<div n="lb">generally regarded as (1/100) of a {%paṇam;%} cf. {%triśūla-kāśu%} (SII 3).
<div n="P">{%Cf. āśuva-kkāśu%} (SITI), or {%ājīvaka-kāśu,%} tax payable by the
<div n="lb">Ājīvakas.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aḍimai-kkāśu%} (SITI), fees collected from the temple
[Page-151+ 40]
<div n="lb">servants; also {%adi-kkāśu,%} tax collected from stall-keepers in the
<div n="lb">markets.
<div n="P">{%Cf. uppu-kkāśu%} (SITI), salt-tax.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vagainda-kāśu%} (SITI), tax payable in cash for marking
<div n="lb">details of land, etc.; fees for the division of land; also the fee
<div n="lb">for settlement of a dispute, etc.
<div n="P">Cf. {%veli-kkāśu, veli-ppaya%}ṟ{%u%} (SITI), Tamil; tax payable in
<div n="lb">cash, the exact nature of which is not clear. Cf. {%veli-kku%}l13{??}-
<div n="lb">{%ppaṇam.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. inavari-kkāśu%} (SITI), communal tax payable in coin;
<div n="lb">cf. {%jāti-siddh-āya%} of Telugu inscriptions.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), Tamil; a measure of weight equal to (1/4) {%palam.%}
<LEND>

{%Kāyastha%}¦ (EI 24; ASLV; HD), a clerk; explained by some
<div n="lb">as ‘a registrar’ (EI 31); a scribe or writer in the king's revenue
<div n="lb">department according to some. See {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} I. 322;
<div n="lb">{%Viṣṇu Dharma Sūtra,%} VII. 3; etc. Cf. {%Aśvaghāsa-kāyastha%} and
<div n="lb">{%Grāma-kāyastha%} ({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} V. 175; {%IHQ,%} Vol. IX,
<div n="lb">p. 12). See also {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. II, pp. 75-77. For
<div n="lb">derivation, cf. {%Bhār. Vid.,%} Vol. X, pp. 280 ff.
<LEND>

<L>2676<pc>152<k1>कायव्रत<k2>काय-व्रत
{%kāya-vrata%}¦ (EI 11), self-immolation.
<LEND>

<L>2677<pc>152<k1>कायोत्सर्ग<k2>काय्-ओत्सर्ग
{%kāy-otsarga%}¦ (EI 3), a kind of obeisance.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Prākrit {%kā-ussagga%} (HA), a posture of meditation in
<div n="lb">which one stands erect with arms hanging and the soles of
<div n="lb">feet kept four inches apart. Cf. {%kāusaggiyā.%}
<LEND>

{%kedāra%}¦ (EI 28), a corn-field.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 32), low land.
<div n="P">{%Cf. bhū-kedāra%} (EI 19); a land measure; cf. the land
<div n="lb">measure called {%keyār%} in the Sylhet region of East Pakistan.

<L>2681<pc>153<k1>केलि<k2>केलि

<L>2682<pc>153<k1>केन्द्र<k2>केन्द्र
{%kendra%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), anomaly of the moon, taken to be her distance
<div n="lb">from apogee, from which point it is always reckoned by Hindu
<div n="lb">astronomers; the annual variation in the moon's {%kendra%} is 3
<div n="lb">signs 2 degrees and 6.2 minutes, or 7 {%tithis%} 9 {%ghaṭīs%} and 42
<div n="lb">{%palas.%} See also {%nīcocca-māsa, tithi-kendra, tithi-madhyama-kendra%}
<div n="lb">and {%tithi-spaṣṭa-kendra.%}
<LEND>

<L>2683<pc>153<k1>केतु<k2>केतु
{%ketu%}¦ (EI 24), the shape or form.
<LEND>

<L>2698<pc>154<k1>खाजण्<k2>खाजण्

<L>2699<pc>154<k1>खज्जन<k2>खज्जन, खज्जण, खज्जान, खज्जणक
{%khajjana, khajjaṇa, khajjāna, khajjaṇaka%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 33),
<div n="lb">same as Marāṭhī and Koṅkaṇī {%khājaṇ;%} an area near the
<div n="lb">sea shore, on which a thin layer of sand accumulates after
<div n="lb">the ebbtide coming through inlets; a rice field created out of
<div n="lb">such an area near a hillock by erecting embankments on the
<div n="lb">three other sides; a field created by reclaiming a river bed;
<div n="lb">cultivable land created from the bed of a river which carries
<div n="lb">the flood-water from the sea; a salty marsh or meadow; a
<div n="lb">rice field created near the bed of a nullah on the sea shore
<div n="lb">by putting embankments. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, pp.
<div n="lb">53-54. It is sometimes called {%pukkoli-khajjana, pukkoli%} probably
<div n="lb">meaning a similar kind of land.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">in the said sense.

<L>2755<pc>157<k1>खोल<k2>खोल
{%Khola%}¦ (IE 8-3); HD), an official designation of uncertain
<div n="lb">meaning ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, pp. 250, 253); probably a kind
<div n="lb">of messenger. Utpala on the {%Bṛhatsaṃhitā,%} 85. 34, explains
<div n="lb">{%Dūta%} as {%Gamāgamika%} while some Pāla inscriptions place {%Khola%}
<div n="lb">between the two; probably the same as {%Preṣaṇika%} or {%Dūta-%}
<div n="lb">{%preṣaṇika,%} a dispatcher of messengers.

<L>2757<pc>157<k1>खोट<k2>खोट

<div n="lb">{%hiraṇya,%} etc., and of compulsory labour and the provision
<div n="lb">of food for the {%Cāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas,%} according to the {%Abhidhāna-%}

<LEND>

<L>2758<pc>157<k1>खोटभङ्ग<k2>खोट-भङ्ग
{%khoṭa-bhaṅga%}¦ (HRS), applies to a person residing for
<div n="lb">one, two or three years, or as long as the king's favour extends,
<div n="lb">without contributing the {%hiraṇya,%} etc., and without providing
<div n="lb">food for the {%Gāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas,%} according to the {%Abhidhānarā-%}
<div n="lb">{%jendra,%} s. v. {%parihāra;%} also called {%ukkoṭa-bhaṅga, akṣoṭa-bhaṅga.%}

<L>2762<pc>158<k1>ख्स्हायथियवष्र्क<k2>ख्स्हायथिय वष्र्क
{%Khshāyathiya vazrka%}¦ (IE 8-2), Old Persian; ‘the great
<div n="lb">king’; royal title. It was translated by the Indo-Greek kings

<div n="lb">original of the Indian royal title {%Mahārāja.%} See {%Basilĕos%}

<L>2768<pc>158<k1>कीर्तन<k2>कीर्तन
{%kīrtana%}¦ (EI 24, 28, 33; SII 1; CII 4), same as {%kīrti;%}
<div n="lb">a temple or any other thing that renders famous the name of
<div n="lb">the person responsible for it; often interpreted as ‘a building
<div n="lb">or temple’; but really, ‘any fame-producing work’; ‘a monu-
<div n="lb">ment of fame’; a pious work like a temple. See {%kīrtanā.%}
<LEND>

<L>2769<pc>158<k1>कीर्तना<k2>कीर्तना

<L>2770<pc>158<k1>कीर्ति<k2>कीर्ति
{%kīrti%}¦ (EI 20, 24; CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the thing that
<div n="lb">speaks of or glorifies one’; used in the special meaning of ‘any
<div n="lb">work which renders the constructor of it famous’; a merit-
<div n="lb">orious work; a pious deed; same as {%kīrtana, kīrtanā;%} often inter-
<div n="lb">preted as ‘a building or temple’; but actually, ‘any fame-
<div n="lb">producing work’. See {%kīrti-sthāna.%}
<div n="P">(CII 1), fame of a dead person; cf. {%yaśo vā kīrtir = vā.%}
<div n="lb">See {%yaśas.%}
<LEND>

<L>2856<pc>162<k1>कृत<k2>कृत
{%kṛta%}¦ (EI 12, 14, 23; BL; CII 3), literally ‘accomplished’.
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘completed’; used in earlier records in connection with the
<div n="lb">era later associated with Vikramāditya. Often spelt
<div n="lb">{%krita,%} possibly standing for {%krīta%} meaning ‘purschased’, which
<div n="lb">was a name sometimes applied to certain foreign rulers of
<div n="lb">North-Western Bhāratavarṣa ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, p.
<div n="lb">152).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), ‘arranged for’, ‘made arrangements for’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23), fruit, booty, reward.
<div n="P">({%Sel. Ins.,%} p. 202), ‘engraved’.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 41, verse 13), written, drafted or
<div n="lb">composed.

<L>2909<pc>165<k1>कुलिक<k2>कुलिक
{%Kulika%}¦ (EI 15, 35), ‘the head of a guild’; but
<div n="lb">cf. {%Prathama-kulika,%} ‘the foremost among the Kulikas’, who
<div n="lb">was the member of a board of administration like the {%Pañcāyat%}
<div n="lb">Board. Some inscriptions of the Gupta age mention a board
<div n="lb">of administration consisting of the {%Nagara-śreṣṭhin Sārthavāha,%}
<div n="lb">{%Prathama-Kulika%} and {%Prathama-Kāyastha%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XV,
<div n="lb">p. 130), where {%Kulika%} seems to mean ‘an artisan’. {%Kulika%}
<div n="lb">is also mentioned as a people probably meaning mercenary
<div n="lb">soldiers of the Kullu valley (ibid., Vol. XVII, p. 321); cf.
<div n="lb">Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 126-27.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), an officer in charge of ten villages who was granted
<div n="lb">a {%kula%} of land for his salary (Manu, VII. 119, and Kullūka
<div n="lb">thereon); also ‘an arbitrator as a tribunal’ ({%IHQ,%} Vol. XIX, p. 14).
<LEND>

<L>2910<pc>165<k1>कुल्लक<k2>कुल्लक
{%kullaka,%}¦ cf. {%udak-āsīhāra-kullaka;%} probably, a kind of channel.
<LEND>

<L>2911<pc>165<k1>कुल्य<k2>कुल्य
{%kulya%}¦ (IE 8-6), a measure of capacity equal to 8 {%droṇas.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-6; EI 29), a land measure; shortened form of
<div n="lb">{%kulyavāpa.%}
<LEND>

<L>2912<pc>165<k1>कुल्यवाप<k2>कुल्यवाप
{%kulyavāpa%}¦ (IE 8-6; EI 28), ‘an area of land requiring one
<div n="lb">{%kulya%} measure of seed grains to be sown’; a land measure
<div n="lb">which was not the same in different ages and localities.
<LEND>

<L>2913<pc>165<k1>कुल्या<k2>कुल्या
{%kulyā%}¦ (EI 13), a channel for irrigation.
<LEND>

<L>2914<pc>165<k1>कुमार<k2>कुमार
{%Kumāra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 28, 30; BL; HD), designation of a
<div n="lb">prince or the king's heir-apparent; usually a prince younger
<div n="lb">than the {%Yuvarāja%} (heir-apparent). See {%CII,%} Vol. I, pp. 93,
<div n="lb">97; Vol. II, pp. 40, 48.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Devī-kumāra%} (IA 18; CII 1).
<LEND>

<L>2915<pc>165<k1>कुमाराधिराज<k2>कुमाराधिराज
{%Kumārādhirāja%}¦ (EI 12, 28), title of a ruler.
<LEND>

<L>2916<pc>165<k1>कुमारदिवान<k2>कुमार-दिवान
{%Kumāra-Divāna%}¦ (BL), possibly, a {%Divāna%} or minister enjoying
<div n="lb">the status of a {%Kumāra%} or a {%Kumāra%} who was the {%Divāna.%} Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Kumār-āmātya, Kumāra-mahāpātra.%}
<LEND>
[Page-166+ 40]

<L>2917<pc>166<k1>कुमारगदिआणक<k2>कुमार-गदिआणक
{%kumāra-gadiāṇaka%}¦ (CII 4), taken to be the name of a coin
<div n="lb">by some scholars; but probably, a tax. Same as {%kumāra-gadyāṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>2918<pc>166<k1>कुमारगद्याण<k2>कुमार-गद्याण
{%kumāra-gadyāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 4; HRS), probably, a tax
<div n="lb">of one {%gadyāṇa%} (i. e. the coin of that name) payable on the
<div n="lb">occasion of a prince's birth. See {%kumāra-gadiāṇaka, komarina-%}
<div n="lb">{%gadyāṇa,%} etc. Cf. Tamil {%kumara-kaccāṇam%} (EI 21), supposed to
<div n="lb">be a tax payable in coin for the maintenance of the temple of
<div n="lb">Kumāra or Subrahmaṇya (SITI). But {%kumāra-gadyāṇa%} is found in
<div n="lb">the records of the Gāhaḍavālas of Vārāṇasī, in whose dominions
<div n="lb">the god in question was not as popular as in the South.
<LEND>

<L>2919<pc>166<k1>कुमारगुरु<k2>कुमार-गुरु
{%Kumāra-guru%}¦ (BL), probably, the royal preceptor enjoying
<div n="lb">the status of a {%Kumāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>2920<pc>166<k1>कुमरकच्चाणम्<k2>कुमर-कच्चाणम्
{%kumara-kaccāṇam%}¦ (EI 21), a tax; cf. {%kumāra-gadyāṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>2921<pc>166<k1>कुमारमहापात्र<k2>कुमार-महापात्र
{%Kumāra-mahāpātra%}¦ (EI 8-3; EI 28), a {%Mahāpātra%} enjoying
<div n="lb">the status of a {%Kumāra%} or a {%Kumāra%} who was the {%Mahāpātra;%}
<div n="lb">cf. {%Kumār-āmātya.%}
<LEND>

<L>2922<pc>166<k1>कुमारामात्य<k2>कुमार्-आमात्य
{%Kumār-āmātya%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), probably
<div n="lb">‘an {%Amātya%} enjoying the status of a {%Kumāra%}’. Cf. Tamil
<div n="lb">{%piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam%} (SITI), ‘the status of a {%Piḻḻai%} (prince)’, an
<div n="lb">officers’ cadre mainly composed of the junior members of
<div n="lb">the royal family. See {%Proc. 6th AIOC,%} pp. 211 ff.; Vogel,
<div n="lb">{%Ant. Ch. St.,%} p. 123.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), in one case, a {%Kumār-āmātya%} was at first a
<div n="lb">{%Mantrin,%} but later became a {%Mahābalādhikṛta;%} in another case,
<div n="lb">a {%Kumārāmātya%} was also a {%Mantrin.%} Cf. {%Kumāra-mahāpātra,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Kumāra-varga=piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam%} (SITI), literally, ‘the
<div n="lb">status of the {%Piḻḻai%} or prince’; supposed to be an officers’ cadre
<div n="lb">composed mainly of the junior members of the royal family.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), also called {%Khādya(kū*)ṭapākika, Sāndhivigrahika,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahādaṇdanāyaka,%} etc., additionally.
<LEND>

<L>3039<pc>172<k1>लोकपाल<k2>लोकपाल
{%Lokapāla%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a guardian of one of the quarters
<div n="lb">of the world, originally conceived as four in number and later
<div n="lb">as eight.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 15), cf. the king called ‘the fifth {%Lokapāla%}’, the four
<div n="lb">{%Lokapālas%} (guardians of the four quarters) being originally
<div n="lb">Yama of the south, Varuṇa of the west, Kubera of the north
<div n="lb">and Vāsava of the east. In the same sense, the king was
<div n="lb">also called {%madhyama-loka-pāla,%} though {%madhyama-loka%} may
<div n="lb">also mean ‘the earth’ standing midway between the heavens
<div n="lb">and the netherworld. See {%Suc. Sāt.,%} pp. 196, 202; {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XXXII, p. 93. Cf. {%Pañcama-lokapāla.%}
<LEND>
<H>M

<L>3042<pc>172<k1>माड<k2>माड
{%māḍa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 7), Telugu; same as Oḏiyā {%mā%}ḏ{%ha%} or
<div n="lb">{%mā%}ḏ{%hā%} and Tamil {%māḍai;%} a coin of gold or silver; 40 {%ratis%} in
<div n="lb">weight; cf. {%biruda-māḍa, malla-māḍa, mallanandi-māḍa, surabhi-%}
[Page-173+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%māḍa, gaṇḍa-māḍa, kulottuṅga-māḍa%} (EI 29), {%gandhavāraṇamāḍa%} (or
<div n="lb">{%gandhahasti-māḍa%}), {%cāmara-māḍa, uttama-gaṇḍamāḍa, padmanidhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%malla-māḍa, rājarāja-māḍa, rājendraco%}l13{%a-māḍa,%} etc. The {%gaṇḍa-māḍa%}
<div n="lb">is sometimes called {%kārṣāpaṇa, niṣka%} and {%gaṇḍaniṣka%} and is also
<div n="lb">characterised in a few cases with the epithet ‘small’. See
<div n="lb">{%māḍai, māḍha.%} Note names like {%kulottuṅga-māḍa,%} a coin issued by
<div n="lb">the Col13a king Kulottuṅga. See {%JNSI,%} Vol. XVI, p. 43.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), Telugu; half a {%pagoda;%} half of a {%dīnār%} or the
<div n="lb">tenth of a {%paṇa%} (cf. {%badi-māḍuvulu%}); half or 50 per cent of
<div n="lb">revenue, etc.; a weight of gold; money in general. Four
<div n="lb">{%māḍas%} are equal to one {%carṣam (karṣa?).%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), probably, payment of 50 per cent; see {%māḍalu.%}
<LEND>

<L>3063<pc>174<k1>महा<k2>महा (प्ज्स्
{%Mahā (PJS),%}¦ abbreviation of {%Mahājana%} (especially in
<div n="lb">medieval Jain inscriptions).
<div n="P">{%Cf. Mahā-Mūla%} (i. e. the elder Mūla) distinguished from
<div n="lb">{%Kṣudra-Mūla%} (i. e. the younger Mūla); also {%Mahā-Dharmagiri%}
<div n="lb">and {%Kṣudra-Dharmagiri,%} etc.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">commander of forces; also called {%Khādya(kū*) ṭapākika, Sān-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhivigrahika, Kumārāmātya,%} etc., additionally; one of the desig-
<div n="lb">nations sometimes included in the {%pañca-mahāśabda;%} cf. the case
<div n="lb">of Maitraka Dhruvasena I ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XX, p. 7; {%Ind.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ant.,%} Vol. IV, p. 105). The five {%mahāśabdas%} applied to Dhruva-
<div n="lb">sena are {%Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra, Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%kārtākṛtika%} and {%Mahārāja.%} See {%Daṇḍanāyaka, Sarvadaṇḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%nāyaka, Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka, Daṇḍapati.%}

<L>3130<pc>178<k1>महाक्षपटलिक<k2>महाक्षपटलिक

<div n="lb">keeper and accountant; same as {%Mahākṣapaṭal-ādhyakṣa;%} see
<div n="lb">{%Akṣapaṭalika,%} sometimes explained as ‘the chief keeper of records’

<L>3132<pc>178<k1>महाक्षत्रप<k2>महाक्षत्रप
{%Mahākṣatrapa%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 16, 27; CII 4; BL; ML;
<div n="lb">HD), the great {%Satrap%} or provincial governor; feudatory title
<div n="lb">of foreign origin; originally, title of a provincial governor;
<div n="lb">later the Śakas of Western India continued to use it even when
<div n="lb">they were practically independent. Cf. {%CII,%} Vol. II, p. 48. See
<div n="lb">{%Kṣatrapa.%}

<L>3138<pc>178<k1>महल्लक<k2>महल्लक

<div n="lb">{%Pañcāyat;%} explained as ‘city elders’; cf. {%yat … nagara-mahallakā%}
<div n="lb">{%vicārya vadante,%} etc.

<L>3154<pc>179<k1>महामण्डलनाथ<k2>महामण्डल-नाथ

<LEND>

<L>3155<pc>179<k1>महामण्डलेश्वर<k2>महामण्डलेश्वर
{%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 4; HD; BL;
<div n="lb">SITI; CITD), according to the lexicons, a sovereign ruler
[Page-180+ 40]
<div n="lb">who is the lord of 40 {%yojanas%} of land and a lakh of villages; but,
<div n="lb">in inscriptions, generally, the governor of a district or pro-
<div n="lb">vince; title of a feudatory ruler or governor (see {%Bomb. Gaz.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XXI, p. 354); see {%Maṇḍaleśvara%} essentially meaning ‘the
<div n="lb">ruler of a {%maṇḍala%} or district’; also called {%Mahāmaṇḍalika,%} etc.,
<div n="lb">cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati.%} The status of a {%Mahāmaṇdal-%}
<div n="lb">{%eśvara%} seems to have been superior to that of a {%Maṇḍaleśvara,%}
<div n="lb">while {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvarādhipati%} apparently enjoyed a still higher
<div n="lb">rank.
<LEND>

<L>3156<pc>180<k1>महामण्डलेश्वराधिपति<k2>महामण्डलेश्वर्-आधिपति
{%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 23), title of a
<div n="lb">feudatory higher in rank than a {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara%} (cf. {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāmantādhipati%}); a feudatory who had some subordinate chiefs
<div n="lb">under him; cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara, Maṇḍaleśvara.%}
<LEND>

<L>3157<pc>180<k1>महामण्डलिक<k2>महामण्डलिक
{%Mahāmaṇḍalika%}¦ (IE 8-3), feudatory title; see {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%maṇḍalīka.%}
<LEND>

<L>3158<pc>180<k1>महामण्डलीक<k2>महामण्डलीक
{%Mahāmaṇḍalīka%}¦ (HD), same as {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara.%} Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. IX, p. 35. See {%Mahāmaṇḍalika, Mahāmaṇḍale-%}
<div n="lb">{%śvar-ādhipati, Māṇḍalika%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>3162<pc>180<k1>महामात्र<k2>महामात्र
{%Mahāmātra%}¦ (IE 8-3), cf. Prakrit {%Mahāmāta%} (EI 3); a high
<div n="lb">executive officer employed in various capacities; cf. {%Nagara-%}
<div n="lb">{%vyavahārika-mahāmātra, Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra, Dharma-mahāmātra,%}
<div n="lb">etc.; adopted in Greek as {%Mamātrai.%} See {%CII,%} Vol. I, p. 92,
<div n="lb">etc.; {%Arthaśāstra,%} I. 12, V. 1; etc.; {%Kāmasūtra,%} V. 5. 17. 33 and
<div n="lb">35. The word {%Mahāmātra%} in Manu, IX. 259, is explained by
<div n="lb">Medhātithi as ‘the {%Mantrin, Purohita%} and others’ and by Kullūka
<div n="lb">as meaning ‘the professional tamers of elephants’. (SITI)
<div n="lb">explained as ‘a senior minister.’ See {%Mātra%} in a similar sense.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Antaḥpura-mahāmātra%} in the Masulipatnam plates of
<div n="lb">Amma II ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIV, p. 276).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28; CII 4), ‘an elephant-driver’.
<LEND>

<L>3163<pc>180<k1>महामात्रगण<k2>महामात्र-गण
{%Mahāmātra-gaṇa%}¦ (CII 4), corporation of elephant-drivers.

<L>3197<pc>182<k1>महापार्षिक<k2>महापार्षिक
{%mahāpārṣika%}¦ (EI 32), used in the sense of ‘a member of the
<div n="lb">{%mahāparṣad%}’.
<LEND>

<L>3198<pc>182<k1>महापर्वन्<k2>महा-पर्वन्
{%mahā-parvan%}¦ (EI 12), auspicious time.
<LEND>

<L>3199<pc>182<k1>महापात्र<k2>महापात्र
{%Mahāpātra%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 19, 30), a minister; a minister
<div n="lb">higher in rank than the {%Pātra;%} cf. {%Pātra%} and {%Ekapātra.%}
<LEND>

<L>3200<pc>182<k1>महापसायित<k2>महापसायित
{%Mahāpasāyita%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 5, 27), probably from Sanskrit
<div n="lb">{%Prasādita,%} ‘favoured’, meaning a {%Jāgīrdār%} of a particular type;
<div n="lb">sometimes also called {%Mahāpradhāna, Antaḥpuravĕrgaḍĕ, Daṇḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%nāyaka, Sarvādhikārin, Mahāsāmanta, Senādibāhatta raniyogādhiṣṭhā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yaka,%} etc., additionally; cf. {%Pasāita, Pasāyita.%}
<LEND>
[Page-183+ 40]

<L>3201<pc>183<k1>महापेरियप्रधान<k2>महापेरियप्रधान
{%Mahāpĕriyapradhāna%}¦ (EI 24), Sanskrit {%Mahābṛhatpradhāna;%}
<div n="lb">see {%Mahāpradhāna.%}
<LEND>

<L>3202<pc>183<k1>महापीलुपति<k2>महापीलुपति
{%Mahāpīlupati%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 28), ‘the great superintendent
<div n="lb">of elephants’; chief of the elephant corps; the master of ele-
<div n="lb">phants; sometimes also called {%Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Pañcā-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhikaraṇ-oparika, Mahāpratīhāra, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika,%}
<div n="lb">etc., additionally. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p. 298. The word
<div n="lb">{%pīlu%} is the same as Perso-Arabic {%fīl.%} See {%Mahāpalupati%} and {%Pīlupati.%}
<LEND>

<L>3203<pc>183<k1>महाप्रभु<k2>महाप्रभु
{%Mahāprabhu%}¦ (EI 21, 32), sometimes used in respect of
<div n="lb">subordinate rulers; (HD), a governor; cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XII,
<div n="lb">p. 335. ({%SITI%}) ‘the great banker’; the senior merchant; the
<div n="lb">title by which the leader of the {%nānādeśi%} merchant community
<div n="lb">was designated.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 30), a village official; see {%Prabhu.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 19), explained as ‘the high sheriff’.
<LEND>

<L>3204<pc>183<k1>महाप्रचण्ड<k2>महाप्रचण्ड
{%Mahāpracaṇḍa%}¦ (EI 12), either a separate official desig-

<div n="lb">{%Daṇḍanāyaka.%}

<L>3207<pc>183<k1>महाप्रधान<k2>महाप्रधान
{%Mahāpradhāna%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 4; BL; HD), ‘the
<div n="lb">great minister’; ‘the chief minister or administrator’; sometimes
<div n="lb">also called {%Mahāsāmant-ādhipati, Antaḥpura-vĕrgaḍĕ (ºādhyakṣa),%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpasāyita, Senāpati, Hĕri (Mahā) sandhivigrahika, Manĕ-%}
<div n="lb">{%vĕrgaḍĕ, Kaḍitavĕrgaḍĕ, Senādhipati, Antaḥpur-ādhyakṣa, Hĕri-Lāḻa-%}
<div n="lb">{%Kannaḍa-sandhivigrahin, Bhānasa-vĕrgaḍĕ, Accupanāyadadhiṣṭhāyaka,%}
<div n="lb">{%Sarvādhikārin, Hĕri (Mahā) bhāṇḍāgārin, Bāhattaraniyogādhipati,%}
<div n="lb">{%Paṭṭasāhaṇ-ādhiṣṭhāyaka, Senāpati, Daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsāmanta,%}
<div n="lb">{%Senādibhāhattaraniyog-ādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāmātya, Paramaviśvāsin,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāparamaviśvāsin,%} etc., additionally. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. V, p. 28.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), senior councillor of the king, usually a military
<div n="lb">officer; same as {%Mahāpradhāni.%} See {%Pradhāna.%}
<LEND>

<L>3208<pc>183<k1>महाप्रधाननायक<k2>महाप्रधान-नायक

<div n="lb">or administrator; same as {%Mahāradhāna;%} a high executive officer.

<L>3214<pc>184<k1>महाप्रति<k2>महा-प्रति

<L>3215<pc>184<k1>महाप्रतिहार<k2>महाप्रतिहार, महाप्रतीहार
{%Mahāpratihāra, Mahāpratīhāra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3;
<div n="lb">BL), head of the door-keepers of the palace or the king's
<div n="lb">chamber, or of the capital; city; sometimes explained as ‘the
<div n="lb">chief usher’ (CII 4). See {%Pratihāra.%}
<div n="P">({%HD%}), the superior officer above all door-keepers, the
<div n="lb">great chamberlain. See {%Kādambarī,%} para. 97; {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} IV.
<div n="lb">142; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. X, p. 75; etc.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), one of the designations often included in the
<div n="lb">{%pañca-mahāśabda,%} as indicated by the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes also called {%Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpīlupati, Pañcakaraṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika,%}
<div n="lb">etc., additionally.
<LEND>

<L>3216<pc>184<k1>महाप्रतिहारपीडा<k2>महाप्रतिहार-पीडा
{%mahāpratihāra-pīḍā%}¦ (EI 12), occurs in the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī;%}
<div n="lb">explained as ‘the office of the high chamberlain’.
