<L>3221<pc>184<k1>महर<k2>महर
{%Mahara%}¦ (EI 1), probably a mistake for {%Mahattara,%} ‘a
<div n="lb">village-headman’ or ‘a member of the village Pañcāyat’.
<LEND>

<L>3222<pc>184<k1>महाराज<k2>महाराज
{%Mahārāja%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), royal title
<div n="lb">first assumed by the foreign rulers of India and later adopted by
<div n="lb">indigenous rulers; originally, an imperial title; later (when the
<div n="lb">emperors assumed more dignified titles), a title of feudatories
<div n="lb">and smaller rulers; cf. Greek {%Basileos Megalou%} and Old Persian
<div n="lb">{%Kshāyathiya vazrka.%} Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 211.
[Page-185+ 40]
<div n="P">(IE 8-2), one of the designations sometimes included in
<div n="lb">the {%pañca-mahāśabda;%} cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes also called {%Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpīlupati, Pañcādhikaraṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika,%}
<div n="lb">etc., additionally.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), often used in the South even when {%Mahārājā-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhirāja%} became the popular imperial title in the North.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), designation of a priest of the members of the
<div n="lb">Vallabhācārya sect. Cf. {%Mahanta-mahārāja,%} title of pontiffs.
<LEND>

<L>3223<pc>185<k1>महाराजबप्पस्वामिन्<k2>महाराज-बप्प-स्वामिन्
{%Mahārāja-bappa-svāmin%}¦ (IE 8-2), designation by which
<div n="lb">the father and predecessor of a ruling king is sometimes
<div n="lb">referred to.
<LEND>

<L>3224<pc>185<k1>महाराजाधि<k2>महाराजाधि
{%Mahārājādhi%}¦ (CII 3), abbreviation of {%Mahārājādhirāja.%}
<LEND>

<L>3225<pc>185<k1>महाराजाधिराज<k2>महाराजाधिराज

<div n="lb">ruling queens of Orissa.

<L>3258<pc>186<k1>महासभा<k2>महा-सभा
{%mahā-sabhā%}¦ (SII 1; ASLV; SITI), ‘the great assembly’;
[Page-187+ 40]
<div n="lb">meeting of the general body of the {%sabhā;%} meeting of the {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%janas%} in session; body of the {%Mahājanas.%}
<LEND>

<L>3259<pc>187<k1>महासाधनभाग<k2>महासाधनभाग
{%mahāsādhanabhāga%}¦ (IE 12; IA 14; HD), occurring in
<div n="lb">the {%Rājataraṅgīṇī;%} explained as ‘the office of the chief executive
<div n="lb">minister’; but cf. {%Mahāsādhanika;%} one of the five offices insti-
<div n="lb">tuted by Lalitāditya of Kashmir ({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} IV. 142-43).
<LEND>

<L>3260<pc>187<k1>महासाधनिक<k2>महासाधनिक
{%Mahāsādhanika%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; CII 4; BL; HD), official
<div n="lb">designation indicating a commander of forces; the chief mili-
<div n="lb">tary officer; one of the designations often included in the {%pañca-%}
<div n="lb">{%mahāśabda%} as indicated by the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī.%} See {%Sādhanika%}
<div n="lb">derived from {%sādhana%} or army. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VII, p. 91.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes mentioned as a {%Pātra.%}
<LEND>

<L>3261<pc>187<k1>महासाहनी<k2>महासाहनी
{%Mahāsāhanī%}¦ (BL), cf. {%Masāhaṇī%} (EI 5), a military officer;
<div n="lb">the same as Sanskrit {%Mahāsādhanika.%}
<LEND>

<L>3262<pc>187<k1>महासाहसिक<k2>महासाहसिक
{%Mahāsāhasika%}¦ (IE 25), official designation; cf. {%Duḥ-%}
<div n="lb">{%sādhya-sādhanika.%}
<LEND>

<L>3263<pc>187<k1>महासैन्यपति<k2>महासैन्यपति
{%Mahāsainyapati%}¦ (EI 29; HL), commander of forces; cf.
<div n="lb">{%Sainyapati%} and {%Mahāsenāpati.%}
<LEND>

<L>3264<pc>187<k1>महाशाइत्<k2>महाशाइत्
{%mahāśāit%}¦ (EI 5), a kind of rice or paddy.
<LEND>

<L>3265<pc>187<k1>महासांकरणनि<k2>महासां-करण-नि
{%mahāsāṃ-karaṇa-ni%}¦ (IE 8-1), abbreviation of {%mahāsāndhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%vigrahika-karaṇa-nirīkṣita,%} ‘examined by the clerk of the
<div n="lb">{%Mahāsāndhivigrahika%}’. {%Karaṇa%} here may also be an abbreviation
<div n="lb">of {%Adhikaraṇa%} or office.
<LEND>

<L>3266<pc>187<k1>महासामन्त<k2>महासामन्त
{%Mahāsāmanta%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; BL), ‘the
<div n="lb">great chieftain’; title of a feudatory of a higher rank than the
<div n="lb">{%Sāmanta;%} sometimes called {%Mahārāja, Mahāpratīhāra, Pañca-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika, Senādibāhattara-%}
<div n="lb">{%niyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin, Mahāpasāyita,%}
<div n="lb">{%Daṇḍanāyaka,%} etc., additionally. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. II, p. 217;
<div n="lb">Vol. IX, p. 107.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a vassal chief, sometimes holding the position of
<div n="lb">a minister or governor.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), one of the designations sometimes included in
<div n="lb">the {%pañca-mahāśabda;%} cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes a feudatory of a lower grade than
<div n="lb">{%Rājan%} and {%Rājanaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>3267<pc>187<k1>महासामन्ताधिपति<k2>महासामन्ताधिपति
{%Mahāsāmantādhipati%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 29, 30; CII 4; BL;
<div n="lb">HD), a feudatory title; cf. {%Sāmantādhipati%} (EI 16); title of
<div n="lb">feudatories who had some subordinate chiefs under them;
<div n="lb">title of a feudatory of a higher rank than the {%Mahāsāmanta;%}
[Page-188+ 40]
<div n="lb">cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara, Samasta-mahāsāmant-ādhipati;%} sometimes
<div n="lb">also called {%Mahāpradhāna, Bhānasavĕrgaḍĕ, Accupannāyadadhiṣṭhā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yaka,%} etc., additionally. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 259. See
<div n="lb">{%Mahāsāmanta, Mahāmaṇḍaleśvarādhipati,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>3268<pc>188<k1>महासामन्तराज<k2>महासामन्तराज
{%Mahāsāmantarāja%}¦ (EI 33), feudatory title; cf. {%Mahāsāmant-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhipati.%} It may also indicate one enjoying the titles {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāmanta%} and {%Rājan.%}
<LEND>

<L>3269<pc>188<k1>महासानि<k2>महासा-नि
{%mahāsā-ni%}¦ (IE 8-1), abbreviation of {%mahāsāndhivigrahikaṇirī-%}
<div n="lb">{%kṣita,%} ‘examined by the {%Mahāsāndhivigrahika%}’. See {%ni, mahākṣa-ni.%}
<LEND>

<L>3270<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहाधिकरण<k2>महासन्धिविग्रह्-आधिकरण

<div n="lb">department of the {%Mahāsandhivigrahika;%} the department of
<div n="lb">peace and war.
<LEND>

<L>3271<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहाधिकरणआधिकृत<k2>महासन्धिविग्रह्-आधिकरण-आधिकृत

<div n="lb">{%vigrah-ādhikaraṇ-ādhikṛta.%}

<L>3272<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहाधिकृत<k2>महासन्धिविग्रह्-आधिकृत

<L>3273<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहाधिपति<k2>महासन्धिविग्रह्-आधिपति

<div n="lb">{%sāndhivigrahika;%} cf. {%Sandhivigrah-ādhipati,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>3274<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहाक्षपटलाधिकृत<k2>महासन्धिविग्रह्-आक्षपटल्-आधिकृत

<L>3276<pc>188<k1>महासन्धिविग्रहिक<k2>महासन्धिविग्रहिक

<L>3277<pc>188<k1>महासान्धिविग्रहिक<k2>महासान्धिविग्रहिक

<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), cf. {%Gauḍa-mahāsāndhivigrahika,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>3299<pc>190<k1>महातलवर<k2>महातलवर
{%Mahātalavara%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 25; HD), explained by some
<div n="lb">authorities as a subordinate ruler and by others as the police
<div n="lb">magistrate of a city or the prefect of the city police. Cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XX, pp. 6, 16. See {%Talavara, Talāra,%} etc.

<L>3301<pc>190<k1>महातन्त्र<k2>महातन्त्र
{%mahātantra%}¦ (SITI; ASLV), often mentioned in South
<div n="lb">Indian records in the sense of ‘the army’; the army council;
<div n="lb">the great assembly of the army.
<LEND>

<L>3302<pc>190<k1>महातन्त्राधिकृत<k2>महातन्त्राधिकृत
{%Mahātantrādhikṛta%}¦ (IE 8-3), explained by some authori-
<div n="lb">ties as ‘an officer in charge of judicial and charitable affairs’;
<div n="lb">but the word {%tantra%} also means ‘administration’ or ‘the army’;
<div n="lb">probably ‘the chief administrator’. The designation may have
<div n="lb">also indicated different functions in different localities and ages.
<div n="lb">See {%Tantrapāla, Tantrapati%} and {%Mahātantrādhyakṣa.%}
<LEND>

<L>3311<pc>190<k1>महत्तक<k2>महत्तक

<LEND>

<L>3312<pc>190<k1>महत्तम<k2>महत्तम
{%Mahattama%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 29; CII 4; BL; HD), probably
<div n="lb">the village headman or a member of the {%Pañcāyat%} board; cf.
<div n="lb">{%Mahattara.%} See {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, p. 306; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 266 ({%Mahattara%} and {%Mahattama%} occur one after another,
<div n="lb">{%Mahattama%} being senior or superior to {%Mahattara%}); {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%}
<div n="lb">VII. 438.
[Page-191+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 26), same as Gujarātī {%Mahetā%} or {%Mehtā.%}
<LEND>

<L>3313<pc>191<k1>महत्तर<k2>महत्तर
{%Mahattara%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23, 29, 30; CII 4; BL; HD),
<div n="lb">literally, ‘an elder [of a town or village]’; according to Stein
<div n="lb">({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 659); a chamberlain, a village headman
<div n="lb">or head of a family or community and a member of the village
<div n="lb">council; cf. Hindī {%Mahato;%} Gujaratī {%Mahetā.%} Cf. {%Ind. Ant.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. VI, p. 114 {%(rāṣṭra-grāma-mahattara); Daśakumāracarita,%} III,
<div n="lb">p. 77 ({%janapada-mahattara%}).
<div n="P">{%Cf. mahattar-ādy-aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa%} (EI 31), ‘office of the
<div n="lb">administrative board of the {%aṣṭakula%} headed by the {%Mahattara%}’;
<div n="lb">see {%Mahattara%} and {%aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 3-3), official guide. (Beal, {%Life of Hiuen Tsiang,%} p. 190).
<LEND>

<L>3314<pc>191<k1>महत्तरक<k2>महत्तरक
{%Mahattaraka%}¦ (EI 23; LL), explained as ‘a chamberlain’;
<div n="lb">same as {%Mahattara.%}
<LEND>

<L>3315<pc>191<k1>महात्राण<k2>महात्राण
{%mahātrāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-5), Bengali; a rent-free holding in
<div n="lb">the possession of non-Brahmanical communities, e. g. the
<div n="lb">Vaiṣṇavas).

<L>3388<pc>194<k1>मण्डल<k2>मण्डल
{%maṇḍala%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 29, 30; CII 4), an administrative
<div n="lb">unit; a district or province.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a province consisting of several {%koṭṭams%} or
<div n="lb">{%valanāḍus.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4), sometimes mentioned as bigger than a {%viṣaya%} and
<div n="lb">sometimes smaller than it; sometimes a {%viṣaya%} was included in a
<div n="lb">{%maṇḍala,%} but sometimes a {%maṇḍala%} was included in a {%viṣaya;%} some-
[Page-195+ 40]
<div n="lb">times {%maṇḍala%} and {%viṣaya%} are identical; sometimes a {%maṇḍala%}
<div n="lb">was smaller than the {%vīthī%} or subdivision.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4; SII 3; ASLV), sometimes used in a wider sense
<div n="lb">to indicate a country.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Kona-maṇḍala (EI 22), also called an {%avani-maṇḍala%}
<div n="lb">or {%deśa.%} Here {%maṇḍala%} means a kingdom or territory.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), an assembled body. Cf. {%mātṛ-maṇḍala.%}
<LEND>

<L>3397<pc>195<k1>मण्डलेश्वर<k2>मण्डलेश्वर

<div n="lb">governor lower in rank than a {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara;%} same as {%Maṇ-%}
<div n="lb">{%ḍaleśa.%} Cf. {%Bomb. Gaz.,%} Vol. XXI, p. 354. Cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%leśvara,%} ‘governor of the provinces’ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV,
<div n="lb">p. 110).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">as {%Māṇḍalika.%}

<L>3401<pc>195<k1>मण्डप<k2>मण्डप
{%maṇḍapa%}¦ (IE 8-3), customs house; Marāṭhī {%māṇḍavī,%} from
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%maṇḍapikā;%} explained by some as ‘a market place’
[Page-196+ 40]
<div n="lb">(Hindī {%maṇḍī%}); but Hindī {%maṇḍī%} seems to be derived from the
<div n="lb">same word because the toll-stations were often situated in market-
<div n="lb">places.
<div n="P">({%BL%}), name of a structure in front of a temple.
<div n="P">({%LL%}), a porch or hall.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), the hall in a temple.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a temple.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 31), a temple or public building.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vaiccamudu-maṇḍapa%} (SITI), kitchen; same as {%maḍaip-%}
<div n="lb">{%paḻḻi.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. vakkāṇikku-maṇḍapa%} (SITI), hall where disputations
<div n="lb">in the {%śāstras%} are held. Cf. {%śanivāra-maṇḍapa.%}
<LEND>

<L>3402<pc>196<k1>मण्डपिका<k2>मण्डपिका

<div n="lb">{%maṇḍapikā%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XI, p. 339 and note 31). See
<div n="lb">Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} pp. 238-39.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 3; CII 4); market; a market pavilion.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a small temple.
<LEND>

<L>3482<pc>200<k1>माष<k2>माष
{%māṣa%}¦ (EI 21, 25, 30, 33; CII 4), according to the {%Kṛtya-%}
<div n="lb">{%kalpataru%} (Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, ed. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, p.
<div n="lb">125), a gold coin as opposed to silver {%māṣaka;%} name of a weight;
<div n="lb">name of a coin; 5 {%ratis%} in weight; sometimes regarded as 10
<div n="lb">{%ratis%} in weight and as equal to (1/4) of a {%śāna.%} See {%JNSI,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XVI, p. 41. It was sometimes regarded as (1/20) of a {%paṇa%} of
<div n="lb">100 {%ratis%} ({%ibid.,%} Vol. XV, p. 143). Cf. {%māṣaka, ādya-māṣa.%}
<LEND>

<L>3483<pc>200<k1>माषक<k2>माषक
{%māṣaka%}¦ (IE 8-8), name of a coin; cf. {%māṣa%} and {%dināri-%}
<div n="lb">{%māṣaka;%} mentioned as a silver coin (K. V. Rangaswami
<div n="lb">Aiyangar, {%Kṛtyakalpataru,%} Vyavahāra-kāṇḍa, p. 125).

<div n="lb">‘twelve’; also {%pakṣa,%} ‘two’.

<L>3491<pc>201<k1>मठ<k2>मठ
{%maṭha%}¦ (EI 17, 19, 23, 31, 32; CII 3, 4; SII 1; BL; ASLV;
<div n="lb">CITD), a school or religious college; a temple; a monastery;
<div n="lb">hermitage or convent; a monastery which was a religious and
<div n="lb">educational institution. See {%maṭhikā.%} In Telugu records, it
<div n="lb">also means ‘a bullock cart’ and ‘a cart load’ (cf. Kannaḍa
<div n="lb">{%maṭṭī,%} ‘a load’).

<div n="lb">({%tapasvins%}) are fed.

<L>3638<pc>208<k1>नगर<k2>नगर
{%nagara%}¦ (IE 8-4), city; palace; cf. {%navara.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 21; SITI), a commercial guild; guild of merchants;
<div n="lb">a mercantile town; often spelt in Kannaḍa inscriptions as {%nakara%}
<div n="lb">or {%nakhara;%} cf. {%pañca-nagara.%}
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), in Telugu inscriptions, a territorial assembly
<div n="lb">like the {%sabhā%} and {%ūr;%} the merchant community in general or
<div n="lb">the organization of the merchant community of a town. In
<div n="lb">some places, the {%nagara%} and {%ūr%} carried on their functions side
<div n="lb">by side. The word is sometimes used to indicate occupational
<div n="lb">groups like {%śāleyanagarattom.%} Cf. K. A. Nilakanta Sastri,
<div n="lb">{%The Co%}l13{%as,%} Vol. II, 1st ed., p. 294.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), same as Kaliṅga-nagara. Cf. {%śrī-Nagara-bhukti=%}
<div n="lb">{%Pāṭaliputra-bhukti%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 311).
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), represented in Prakrit by {%nera%} further corrupted
<div n="lb">to {%ner%} or {%nar.%} See {%nagarī.%}
<LEND>

<L>3639<pc>208<k1>नगराधिकृत<k2>नगर्-आधिकृत
{%Nagar-ādhikṛta%}¦ (HD), the city prefect. See {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%}
<div n="lb">IV. 81; VI. 70; VIII. 3334.

<div n="lb">duties or interests.

<div n="lb">{%badarī%} fruit’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. śāka-phalaka-nyāyena%} (LP), ‘like vegetables and fruits’.

<div n="P">{%Cf. vṛddhi-phala-bhoga-nyāya%} (LP), principle of enjoying the
<div n="lb">interest of a deposit; also cf. {%gṛhasya bhāḍakaṃ na hi; drammāṇāṃ%}

<L>3909<pc>224<k1>पादानुध्यानरत<k2>पाद्-आनुध्यान-रत
{%Pād-ānudhyāna-rata%}¦ (IE 8-2), ‘engaged in meditating on
<div n="lb">the feet of … ’; cf. {%Pād-ānudhyāta.%}
<LEND>

<L>3910<pc>224<k1>पादानुध्यात<k2>पाद्-आनुध्यात
{%Pād-ānudhyāta%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 2; CII 3), ‘meditating on the
<div n="lb">feet or favoured by the feet of … ’, a technical expression for
<div n="lb">the relations of a feudatory to his paramount sovereign, of a
<div n="lb">subordinate to a chief, of a successor to his predecessor, of a son
<div n="lb">to his parents, of a nephew to his uncle, of a grandson to his
<div n="lb">grandfather, and of a younger to his elder brother; used also in
<div n="lb">respect of gods. In rare cases, the word {%pāda%} is omitted. Cf
<div n="lb">{%Pāda-bhakta%} and {%Pād-ānudhyāna-rata.%}
<LEND>

<L>3911<pc>224<k1>पादपद्मोपजीविन्<k2>पाद-पद्म्-ओपजीविन्
{%Pāda-padm-opajīvin%}¦ (CII 3; IA 18), ‘subsisting [like a bee]
<div n="lb">on the lotuses that are the feet of … ’; a technical expression
<div n="lb">(often occurring in medieval South Indian inscriptions) for the
<div n="lb">relations of a feudatory or officer to his master; cf. {%Pāda-piṇḍ-%}
<div n="lb">{%opajīvin, Pād-opajīvin.%}
<LEND>

<L>3912<pc>224<k1>पादपाश<k2>पाद-पाश
{%pāda-pāśa%}¦ (SITI), name of a foot-ornament.
<LEND>

<L>3913<pc>224<k1>पादपिण्डोपजीविन्<k2>पाद-पिण्ड्-ओपजीविन्
{%Pāda-piṇḍ-opajīvin%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), ‘subsisting on the food
<div n="lb">supplied by the feet of … ’; a technical expression to denote
<div n="lb">the relationship of officials or subordinates to their master;
<div n="lb">same as {%Pād-opajīvin%} and {%Pāda-padm-opajīvin.%}

<L>3941<pc>225<k1>पद्र<k2>पद्र
{%padra%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 24; CII 4), ‘a village’; often suffixed
<div n="lb">to the names of villages; see {%padraka.%} Cf. {%pādrīyaka%} (LP), those
[Page-226+ 40]
<div n="lb">living in the confines of a village.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), probably, ‘inhabited area’; may also be ‘com-
<div n="lb">mon land’ (cf. {%padraka%}); cf. {%sa-padr-āraṇyaka%} as an epithet of
<div n="lb">a gift village.
<LEND>

<L>3942<pc>226<k1>पद्रक<k2>पद्रक
{%padraka%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 3; etc.); ‘a village’; generally used
<div n="lb">as the termination of the name of a village; interpreted as ‘com-
<div n="lb">mon-land’ in expressions like {%Bhumbhusa-padraka%} and {%Śivaka-%}
<div n="lb">{%padraka.%} Wilson's Glossary explains {%pādar%} (i. e. {%padra%}) as
<div n="lb">‘common-land, land adjacent to a village left uncultivated’.

<L>3951<pc>226<k1>पगोद्<k2>पगोद्, पगोद
{%pagod, pagoda%}¦ (EI 8-8), also called ‘star pagoda’; English
<div n="lb">name of the gold coin called {%hūn (hon)%} or {%varāha;%} probably so
<div n="lb">called because the coins often bore the representation of a
<div n="lb">temple called {%pagod%} or {%pagoda%} by the early European travellers.
<div n="lb">The word seems to have been derived from Sanskrit {%bhagavat%} or
<div n="lb">{%bhagavatī%} meaning the deities worshipped in the temples and
<div n="lb">also often figuring on the coins. Cf. ‘{%ṭaṅkakas%} stamped with the
<div n="lb">figure of the {%Bhagavat%}’ (Bhandarkar's List, No. 2033).
<div n="P">{%Cf. Cīna-pagoda%} (SII 12), ‘the Chinese temple’; name of
<div n="lb">a Buddhist shrine at Nāgapaṭṭanam.
<LEND>

<L>3952<pc>226<k1>पाहुड<k2>पाहुड
{%pāhuḍa,%}¦ Sanskrit {%prābhṛta;%} cf. {%pāhuḍa-pramāṇena%} (LP), ‘in
<div n="lb">proportion to the gift given by him’.
<LEND>

<L>3953<pc>226<k1>पाइक्<k2>पाइक्
{%Pāik%}¦ (IE 7-3; EI 33), Sanskrit {%Padātika;%} same as {%Bhaṭa%} or
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭa-manuṣya;%} a footman; cf. {%Piāda.%}
<LEND>

<L>3954<pc>226<k1>पाइका<k2>पाइका
{%pāikā%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 29), Oḏiyā; also called {%pāikāli;%} same as
<div n="lb">{%padāti-jīvya.%}
<LEND>

<L>3955<pc>226<k1>पाइकालि<k2>पाइकालि
{%pāikāli,%}¦ see {%pāikā.%}

<L>3967<pc>227<k1>पल<k2>पल
{%pala%}¦ (EI 9, 21, 30; CII 3), name of a weight.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 26), a weight equal to 320 {%ratīs;%} sometimes spelt {%phala%}
<div n="lb">in Pāli.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), in Telugu-Kannaḍa records, a weight equal to
<div n="lb">that of 10 {%pagodas;%} four {%karṣas%} or (1/100) of a {%tula;%} the 8th part of
<div n="lb">a ser, or 3 {%tolas%} or rupees; 4 {%tolas%} or 320 {%guñjās.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), the sixtieth division of a {%ghaṭī;%} equal to twenty-
<div n="lb">four English seconds.
<LEND>

<L>3990<pc>228<k1>पण<k2>पण
{%paṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 23, 24, 30; SII 11-1), same as Tamil
<div n="lb">{%paṇam,%} spelt in English as {%fanam;%} cf. {%Yādavarāyan-paṇam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">name of a coin issued by the Yādavarāyas; name of a coin
<div n="lb">80 ratis in weight; same as the copper {%kārsāpaṇa;%} equal to 80
<div n="lb">cowrie-shells according to the {%Līlāvatī;%} copper coin (1/16) of a
<div n="lb">silver {%kārṣāpaṇa%} according to the {%Kṛtyakalpataru%} (Vyavahāra-
<div n="lb">kāṇḍa, ed. K.V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, p. 125), and (1/48) of a
[Page-229+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%suvarṇa%} ({%JNSI,%} Vol. II, p. 7); also used to indicate ‘money’.
<div n="lb">In Tamil, {%paṇam%} means a particular coin (usually, a small gold
<div n="lb">coin), or money in general, or taxes; cf. {%paṇa-vargam%} (SITI), a
<div n="lb">class of taxes payable in cash, same as {%kāśāya-vargam;%} also {%paṇa-%}
<div n="lb">{%vāśi,%} ‘discount payable for the exchange of coins; amount pay-
<div n="lb">able to make up the wear in the coin’. Cf. {%vil-paṇam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">sale-tax; also understood as a tax on bows or archery; {%vāśal-%}
<div n="lb">{%paṇam%} (SITI), door-tax or periodical payment due to the
<div n="lb">palace.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), a sect or caste, eighteen in number theoretically.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 19), a land measure.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a liquid; name of a measure.

<L>4009<pc>230<k1>पञ्चकुल<k2>पञ्चकुल
{%pañcakula%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 5, 25; CII 4; LP; HRS), the {%Pañ-%}
<div n="lb">{%cāyat%} Board; an assembly of administrators and arbitrators,
<div n="lb">usually consisting of five members; a board of administration
<div n="lb">charged with control of the customs house, with the deposit of
<div n="lb">property of persons dying without heirs into the royal treasury,
<div n="lb">etc.; also called {%pañcapa%} (EI 4); members of such a board; ac-
<div n="lb">cording to some, an officer over a certain number of villages
<div n="lb">(HD). Cf. {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XI, p. 242. Cf. {%Pañcavīra, Pāñca-%}
<div n="lb">{%kulika, añjaṣṭa-sabhā,%} etc.

<L>4018<pc>230<k1>पञ्चमहापातक<k2>पञ्च-महापातक
{%pañca-mahāpātaka%}¦ (EI 26; CII 3; CITD), the five great
<div n="lb">sins or heinous crimes, viz., killing a Brāhmaṇa, drinking intoxi-
<div n="lb">cating liquors, stealing gold, committing adultery with the
<div n="lb">wife of a {%guru%} and associating with any one guilty of these
<div n="lb">crimes. Cf. {%daś-āparādha, pañc-ānantarya.%}
<LEND>

<L>4019<pc>230<k1>पञ्चमहाशब्द<k2>पञ्च-महाशब्द
{%pañca-mahāśabda%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; SITI; CITD;
<div n="lb">BL), refers to the privilege of enjoying the sounds of five
<div n="lb">musical instruments, or five titles beginning with {%mahat;%} five
<div n="lb">official designations or musical instruments mentioned in con-
<div n="lb">nection with feudatories; five official designations beginning
<div n="lb">with the word {%mahā%} in the North and five kinds of musical
<div n="lb">instruments in the South; in South India, it was the same as
<div n="lb">{%pañca-mahānināda,%} i. e. the sounds of the five great musical ins-
<div n="lb">truments called the {%pañca-mahāvādya%} enumerated by some as a
[Page-231+ 40]
<div n="lb">horn, a tabor, a conch-shell, a kettle-drum and a gong; in
<div n="lb">some parts of North India, the expression indicated five
<div n="lb">official designations with the prefix {%mahā.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), sounds of five musical instruments, the use of
<div n="lb">which was allowed to persons of high rank and authority;
<div n="lb">usually a title of feudatories; cf. {%tat-pradatta-pañcamahāśabda%} (IE
<div n="lb">8-2), used in respect of feudatory rulers who received the right
<div n="lb">of enjoying the {%pañca-mahāśabda%} from their overlords; rarely
<div n="lb">used in the South by independent monarchs. Cf. {%pañca-vādya%} (EI
<div n="lb">4) and {%pañca-mahāvādya.%} See {%Samadhigata-pañcamahāśabda,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. pañca-māśattam%} (SITI), the five musical instruments,
<div n="lb">to the use of which a nobleman was entitled; sometimes enu-
<div n="lb">merated as {%ceṇḍai, timilai, śegaṇḍi,%} cymbals and {%kāhaḻam%} or as
<div n="lb">{%tattaḻi, maddaḻi, karaḻikai,%} cymbals and {%kāhaḻam.%}
<div n="P">({%SII%} 11-1), cf. grant of 40 {%mattars%} of land to a piper for
<div n="lb">arranging to play the five musical instruments.
<LEND>

<L>4020<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमहावाद्य<k2>पञ्च-महावाद्य
{%pañca-mahāvādya%}¦ (EI 12), enumerated as the horn, conch-
<div n="lb">shell, tambourine, trumpet and gong. See {%pañca-mahāśabda.%}
<LEND>

<L>4021<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमहायज्ञ<k2>पञ्च-महायज्ञ
{%pañca-mahāyajña%}¦ (EI 29; CII 3, 4), ‘the five great sacri-
<div n="lb">fices’; the five daily duties of a Brāhmaṇa enumerated as {%bali,%}
<div n="lb">{%caru, vaiśvadeva, agnihotra%} and {%atithi.%}
<LEND>

<L>4022<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमलोकपाल<k2>पञ्चम-लोकपाल
{%Pañcama-lokapāla%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXII, p. 93), epithet
<div n="lb">of certain kings; cf. {%Lokapāla.%}
<LEND>

<L>4023<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमण्डली<k2>पञ्च-मण्डली
{%pañca-maṇḍalī%}¦ (CII 3, 4; HD), an assembly of five persons;
<div n="lb">equivalent to the modern {%Pañcāit, Pañcāyat%} or {%Pañc,%} i. e., a village
<div n="lb">jury. See {%pāñcaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>4024<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमातृका<k2>पञ्च-मातृका
{%pañca-mātṛkā,%}¦ cf. Prakrit {%paṃca-mātuka%} (EI 20), five princi-
<div n="lb">pal texts of the Buddhists, also called {%pañca-nikāya,%} viz., the
<div n="lb">{%Dīgha-nikāya, Majjhima-nikāya, Aṅguttara-nikāya, Khuddaka-nikāya%}
<div n="lb">and {%Saṃyutta-nikāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>4025<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमौष्टिकलोच<k2>पञ्च-मौष्टिक-लोच
{%pañca-mauṣṭika-loca%}¦ (HA), plucking out five handfuls of
<div n="lb">hair by a would-be Jina at the time of {%dīkṣā.%}
<LEND>

<L>4026<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमीबलि<k2>पञ्चमी-बलि
{%pañcamī-bali%}¦ (EI 11), a particular {%tithi%} of the year.
<LEND>

<L>4027<pc>231<k1>पञ्चामृत<k2>पञ्च्-आमृत
{%pañc-āmṛta%}¦ (SITI), mixture of five objects for anointing
<div n="lb">idols, viz. banana, honey, sugar, ghee and grape.
<LEND>

<L>4028<pc>231<k1>पञ्चमुखनगर<k2>पञ्च-मुख-नगर
{%pañca-mukha-nagara%}¦ (LP), explained as ‘a city in which
<div n="lb">there are five leading men’; cf. {%pañca-mukha-nagara-viditam%} (LP),
<div n="lb">‘having informed the five leading men of the city’; explained
<div n="lb">as ‘the five-fold people of the town’ ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XLI, p. 20);
<div n="lb">really ‘the citizens headed by the members of the {%Pañcāyat%}’.
<LEND>
[Page-232+ 40]

<L>4029<pc>232<k1>पञ्चनगर<k2>पञ्च-नगर
{%pañca-nagara,%}¦ a mercantile guild (cf. {%nagara,%} also {%pañca%});
<div n="lb">see {%A.R. Ep.,%} 1956-57, No. B 190.
<LEND>

<L>4030<pc>232<k1>पञ्चनैकायिक<k2>पञ्चनैकायिक
{%Pañcanaikāyika%}¦ (LL), Buddhist; a teacher of the five {%nikāyas%}
<div n="lb">(e. g. {%Dīgha-nikāya, Majjhima-nikāya, Khuddaka-nikāya, Saṃyutta-%}
<div n="lb">{%nikaya%} and {%Aṅguttara-nikāya%}).
<LEND>

<L>4031<pc>232<k1>पञ्चानन्तर्य<k2>पञ्च्-आनन्तर्य
{%pañc-ānantarya%}¦ (CII 3), the five sins that entail immediate
<div n="lb">retribution. See {%pañca-mahāpātaka, daś-āparādha, pañc-āparādha.%}
<LEND>

<L>4032<pc>232<k1>पञ्चाङ्ग<k2>पञ्चाङ्ग
{%pañcāṅga%}¦ (CII 3), the Hindu almanac; in the Deccan
<div n="lb">and in some other parts, the {%pañcāṅgas%} are now prepared from
<div n="lb">the {%Grahalāghava%} and the {%Tithicintāmaṇi%} of {%Gaṇeśa-daivajña.%} The
<div n="lb">right of reading the {%pañcāṅga%} was sometimes granted by the
<div n="lb">rulers to individuals (ASLV).
<LEND>

<L>4033<pc>232<k1>पञ्चाङ्गनमस्कार<k2>पञ्चाङ्ग-नमस्कार
{%pañcāṅga-namaskāra%}¦ (HA), bowing down in such a way
<div n="lb">that five limbs of the body (viz., two hands, two knees and the
<div n="lb">head) touch the ground. Cf. {%aṣṭ-āṅga-namaskāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>4034<pc>232<k1>पञ्चाङ्गप्रसाद<k2>पञ्चाङ्ग-प्रसाद
{%pañcāṅga-prasāda,%}¦ cf. {%pañcāṅga-pasāya%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. IX,
<div n="lb">p. 95), translated as ‘five manners of gifts’; cf. {%pañcāṅga-pasāya%}
<div n="lb">{%chatra sukhāsana bbala gaddi aṅka-daṇḍa-khaṇḍane,%} translated as
<div n="lb">‘gave [to that Māro-śĕṭṭi] five manners of gifts--an umbrella,
<div n="lb">a palanquin, an escort, a throne and with the faults, fines and
<div n="lb">divisions (really ‘with fines and the grain share’).’
<LEND>

<L>4035<pc>232<k1>पञ्चप<k2>पञ्चप
{%pañcapa%}¦ (EI 4), same as {%pañcakula%} (q. v.).

<L>4036<pc>232<k1>पञ्चापराध<k2>पञ्च्-आपराध
{%pañc-āparādha%}¦ (HRS), known from the Gupta and other
<div n="lb">records; donee's privilege relating to the enjoyment of fines
<div n="lb">payable by persons committing five offences. Cf. {%daś-āparādha,%}
<div n="lb">{%pañc-ānantarya, pañca-mahāpātaka.%}

<div n="lb">sometimes used to indicate ‘taxes in general’; cf. {%paṅga-śulka,%}

<L>4065<pc>234<k1>पङ्गतप्पु<k2>पङ्ग-तप्पु

<L>4079<pc>234<k1>पन्नस<k2>पन्नस
{%pannasa,%}¦ also spelt {%pannāsa, pannāsu%} (IE 8-6; EI 5, 12; {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 336, note 3), Kannaḍa; probably derived from
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%pañchāśat%} in the sense of a tenure in which the donee
<div n="lb">enjoyed fifty per cent of the revenue of the donated land. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%pannavīsa.%} ({%EI%} 20), explained as ‘a gift’.

<L>4080<pc>234<k1>पन्नास<k2>पन्नास

<div n="lb">krit {%pañcaviṃśati;%} probably a tenure in which the donee enjoyed

<L>4159<pc>238<k1>परिगृहीत<k2>परिगृहीत
{%parigṛhīta%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 31), ‘accepted’, sometimes used in
<div n="lb">place of {%anudhyāta%} (‘meditating’ or ‘favoured’) in passages like
<div n="lb">{%tatpāda-parighṛhīta;%} cf. {%bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta, bhaṭṭāraka-%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāsena-parigṛhīta,%} etc.; refers to selection or acceptance of a
<div n="lb">succession or appointment or receipt in one's favour.
<div n="P">{%Cf. catuḥśāla-parigṛhītaṃ śaila-maṇḍapam%} and {%Samyaksam-%}
<div n="lb">{%buddhasya dhātu-parigṛhītasya%} ({%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 228).

<L>4160<pc>238<k1>परिहार<k2>परिहार
{%parihāra%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 6; SITI), same as {%maryādā-parihāra;%}
[Page-239+ 40]
<div n="lb">exemptions from taxes and obligations granted to the donees of
<div n="lb">rent-free land; privileges of the donee of rent-free holdings; for
<div n="lb">many such privileges, see Appendix I. Cf. certain privileges
<div n="lb">in respect of a number of taxes and obligations enumerated in
<div n="lb">Tamil records as follows: {%vaṭṭi-nāḻi%} (payment of one {%nāḻi%} per
<div n="lb">{%vaṭṭi%}), {%pudā-nāḻi%} (or {%pidāº,%} cess on each door or tax for the main-
<div n="lb">tenance of sluices), {%maṇṟupādu%} (fine imposed by a court of law),
<div n="lb">{%ūrāṭci%} (tax for running the village administration), {%taragu%} (tax
<div n="lb">on brokers), {%kūlam%} (tax on grains), {%ī%}l13{%am-puṭi%} (tax on toddy-
<div n="lb">drawers), {%nāḍu-kāval%} (tax for the policing of a district), {%ūḍupokku%}
<div n="lb">(meaning uncertain), {%uppu-kocceygai%} (tax for the manufacture of
<div n="lb">salt), {%nall-ā%} (tax for maintaining specimen cows), {%nallerudu%} (tax
<div n="lb">for maintaining specimen buffaloes), {%nerv-āypuvum%} (meaning un-
<div n="lb">certain) and others. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVIII, p. 124.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), a ring.
<LEND>

<L>4161<pc>239<k1>पारिहारिक<k2>पारिहारिक
{%pārihārika%}¦ (HRS), land exempted from revenue, as sug-
<div n="lb">gested by the {%Arthaśāstra;%} privileges enjoyed by the donee
<div n="lb">of a rent-free holding.
<div n="P">{%Cf. sarva-jāta-pārihārika;%} same as {%parihāra%} or the {%parihāras%}
<div n="lb">collectively. See {%Select Inscriptions,%} pp. 192, 194.
<LEND>

<L>4162<pc>239<k1>पारिहीनिक<k2>पारिहीनिक
{%pārihīnika%}¦ (HRS), damage-fee which was a branch of
<div n="lb">accidental revenue, according to the {%Arthaśāstra.%} See Ghoshal,
<div n="lb">{%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 28.
<LEND>

<L>4163<pc>239<k1>परिकर<k2>परिकर
{%parikara%}¦ (IE 8-5; CII 4), same as {%uparikara,%} occasional or
<div n="lb">minor taxes; cf. {%sa-parikara%} (EI 23) which is the same as {%s-opari-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), requisites of a village.
<div n="P">({%HA%}), accessory decoration round the figure of a Jina,
<div n="lb">the motifs being taken from the Jain conception of the eight
<div n="lb">chief objects attendant upon a Jina ({%aṣṭa-mahāprātihāryāṇi,%} viz.
<div n="lb">the wheel of law, the caitya-tree, the lion-seat, the aureole behind
<div n="lb">the head, two attendant flywhisk-bearers, drum-beaters and
<div n="lb">pipe-players, and garland-bearers).
<LEND>

<L>4164<pc>239<k1>परिकार<k2>परिकार
{%Parikāra%}¦ (SITI), a servant.
<LEND>

<L>4165<pc>239<k1>पारिख्<k2>पारिख्

<div n="lb">coins; a family name amongst the Baniās. See {%Rūpa-darśaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>4166<pc>239<k1>पारिखाय<k2>पारिख्-आय

<L>4261<pc>244<k1>पट्ट<k2>पट्ट
{%paṭṭa%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 3, 4), a territorial term meaning a
<div n="lb">group of villages; cf. {%apara-paṭṭa%} (EI 22) ‘the western district’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7, 9, 11; SII 1; BL), a school or spiritual line; a
<div n="lb">pontificate; a pontifical seat; the dignity of the head of a Jain
<div n="lb">school; cf. reference to a Jain religious teacher as belonging to
<div n="lb">the {%paṭṭa%} of another teacher and the {%santāna%} of a third teacher;
<div n="lb">cf., e. g., ‘in the {%paṭṭa%} of Dharma-sūri’; also cf. ‘{%paṭṭ-āvalī%} of
<div n="lb">the Kharatara {%gaccha%}’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. rāja-paṭṭa, paṭṭa-bandha, paṭṭ-ābhiṣeka,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 18), a piece of land.
<div n="P">({%LL%}), a slab; cf. Prakrit {%paṭa%} (EI 20), a stone slab. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%yoni-paṭṭa; Gaurī-paṭṭa.%}
<div n="P">({%Chamba%}), also called {%paṭha;%} a grain measure, derived
<div n="lb">from Sanskrit {%prastha.%}

<L>4417<pc>253<k1>प्रबन्ध<k2>प्रबन्ध
{%prabandha,%}¦ name of hymnal compositions in Tamil by
<div n="lb">ancient Vaiṣṇava devotees. The contributions of hymns and
<div n="lb">prayers by the twelve {%ā%}l13{%vārs%} in praise of Viṣṇu make up the
<div n="lb">{%Nālāyiradivyaprabandham. Nālāyira%} (four thousand) indicates the
<div n="lb">rough total number of items and {%prabandham%} is regarded as mean-
<div n="lb">ing a compilation. The first thousand is known as {%Tirumo%}l13{%i%} and
<div n="lb">comprises hymns of Periyāl13vār, Āṇḍāl, Kulaśekhara, etc.; the
<div n="lb">second thousand contains the hymns of Tirumaṅgai; the third
<div n="lb">comprises the compositions of the first three {%ā%}l13{%vārs%} called
<div n="lb">{%Iya%}ṟ{%pā,%} viz. Tirumal13iśai, Nammāl13var and Tirumaṅgai, and the
<div n="lb">fourth called {%Tiruvāymo%}l13{%i%} is entirely the work of Nammāl13vār.
<div n="lb">Nāthamunigal13 is stated to be the compiler of this anthology.
<div n="lb">See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, {%Tamil Literature,%} pp. 181 ff.
<LEND>

<L>4458<pc>255<k1>प्रकृति<k2>प्रकृति
{%prakṛti%}¦ (HD); cf. {%Mahābhārata,%} II. v. 23, speaking of
<div n="lb">the seven {%prakṛtis%} which Nīlakaṇṭha explains as referring to
<div n="lb">{%Durg-ādhyakṣa%} (commandant of the citadel), {%Bal-ādhyakṣa%} (con-
<div n="lb">troller general of the army), {%Dharma-ādhyakṣa%} (chief of the
<div n="lb">departments of charity and justice), {%Camūpati%} (commander of
<div n="lb">the army in the field), chaplain, physician and astrologer. The
<div n="lb">{%Milindapañha%} (IV. i. 36) mentions six officers, e.g., the com-
<div n="lb">mander-in-chief, prime minister, chief judge, chief treasurer,
<div n="lb">bearer of the sun-shade and bearer of the sword of state (cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 77, note 6). Cf. {%Mātra.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 16), a temple official.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘twentyone.’
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9), the Kṣatriya community.
<div n="P">{%Cf. sa-tantuvāya-gokuṭa-śauṇḍik-ādi-prakṛtika%} (IE 8-5);
<div n="lb">subjects of a king.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), usage.

<L>4527<pc>259<k1>प्रतिहार<k2>प्रतिहार, प्रतीहार
{%Pratihāra, Pratīhāra%}¦ (EI 23; BL), also called {%Pratihārin%}
<div n="lb">(EI 3, 23), ‘a door-keeper’; but cf. {%Mahāpratihāra%} who was a
<div n="lb">high officer; officer in charge of the defence of the royal palace
<div n="lb">or bed-chamber or the head of the guards of the city gate; a
<div n="lb">chamberlain or inditer of grants, according to some (HD);
<div n="lb">personal attendant of a king, according to others (CII; 4). See
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VIII, p. 73; Vol. IX, p. 192; Bṛhaspati quoted by
<div n="lb">Viśvarūpa on the {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} I. 307 (for his qualifications);
<div n="lb">{%Mahābhārata,%} Ādiparvan, 85. 28-29; {%Viṣṇudharmottara,%} II. 24.
<div n="lb">12; Śukra, I. 121. Cf. {%Antaḥ-pratīhāra%} (IE 8-3), {%Rajju-pratihāra.%}

<L>4608<pc>263<k1>प्रावेश्य<k2>प्रावेश्य
{%prāveśya%}¦ (EI 31), also spelt {%praveśya;%} explained by some
<div n="lb">as a small territorial unit; sometimes translated as ‘situated in’
<div n="lb">(CII 4); but may refer to the revenue assessment of a village
<div n="lb">along with another; cf. {%Ardhaṭi-prāveśya-Lavaṅgasikāyām%} ({%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 143); same as {%praveśa.%} Cf. {%Hastiśīrṣa-prāveśya-%}

<div n="lb">as ‘Kandalivāḍa-grāma having its rent assessed along with
<div n="lb">Siviḍi.’ Same as {%prāpīya%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 109); cf. {%Akṣa-%}
<div n="lb">{%saraka-prāveśya%} used in the sense as {%Akṣasaraka-prāpīya.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. praveśa, prāveśa, prāpīya%} (LP), also {%patra-pṛṣṭhato praveśyo%}
<div n="lb">{%dātavyaḥ,%} ‘should get [the sum] entered at the back of the docu-
<div n="lb">ment’ ({%dātavya%} from {%dā%} ‘to cut’).
<div n="P">{%Cf. a-prāveśya,%} etc. (IE 8-5); entrance.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-8; EI 30), an entry tax or levies relating to the
<div n="lb">entry of royal agents.

<L>4611<pc>263<k1>प्रयाणदण्ड<k2>प्रयाण-दण्ड
{%prayāṇa-daṇḍa%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 25, 26), cf. {%rājasevakānāṃ vasati-%}
<div n="lb">{%daṇḍa-prayāṇa-daṇḍau na staḥ;%} refers to the obligation of the
<div n="lb">villagers to provide free conveyance and carriage of loads, etc.,
<div n="lb">when royal officers passed through their village. {%Prayāṇa%} thus
<div n="lb">seems to mean ‘passage, transit’, and {%daṇḍa%} ‘levy’; cf. {%rūḍhabhāroḍi.%}

<L>4649<pc>265<k1>पुराण<k2>पुराण
{%purāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 12, 21, 29), name of a coin; a silver
<div n="lb">coin also called {%dharaṇa%} and {%kārṣāpaṇa%} (32 or 24 {%ratis%}); cf. {%kapar-%}
<div n="lb">{%daka-purāṇa%} (EI 26), meaning {%purāṇa%} calculated in cowrie-
<div n="lb">shells; also {%paṇa-purāṇa%} (i. e. {%purāṇa%} counted in copper {%paṇas%}).
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXVIII, p. 246), the Purāṇa texts, e. g.
<div n="lb">the {%Āditya Purāṇa.%}
<LEND>

<L>4651<pc>265<k1>पुरपालोपरिक<k2>पुरपाल्-ओपरिक
{%Purapāl-oparika%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; BL), official designation pro-
<div n="lb">bably indicating the governor of a city or chief amongst the
<div n="lb">governors of cities; called {%Mahārāja, Mahāsāmanta, Mahāprati-%}
<div n="lb">{%hāra, Mahāpīlupati, Pañcakaraṇoparika%} and {%Pāṭyuparika%} addition-
<div n="lb">ally (IE 8-3). The expression may also mean two different
[Page-266+ 40]
<div n="lb">designations, viz. {%Purapāla%} and {%Uparika.%} With {%Purapāla,%} cf. {%Pura-%}
<div n="lb">{%pati,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>4658<pc>266<k1>पूर्णघटकपट्ट<k2>पूर्णघटक-पट्ट
{%pūrṇaghaṭaka-paṭṭa%}¦ (LL), slab bearing the representa-

<LEND>

<L>4659<pc>266<k1>पूर्णिमान्त<k2>पूर्णिमान्त
{%pūrṇimānta%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), the technical name for the scheme
<div n="lb">of the lunar months in Northern India, according to which
<div n="lb">the months end with the full-moon day, and the dark fortnights
<div n="lb">precede the bright; Fleet states that in astronomical works, it
<div n="lb">is always the {%amānta%} arrangement that is actually taken for
<div n="lb">calculations though, even in Southern India, the {%pūrṇimānta%}
<div n="lb">arrangement was used with the Śaka years, for the civil reckoning,
<div n="lb">up to between 804 and 866 A. D.; on the other hand, according
<div n="lb">to him, even in Northern India, it was not used with the Newar
<div n="lb">era in Nepal, though it was adopted there when the Newar
<div n="lb">era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern variety.
<LEND>

<L>4660<pc>266<k1>पुरोग<k2>पुरोग
{%Puroga%}¦ (EI 23), prominent among a particular class of
<div n="lb">people; sometimes wrongly taken to be the same as {%Purohita.%}
<LEND>

<L>4661<pc>266<k1>पुरोहित<k2>पुरोहित
{%Purohita%}¦ (CII 4; SII 1; BL; ASLV; HD), a priest; a
<div n="lb">family priest; the royal priest; occurs in the list of functionaries
<div n="lb">in records like those of the Gāhaḍavālas ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p.
<div n="lb">305) and Senas (ibid., Vol. XII, p. 9). See {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">III, pp. 111-12, 117.
<LEND>

<L>4662<pc>266<k1>पुरोनायक<k2>पुरो-नायक

<L>4694<pc>268<k1>पूति<k2>पूति
{%pūti%}¦ (EI 12, 14), also read as {%yūti;%} cf. {%tṛṇa-pūti%} (or {%yūti%})-
<div n="lb">{%go-cara-paryanta,%} epithet of a gift village. The expression {%tṛṇa-%}
<div n="lb">{%pūti%} or {%tṛṇa-yūti%} may mean ‘grass-land’. The word is some-
<div n="lb">times written as {%yutī%} and {%yuthī%} also.

{%putra,%}¦ cf. {%Nigama-putra%} (LL), ‘the inhabitant of a {%nigama%}
<div n="lb">(township).’
<div n="P">{%Cf. Durgā-putra, Puruṣottama-putra,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), probably confused with {%pāṇḍu-putra%} and used

<L>4696<pc>268<k1>पुत्रसूनु<k2>पुत्र-सूनु

<LEND>

<L>4697<pc>268<k1>पुट्टि<k2>पुट्टि
{%puṭṭi%}¦ (CITD), Telugu; a measure equal to twenty {%tūmus;%}
<div n="lb">also called {%khaṇḍi%} (spelt {%candy%} in English and found as {%khaṇḍikā%}
<div n="lb">in Sanskrit inscriptions) and regarded as equal to between 800
<div n="lb">and 1000 seers. {%Khaṇḍi%} at Masulipatam has 3 weights, viz.
<div n="lb">488 pounds for tobacco, 500 pounds for metals, hardware, etc.,
<div n="lb">and 560 pounds for sugar, dates and other soft articles. The
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi%} and its fractions also denote the area of the land that is
<div n="lb">supposed by some to produce the particular quantities of
<div n="lb">grain. According to some, it is a land measure equal to 8
<div n="lb">acres being presumably the area which can be sown with a
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi%} of grain. There were different kinds of {%puṭṭis,%} e. g. {%gāl-%}
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi.%} Cf. also {%pelle-puṭṭi%} regarded as equal to 80 {%kuñcas%} and
<div n="lb">{%Malaca-puṭṭi%} or Malacca ton as equal to 300 to 240 {%kuñcas.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4, 27), a land and grain measure.
[Page-269+ 38]
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), same as Telugu {%puṭṭi-dosillu,%} ‘a fee of two hand-
<div n="lb">fuls from each {%puṭṭi%} of grain paid to the village-servants’.
<LEND>

<L>4698<pc>269<k1>पुट्टिदोसिल्लु<k2>पुट्टि-दोसिल्लु
{%puṭṭi-dosillu%}¦ (EI 33), a levy; see {%puṭṭi.%}
<LEND>

<L>4699<pc>269<k1>प्योडा<k2>प्योडा
{%pyoḍā%}¦ (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt {%piṭha, piḍā,%}
<div n="lb">{%peḍā.%}

<L>4714<pc>269<k1>राहुत्तरायन्<k2>राहुत्त-रायन्
{%Rāhutta-rāyan%}¦ (SITI), Sanskrit {%Rājaputra-rājan;%} title of
<div n="lb">nobility; explained as ‘a cavalry officer’.
<LEND>

<L>4715<pc>269<k1>रैक्वाल<k2>रैक्वाल
{%Raikvāla%}¦ (Chamba), the king's personal servant.
<LEND>

<L>4716<pc>269<k1>राज<k2>राज
{%Rāja%}¦ (LP), abbreviation of {%Rājaputra (Rājpūt);%} explained
<div n="lb">as a cavalry-soldier or a {%Rājpūt.%} See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, pp.
[Page-270+ 40]
<div n="lb">143-44, where it is probably an abbreviation of {%Rājakula (Rāval).%}
<LEND>

<L>4723<pc>270<k1>राजधानी<k2>राजधानी

<L>4724<pc>270<k1>राजाधिराज<k2>राजाधिराज

<div n="lb">paramount sovereignty; an imperial title meaning ‘the king of
<div n="lb">kings’; used in the Gupta period in some metrical passages,
<div n="lb">both alone and along with {%Rājarājādhirāja.%} Cf. {%Adhirājarāja%}
<div n="lb">(EI 9).

<div n="lb">for the king.’

<L>4729<pc>270<k1>राजगृह<k2>राज-गृह

<div n="lb">rities; also the taxes due to the same. Cf. {%rājakaraṅ-kāṇikkai,%}

<L>4739<pc>271<k1>राजकुल<k2>राजकुल
{%Rājakula%}¦ (IE 8-5; CII 3; IA 20; BL; HD), royal house-
<div n="lb">hold; the king, royal officers and members of the royal family.
<div n="lb">Originally, ‘the royal family’; then ‘a member of the royal
<div n="lb">family’; and then ‘a royal officer’; later, a title of nobility, same
<div n="lb">as modern {%Rāval%} or {%Rāul.%} See Bhandarkar's List, No. 324.
<div n="P">{%Cf. rājakulaṅ-kāṇi-ppaṟṟu%} (SITI), ‘land or village in the
<div n="lb">enjoyment of the members of the royal family’. The expres-
<div n="lb">sion occurs along with {%devadāna, brahmadeya, paḻḻiccandam,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>4740<pc>271<k1>राजकुमार<k2>राजकुमार
{%Rājakumāra%}¦ (IE 8-3; LL; HD), same as {%Rājaputra;%} desig-
<div n="lb">nation of a prince. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. I, p. 5.
<LEND>

<L>4741<pc>271<k1>राजलिपिकर<k2>राज-लिपिकर
{%Rāja-lipikara%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 2; LL), king's scribe.

<div n="lb">or government; same as {%rājakīya-māna.%}

<L>4746<pc>271<k1>राजन्<k2>राजन्
{%Rājan%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), royal title;
<div n="lb">originally used by imperial rulers; later, when emperors assumed
<div n="lb">more dignified titles, a title of feudatories and smaller rulers.
<div n="lb">Cf. Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} p. 121; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p. 297.
<LEND>

<L>4747<pc>271<k1>राजनक<k2>राजनक
{%Rājanaka%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 23, 29), same as {%Rājānaka,%}
<div n="lb">{%Rājanyaka, Rājānika;%} a feudatory; in some cases, smaller than
<div n="lb">the feudatory called {%Rājan.%}
<LEND>

<L>4748<pc>271<k1>राजानक<k2>राजानक
{%Rājānaka%}¦ (IE 8-2, 8-3; EI 30; BL; HD), same as {%Rājanaka,%}
<div n="lb">{%Rājanyaka, Rājānika%} or {%Rāṇaka;%} title of feudatory rulers or of
<div n="lb">the nobility; often a feudatory smaller than a {%Rājan.%} Cf. {%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%taraṅgiṇī,%} VI. 117, 261 (title given for services to the king and
<div n="lb">surviving in the form {%Rāzdān%} as a family name of Kashmir Brāh-
<div n="lb">maṇas); {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, pp. 394, 306.
<LEND>
[Page-272+ 40]

<L>4760<pc>272<k1>राजपुत्र<k2>राज-पुत्र
{%Rāja-putra%}¦ (EI 30; CII 3; 4; HD), originally ‘a prince’;
<div n="lb">title of princes and subordinate rulers; but later a title of nobi-
<div n="lb">lity especially in the modified forms {%Rāvata, Rāuta,%} etc.; some-
<div n="lb">times also used in the sense of ‘a Rājpūt’ often explained as ‘a
<div n="lb">horse-man’. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321. See {%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%putraka.%}

<L>4761<pc>272<k1>राजपुत्रक<k2>राज-पुत्रक

<L>4778<pc>273<k1>राजस्थानी<k2>राजस्थानी

<LEND>

<L>4779<pc>273<k1>राजस्थानीय<k2>राजस्थानीय
{%Rājasthānīya%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 24, 26, 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD),
<div n="lb">‘an officer acting for the king’; generally a viceroy; probably
<div n="lb">also a subordinate ruler; but cf. {%Rājasthān-ādhikāra%} who was
<div n="lb">also a judge; an official title indicating a viceroy in some areas
<div n="lb">and a judge in others; an officer who carried out the object
<div n="lb">of protecting subjects, according to some ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. V,
<div n="lb">p. 207). Cf. {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 157; Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} p.
<div n="lb">112; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 176 (probably, a chief justice),
<div n="lb">explained wrongly as ‘an officer connected with other kings,
<div n="lb">i. e. a foreign secretary’ ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XII, p. 122, note 76).
<LEND>

<L>4780<pc>273<k1>राजस्थानोपरिक<k2>राजस्थान्-ओपरिक
{%Rājasthān-oparika%}¦ (EI 29), probably a viceroy; cf. {%Rājas-%}
<div n="lb">{%thānīya%} and {%Uparika.%} See {%Rājasthān-ādhikāra%} and {%Rājas-%}
<div n="lb">{%thānīya.%}
<LEND>

<L>4781<pc>273<k1>राजसूय<k2>राजसूय
{%rājasūya%}¦ (EI 4), name of a sacrifice.
<LEND>

<L>4782<pc>273<k1>राजस्व<k2>राजस्व
{%rājasva%}¦ (SITI), property belonging to the king or state
<div n="lb">[by confiscation, etc.].

<L>4783<pc>273<k1>राजातिराज<k2>राजातिराज

<div n="lb">certain foreign rulers; cf. {%Basileos Basileon Megalou.%}

<L>4784<pc>273<k1>राजवैद्य<k2>राज-वैद्य
{%Rāja-vaidya%}¦ (IE 8-3; LL), physician to the king; the royal
<div n="lb">physician.
<LEND>

<L>4785<pc>273<k1>राजावली<k2>राज्-आवली
{%rāj-āvalī%}¦ (EI 9; IA 30), genealogy of rulers; a list of
<div n="lb">lineal succession of kings.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 10), royal titles; cf. {%rājāvalī pūrvavat%} (IE 8-2), ‘the
[Page-274+ 40]
<div n="lb">royal titles as above’, often used when a repetition of the string
<div n="lb">of royal titles was avoided. Cf. {%Paramabhaṭṭārak-ety-ādi-rāj-āvalī-%}
<div n="lb">{%tray-opeta%} referring to the imperial titles {%Paramabhaṭṭāraka,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahārājādhirāja%} and {%Parameśvara.%}

<L>4786<pc>274<k1>राजवल्लभ<k2>राज-वल्लभ

<div n="lb">favourite’; a courtier.

<L>4789<pc>274<k1>राजवेश्याभुजङ्ग<k2>राज-वेश्या-भुजङ्ग
{%Rāja-veśyā-bhujaṅga%}¦ (SITI), ‘the lover of the courtesans
<div n="lb">of the [enemy] kings’; a title assumed by some kings after cap-
<div n="lb">turing the enemies’ countries, probably describing {%rājya-śrī%} as
<div n="lb">a prostitute.

<L>4796<pc>274<k1>रज्जुक<k2>रज्जुक
{%Rajjuka%}¦ (IE 8-3; HD), Prakrit {%Rajuka%} or {%Lajūka%} (EI 2);
<div n="lb">an officer of the land survey and revenue department, accord-
<div n="lb">ing to some; but seems to be the governor of a district, one of
<div n="lb">whose functions was probably the survey of land with a measur-
<div n="lb">ing rope for the fixation of the amount of the king's share of
<div n="lb">the produce; probably the same as Greek {%Agronomoi%} mentioned
<div n="lb">by Megasthenes.
<LEND>

<L>4797<pc>274<k1>रज्जुप्रतिहार<k2>रज्जु-प्रतिहार
{%Rajju-pratihāra%}¦ (EI 24), ‘rope-jugglers or dancers’; cf.
<div n="lb">{%rajju-pratihār-āpaṇa,%} ‘booths of rope-jugglers and dancers’; but
<div n="lb">{%rajju-pratihār-āpaṇājīvika%} may be a tax for maintaining surveyors
<div n="lb">and gate-keepers (toll-collectors) and from shop-keepers.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">XXXII, p. 343. The name is also spelt {%Raṇṇā%} or {%Rāṇā.%}

<div n="lb">Thanwala near Pushkar was Rannāditya (also spelt {%Raṇṇāditya%}
<div n="lb">and {%Rāṇāditya%}).

<L>4855<pc>278<k1>राष्ट्रिक<k2>राष्ट्रिक
{%Rāṣṭrika%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 1; HD; LL), Prakrit {%Raṭhika%} (EI 2),
<div n="lb">{%Raṭṭhika%} (EI 7); same as {%Rāṣṭrin;%} ruler of a {%rāṣṭra,%} i. e. a district
<div n="lb">or its subdivision; also the name of a people called ‘hereditary
<div n="lb">{%Rāṣṭrikas%}’. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. I, p. 5; Bhandarkar, {%Aśoka,%} p. 30.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p. 78), mentioned in the list of
<div n="lb">officials addressed by the king in respect of a grant.
<LEND>

<L>4856<pc>278<k1>राष्ट्रिन्<k2>राष्ट्रिन्

<div n="lb">{%Rāṣṭrapati, Mahārāṣṭrin,%} etc.

<div n="lb">{%kṛṣṇarāja-rūpaka%} (EI 25; CII 4), a silver coin issued by the
<div n="lb">Kalacuri king Kṛṣṇarāja; silver coin (1/16) of the value of a gold
<div n="lb">{%dīnāra%} in the Gupta age ({%JNSI,%} Vol. II, p. 5); same as {%dramma.%}

<L>5067<pc>288<k1>समधिगतपञ्चमहाशब्द<k2>समधिगत-पञ्च-महाशब्द
{%Samadhigata-pañca-mahāśabda%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII 3), a customary
<div n="lb">epithet of feudatory rulers, indicating that they were entitled
<div n="lb">to the privilege of the {%pañca-mahāśabda%} (five kinds of musical
<div n="lb">instruments), or of using five official titles beginning with the
<div n="lb">word {%mahā.%} There are a few instances in which the epithet
<div n="lb">is applied to paramount sovereigns in South India. The title
<div n="lb">is sometimes stated to have been conferred on a feudatory by
<div n="lb">his overlord. See {%mahāśabda,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>5068<pc>288<k1>समाहर्तृ<k2>समाहर्तृ
{%Samāhartṛ%}¦ (EI 27; HD; HRS), official designation; ex-
<div n="lb">plained as ‘the collector-general’; officer in charge of the collec-
<div n="lb">tion of various branches of revenue; compared by Ghoshal with
<div n="lb">the {%Qānungo%} of Mughal times ({%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 52). See {%Artha-%}
<div n="lb">{%śāstra,%} I. 12; II. 6; {%Śabara%} on {%Jaimini,%} XII. 1. 28; {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. VIII, p. 141; Vol. XI, p. 94.
<LEND>

<L>5109<pc>290<k1>समय<k2>समय
{%samaya%}¦ (EI 10), a religious system.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), Telugu-Kannaḍa; a sect; an assemblage, a
<div n="lb">company or congregation; established moral or ceremonial
<div n="lb">custom; cf. {%samaiyam%} (EI 24), a creed.

<div n="lb">{%saṃvat.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a religious mendicant; cf. {%Samay-mudali,%} religious head.

<L>5110<pc>291<k1>समयाचार<k2>समय्-आचार
{%samay-ācāra%}¦ (SITI), religious usage; established custom; super-
<div n="lb">vision of the religious and social life of the people; censoring of
<div n="lb">public morals; also a class of officials called {%Samayācārya%} or {%Dāsari.%}
<LEND>

<L>5111<pc>291<k1>समयाचार्य<k2>समयाचार्य
{%Samayācārya%}¦ (ASLV), also called {%Samayācāra;%} same as
<div n="lb">{%Dāśari;%} a censor of morals; a class of officials.
<LEND>

<L>5112<pc>291<k1>समयधर्म<k2>समय-धर्म
{%samaya-dharma%}¦ (SITI), law of the {%samaya%} or agreement.
<div n="lb">The expression is generally used in relation to the organisation
<div n="lb">of merchants and agriculturists known respectively as {%Nānādeśīn%}
<div n="lb">and {%Citrame%}l13{%i.%}
<LEND>

<L>5113<pc>291<k1>समयपत्र<k2>समय-पत्र
{%samaya-patra%}¦ (SII 1; SITI; LP), an agreement; a docu-
<div n="lb">ment containing an agreement; a deed of agreement.
<LEND>

<L>5114<pc>291<k1>सामायिक<k2>सामायिक
{%sāmāyika%}¦ (HA), remaining steadfast in worship or medi-
<div n="lb">tation (at least for 48 minutes), with the mind drawn away
<div n="lb">from attachments or ill will and abstaining from committ-
<div n="lb">ing sins, which is the daily duty of a Jain.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>5163<pc>293<k1>संवत्<k2>संवत्
{%saṃvat%}¦ (IE 8-1), originally an abbreviation of {%saṃvatsara%}
<div n="lb">(a year) or any of its declensional cases that can be used in ex-
<div n="lb">pressing a date; later stereotyped in the sense of ‘a year’ or
<div n="lb">‘an era’. It was generally regarded as indeclinable; but we
<div n="lb">have some cases of the use of forms with case-endings, e. g.,
<div n="lb">{%saṃvataḥ, saṃvatā, saṃvati%} and {%saṃvatām.%} See also {%saṃvate%} (IE
<div n="lb">8-1), the seventh case-ending of {%saṃvata,%} a corrupt form of
<div n="lb">{%saṃvat.%} Since the late medieval age, the word specially indi-
<div n="lb">cates the Vikrama era, although originally it was used with the
<div n="lb">name of any reckoning in quoting the dates of records, especially
<div n="lb">the regnal reckoning. The word is used in inscriptions in a
<div n="lb">large number of corrupt forms, e. g., {%samvata, samvatta, samata,%}
<div n="lb">{%samanta, samatta, saṃmat, samasta, smat, samvatu, samvatū,%} etc., etc.
<LEND>

<L>5164<pc>293<k1>सम्वत्<k2>सम्वत्
{%samvat%}¦ (IE 8-1), mistake for {%saṃvat,%} originally an abbre-
<div n="lb">viation of {%saṃvatsara.%}
<LEND>

<L>5165<pc>293<k1>संवत्सर<k2>संवत्सर
{%saṃvatsara%}¦ (CII 3; 4; IA 17), ‘a year’; ‘an cra’, the
<div n="lb">earlier years of the Indian eras being quoted by this term (or
<div n="lb">by its abbreviations {%saṃ, saṃvat,%} etc.), without any dynastic or
<div n="lb">other appellation just as in the case of the year of a regnal
<div n="lb">reckoning.
<LEND>

<L>5166<pc>293<k1>सांवत्सर<k2>सांवत्सर

<div n="lb">75; {%Bṛhatasaṃhitā,%} 2. 9; cf. {%Sāṃvatsarika%} (EI 5).

<div n="lb">and war.

<L>5215<pc>296<k1>सङ्गम्<k2>सङ्गम्
{%saṅgam,%}¦ Tamil; same as Sanskrit {%saṅgha;%} an assembly of
<div n="lb">ancient Tamil poets; the name given to an assembly of poets
<div n="lb">reported in tradition to have functioned in three different pe-
<div n="lb">riods. The poets are believed to have been both literary critics
<div n="lb">and composers. Literary compositions of the age were later
<div n="lb">collected and compiled into anthologies known as {%Eṭṭuttokai,%}
<div n="lb">{%Pattuppāṭṭu%} and {%Padineṇkīḻkaṇakku%} according to their contents
<div n="lb">and size. The {%saṅgam%} is stated to have flourished at Kūḍal
<div n="lb">(also called Madurai in later literature) in the first and last
<div n="lb">period and at Kavāṭapuram in the middle period. The latest
<div n="lb">limit for the first two anthologies may be placed round about
<div n="lb">700 A.D. See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, {%Tamil Literature,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 14-18; S. Vaiyapuri Pillai, {%History of Tamil Language and%}
<div n="lb">{%Literature,%} p. 38.
<LEND>

<L>5216<pc>296<k1>सङ्घ<k2>सङ्घ
{%saṅgha%}¦ (ASLV), a social organisation.
<div n="P">({%BL%}), a community of Buddhist monks; the Buddhist Church.
<div n="P">({%HA%}), a Jain congregation; the Jain Church (made up
<div n="lb">of four constituents, viz. {%sādhu, sādhvī, śrāvaka%} and {%śrāvikā%})
<div n="lb">also called {%Jaina-saṅgha;%} a group of pilgrims going together on
[Page-297+ 40]
<div n="lb">pilgrimage under the leadership of a {%Saṅghapati%} (q. v.).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 22), a tribe.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%saṅgam%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>5217<pc>297<k1>सङ्घपति<k2>सङ्घ-पति

<div n="lb">Jain pilgrims to a holy place, who bears all the expenses of the
<div n="lb">whole group; same as {%Saṅghaprabhu, Saṅghavī,%} etc. Cf. the
<div n="lb">modern Jain family name {%Siṅghī.%}

<L>5265<pc>299<k1>शान्त्यागार<k2>शान्त्य्-आगार

<div n="lb">with the propitiatory water after a sacrifice; the room for
<div n="lb">performing propitiatory rites. See {%Śāntyāgārika, Śāntyāgār-ādhikṛta.%}

<L>5272<pc>299<k1>सप्तमचक्रवर्तिन्<k2>सप्तम-चक्रवर्तिन्

<div n="lb">ruling monarch; according to the {%Abhidhānacintāmaṇi,%} the six
[Page-300+ 40]
<div n="lb">older {%Cakravartins%} are: {%Māndhātā Dhundhumāraś = ca Hariścan-%}

<L>5277<pc>300<k1>सप्तसागर<k2>सप्त-सागर

<L>5278<pc>300<k1>सप्तसन्तान<k2>सप्त-सन्तान
{%sapta-santāna%}¦ (SITI), also called {%sapta-santati;%} merit equal
<div n="lb">to that obtainable through progeny from their performance of
<div n="lb">seven kinds of great deeds, viz. digging of tanks, hoarding of
<div n="lb">treasure, founding of {%agrahāras,%} erection of temples, creation
<div n="lb">of flower gardens, getting literary works written by poets, and
<div n="lb">the establishment of Choultries. An inscription ({%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. III, pp. 88 ff.) mentions the following seven meritorious
<div n="lb">acts a man ought to perform during his lifetime; viz. procrea-
<div n="lb">tion of sons, accumulation of wealth, planting of groves, help-
<div n="lb">ing people (Brāhmaṇas) to marry, getting poems composed,
<div n="lb">erection of temples and excavation of tanks.
<LEND>

<L>5279<pc>300<k1>सप्तसन्तति<k2>सप्त-सन्तति
{%sapta-santati%}¦ (SITI), same as {%sapta-santāna.%}
<LEND>

<L>5281<pc>300<k1>शर<k2>शर
{%śara%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘five’.
<LEND>

<L>5282<pc>300<k1>सारा<k2>सारा
{%sārā%}¦ (EI 9; LP), care; cf. {%etair = aṣṭabhir = goṣṭhikaiḥ … sārā%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇīyā,%} ‘[this place of worship] has to be taken care of by the
<div n="lb">following eight trustees’. Cf. also Gujarātī {%sāravār.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 8, 11), supervision.
<LEND>

<L>5283<pc>300<k1>शरभङ्ग<k2>शरभङ्ग
{%Śarabhaṅga%}¦ (IE 8-3; 8-8; EI 23), a leader of forces; an
<div n="lb">officer of the military department; possibly, a military governor;
<div n="lb">same as Persian {%Sarhang%} and Hindī {%Serāṅg;%} also spelt {%Sarabhaṅga%}
<div n="lb">and {%Sarobhaṅga;%} Wilson's Glossary explains {%Sarhang%} as ‘a com-
<div n="lb">mander’ and says, “but [it is] generally applied in India to
<div n="lb">the headman of a native crew, whether on board a ship or a
<div n="lb">boat; also to the headman of a gang of natives attached to artill-
<div n="lb">ery, dragging guns, or to the army in general, as tent-pitchers,
<div n="lb">and the like, or to the head of gangs of a superior order of labour-
<div n="lb">ers employed in public or private works, in docks, buildings,
[Page-301+ 40]
<div n="lb">etc.’ Cf. Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 123, 166 (spelt {%Sarobhaṅga%}),
<div n="lb">{%Ind. Cult.,%} Vol. VII, p. 309. Kane ({%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 1005) is certainly wrong when he thinks that it may be con-
<div n="lb">nected with {%śarayantra%} and {%Śarayantrin%} (a title bestowed in Mithilā
<div n="lb">upon a very learned man who faced the ordeal of answering
<div n="lb">satisfactorily all questions on any {%śāstra%} put to him by learned
<div n="lb">{%Ācāryas%} and also the questions put by common people). See {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, pp. 95. ff. See {%Sarāṅgha, Sarāhang,%} etc.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">Brāhmī and was prevalent in the Kashmir region.
<LEND>

<L>5286<pc>301<k1>शरणागतवज्रपञ्जर<k2>शरणागत-वज्रपञ्जर

<L>5318<pc>303<k1>सर्वजात<k2>सर्व-जात

<L>5319<pc>303<k1>सर्वमान्य<k2>सर्व-मान्य
{%sarva-mānya%}¦ (IE 8-5, SITI; CITD), a free tenure; a
<div n="lb">rent-free holding; land exempted from taxes; lands and villages
<div n="lb">fully exempt from all taxes. This corresponds to the
<div n="lb">{%iṟaiyili%} class of land mentioned in the Col13a inscriptions. Often
<div n="lb">this is associated with {%aṣṭa-bhoga,%} i. e. the eight forms of enjoy-
<div n="lb">ing the land. For a discussion of this form of land tenure, see
<div n="lb">{%JAHRS,%} Vol. X, pp. 123-32. It is noteworthy that even the
<div n="lb">so-called tax-free ({%i%}ṟ{%aiyili%}) lands paid to the king certain dues
<div n="lb">of the nature of taxes. See K. A. Nilakanta Sastri, {%The%}
<div n="lb">{%Co%}l13{%as,%} 2nd ed., pp. 534-35. See {%sarva-namasya,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>5320<pc>303<k1>सर्वमेध<k2>सर्व-मेध
{%sarva-medha%}¦ (EI 4), name of a sacrifice.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">same as {%sarva-mānya, sarva-namaskṛta, namasya-vṛtti.%}

<L>5324<pc>303<k1>सर्वसैन्याधिकारिन्<k2>सर्व-सैन्य्-आधिकारिन्

<L>5325<pc>303<k1>सर्वस्वहरण<k2>सर्वस्व-हरण

<L>5326<pc>303<k1>सर्वतन्त्राधिकृत<k2>सर्व-तन्त्र्-आधिकृत

<div n="lb">a superintendent of all departments; but {%tantra%} is used in South
<div n="lb">Indian records in the sense of ‘the army’. See {%tantra, Tantr-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhikārin,%} etc.

<L>5327<pc>303<k1>सर्वतोभद्र<k2>सर्वतोभद्र
{%sarvatobhadra%}¦ (EI 9), a building having doors on all the
<div n="lb">four sides.

<L>5332<pc>304<k1>शासन<k2>शासन
{%śāsana%}¦ (EI 19; IA 20), order, a royal edict; any royal
<div n="lb">record (cf. {%vijaya-śāsana%}).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4; EI 13, 23; CII 3; BL), a charter; land or
<div n="lb">village granted by a charter; rent-free land or village; some-

<div n="lb">free holdings. See also {%tāmra-śāsana,%} a technical term for a deed
<div n="lb">of conveyance on copper-plates.

<L>5425<pc>309<k1>सेनापति<k2>सेनापति
{%Senāpati%}¦ (IE 8-3), leader of forces; mentioned separately
<div n="lb">along with {%Bal-ādhyakṣa;%} probably, a subordinate of the latter;
<div n="lb">the military governor of a district, according to some
<div n="lb">(HD); commander-in-chief (ASLV), also called {%Sarva-sainy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhikārin%} and {%Dalavāya,%} i. e. the chief officer in charge of the
<div n="lb">military department. See {%Bṛhaspati%} quoted by Viśvarūpa on
<div n="lb">{%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} I. 307; {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, p. 187. Puṣya-
<div n="lb">mitra, the founder of the Śuṅga dynasty, was called {%Senāpati%}
<div n="lb">even after his accession to the Maurya throne. See {%Sen-ādhipa,%}
<div n="lb">etc.; cf. also {%Anusenāpati%} (EI 18).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes called {%Mahāpradhāna, Bāhattara-%}
<div n="lb">{%niyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Paṭṭa-sāhan-ādhipati,%} etc., additionally.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{%matsyinī c = aiva naidhānī bhaya-varjitā | rājaśāsana-nītā ca sīmā pañca-%}
<div n="lb">{%vidhā smṛtā%} (i. e. big trees or hills, rivers or tanks, under-
<div n="lb">ground signs and artificial marks made by men and by the king's
<div n="lb">order).
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%śīrmai, śīmai%} (SITI), a territorial division; also
<div n="lb">called {%sīman.%}
<LEND>

<L>5485<pc>312<k1>सीमकर्मकर<k2>सीमकर्मकर
{%Sīmakarmakara%}¦ (HD), officer in charge of boundaries or
<div n="lb">of boundary disputes. See {%CII,%} Vol. III, pp. 213, 216.

<div n="lb">guild.

<L>5585<pc>316<k1>श्रेष्ठिजीर्णविश्वमल्लप्रिय<k2>श्रेष्ठि-जीर्ण-विश्वमल्ल-प्रिय
{%śreṣṭhi-jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya,%}¦ wrongly read as {%śreṣṭha%} (LP),
[Page-317+ 40]
<div n="lb">probably a mistake for {%jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-viśvamalla-priya;%} name of a
<div n="lb">coin struck by {%Śreṣṭhin%} Viśvamalla. See {%jīrṇa-śreṣṭhi-viśvamalla%}

<LEND>

<L>5586<pc>317<k1>श्रेष्ठिन्<k2>श्रेष्ठिन्
{%Śreṣṭhin%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 4; LL), a banker or merchant or
<div n="lb">the foreman of a guild; sometimes mentioned in the list of the
<div n="lb">king's officials and subordinates addressed by him while making
<div n="lb">a grant ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIV, p. 276).
<div n="P">({%BL%}), representative of the banker class in the council of
<div n="lb">the local administrators of a town. Cf. {%Śeṭṭi, Nagara-śreṣṭhin.%}
<LEND>

<L>5587<pc>317<k1>श्री<k2>श्री
{%śrī%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), honorific prefix to names often rendered
<div n="lb">variously in English; e. g., in the case of paramount sovereigns
<div n="lb">and their wives by ‘glorious’; of feudatories and other ordinary
<div n="lb">persons by ‘illustrious’; of priests, teachers, etc., by ‘saintly’;
<div n="lb">of gods by ‘holy’; sometimes {%śrī%} is used before consonants and
<div n="lb">{%śrīmat%} before vowels. The honorific {%śrī%} is sometimes used in
<div n="lb">South Indian records along with the words {%vijaya%} or {%vijaya-śiva%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.). Cf. {%śrī-ni, Śrīcaraṇa,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), cf. {%śrī-pūrva%} used for {%śrī-yuta; śrī%} is sometimes
<div n="lb">repeated for emphasis, e. g., ‘{%śrī%} 108’ is written to indicate the
<div n="lb">repetition of the word for 108 times.
<LEND>

<L>5588<pc>317<k1>श्रीबलि<k2>श्री-बलि
{%śrī-bali%}¦ (SITI), daily offering of the {%bali%} service in temples;
<div n="lb">also {%havir-bali.%} Cf. Tamil {%śrī-bali-koṭṭuvār,%} a musical troupe
<div n="lb">playing on the instruments at the time of the {%śrī-bali%} in temples.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), image of the deity taken round the temple
<div n="lb">when the {%bali%} is offered; the procession circumambulating the
<div n="lb">temple at the time of the {%bali%} service.
<LEND>

<L>5589<pc>317<k1>श्रीबलिभोग<k2>श्री-बलि-भोग
{%śrī-bali-bhoga%}¦ (SITI), land set apart to meet the expenses
<div n="lb">of the {%śrī-bali%} service in a temple; also called {%śrī-bali-ppaṭṭi.%}
<LEND>

<L>5590<pc>317<k1>श्रीभाण्डार<k2>श्री-भाण्डार
{%śrī-bhāṇḍāra%}¦ (EI 33; SITI), the treasury of a temple.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), collective name for the trustees of a temple; same
<div n="lb">as {%śrībhaṇḍāra-vāriyam.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">the administration of a temple. Cf. {%śrī-bhāṇdāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>5617<pc>319<k1>श्रीमन्दिर<k2>श्री-मन्दिर

<L>5634<pc>320<k1>श्रीश्रीकरणादिसमस्तमुद्राव्यापार<k2>श्रीश्रीकरण्-आदि-समस्त-मुद्रा-व्यापार

<L>5635<pc>320<k1>श्रीवल्लभ<k2>श्रीवल्लभ

<L>5710<pc>325<k1>स्तूप<k2>स्तूप
{%stūpa%}¦ (CII 3; BL; LL), technical name of a type of
<div n="lb">Buddhist monument; a Buddhist structure enshrining relics.
<div n="lb">Sometimes the term {%ratna-gṛha%} (i. e. the house enshrining the
<div n="lb">three {%ratnas%} or the best amongst the three) seems to be used to
<div n="lb">denote a {%stūpa.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 2), a Jain religious establishment.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), pinnacle of a temple.
<LEND>

<L>5711<pc>325<k1>स्तुपी<k2>स्तुपी
{%stupī,%}¦ same as {%vimāna%} (IA 9), q. v.

<div n="lb">the month; used in connection with {%di%} (e. g. {%śu-di%}), but some-
<div n="lb">times by itself; often written as {%su.%} Cf. {%ba-di.%}

<L>5723<pc>326<k1>शुकनास<k2>शुक-नास
{%śuka-nāsa,%}¦ cf. {%śukanāsi%} ({%Arch. Rev.,%} 1960-61, Section III)
<div n="lb">literally, ‘a parrot's nose’ explained as ‘a gargoyle or
<div n="lb">the water spout in a building’ (Acharya, {%Ind. Arch.,%} p. 169)
<div n="lb">and ‘a vestibule’ (R. Narasiṃhachar, {%The Keśava Temple of%}
<div n="lb">{%Somanāthapur,%} p. 3); but also as ‘the projection of the main
<div n="lb">body of the {%śikhara%} of a temple originally at the front-
<div n="lb">side’ (Kramrisch, {%Hindu Temple,%} p. 241); also called {%śuk-%}
<div n="lb">{%āṅghri.%} The {%Dīpārṇava%} (ed. Prabhāśaṅkar O. Sompurā, p. 116)
<div n="lb">has the following stanzas on the subject:
{%agre kolī kapolas = tu śuka-nāsas = tu nāsikā |%}
<div n="lb">{%sāndhāre stambha-rekhā ca kartavyā madhya-koṣṭhake ||%}
<div n="lb">{%prāsādasya puro-bhāge nirvāṇa-mūla-śṛṅgakam |%}
<div n="lb">{%tad-agre śuka-nāśaṃ ca ek-ādi saptam = udgamam ||%}
<div n="lb">{%tasy = opari siṃhaḥ sthāpyo maṇḍapa-kalaśa-samaḥ |%}
<div n="lb">{%dvi-stambhaḥ śuka-nās-āgre vijñeyaḥ pāda-maṇḍapaḥ ||%}
<LEND>

<L>5739<pc>327<k1>शुल्क<k2>शुल्क
{%śulka%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12, 23, 25, 30; CII 4; CITD), tolls;
<div n="lb">customs duties; octroi duties; taxes particularly levied at ferries
<div n="lb">and passes and on roads, etc.; cf. {%krīḍara-śulka%} (EI 5), name of
<div n="lb">a tax; also {%śuṅgam, śuṅkam%} (SITI), customs, tolls.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), tax, probably identical with {%bali%} according to
<div n="lb">early authorities; ferry dues, tolls and transit duties according
<div n="lb">to the {%Smṛtis%} and lexicons; according to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} (1)
<div n="lb">duties levied upon articles imported into a city, (2) port-dues,
<div n="lb">(3) duty upon the sale of liquors, (4) customs collected by
<div n="lb">the ferrymen and boundary-officers, (5) duty upon mining
<div n="lb">products, (6) duty upon imported salt, and (7) duty upon
<div n="lb">animals intended for slaughter; according to Śukra, tolls and
<div n="lb">duties upon building-sites, etc. The {%Amarakoṣa%} explains {%śulka%}
<div n="lb">as {%ghaṭṭ-ādi-deya%} and Kṣīrasvāmin enumerates the dues as ferry
<div n="lb">duties, tolls paid at military stations or police outposts and
<div n="lb">transit duties paid by merchants.
<LEND>

<L>5740<pc>327<k1>शुल्काधिकार<k2>शुल्क्-आधिकार
{%śulk-ādhikāra,%}¦ cf. {%suṅk-ādhikāra%} (EI 5), ‘office for the collec-
<div n="lb">tion of tolls [of the Banavāsi District]’. Same as {%Śulk-ā-dhyakṣa.%}
<LEND>

<L>5741<pc>327<k1>शुल्कग्राह<k2>शुल्कग्राह
{%Śulkagrāha%}¦ (HD), an official who collected tolls or cus-
<div n="lb">toms duties. See Śukra, II. 128.
<LEND>

<L>5760<pc>328<k1>सुरही<k2>सुरही

<div n="lb">donations or exemptions from obligations or taxes declared

<L>5799<pc>330<k1>स्वामिन्<k2>स्वामिन्

<div n="lb">of foreign origin, assumed by the kings of Śaka-Kuṣāṇa ex-
<div n="lb">traction; adopted by indigenous rulers like the Śātavāhanas.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Śāmi%} (SITI), the king.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Vihāra-svāmin%} (founder or master of a monastery), etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7), same as {%Svāmi-Mahāsena,%} i. e. Kārttikeya.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23), designation of the member of a guild.

<div n="lb">the {%Māheśvaras.%}

<div n="lb">Tamil {%mel-vāram.%}

{%tala-pāṭa%}¦ (SITI), Tamil; an army; armaments.

<L>5861<pc>333<k1>तालपत्र<k2>ताल-पत्र
{%tāla-patra,%}¦ Tamil {%olai%} (SITI); literally, ‘palmyra-leaf’;
<div n="lb">an order from the king or a person in authority. Cf. {%olai-ccāda-%}
<div n="lb">{%nam,%} ‘a document written on palm-leaf’; {%olai-ccampaḍam,%} ‘wages
<div n="lb">paid to the messenger who brings the {%olai%} to meet his expenses
<div n="lb">on the way’; also written as {%olai-ccambaḻam, olai-ccammāḍam,%} etc.;
<div n="lb">same as {%nirūpa-ccambaḍam;%} cf. {%olai-nāyaka,%} ‘the chief secretary
<div n="lb">or the senior officer looking after correspondence.’
<LEND>

<L>5862<pc>333<k1>तालपट्ट<k2>ताल-पट्ट
{%tāla-paṭṭa%}¦ (IA 15), probably the same as {%tāla-patra,%} mean-
<div n="lb">ing ‘an ear-ornament’.

<L>5863<pc>333<k1>तलप्रहारिन्<k2>तलप्रहारिन्

<div n="lb">same as {%Talārī%} or {%Kotwāl.%}

<L>5864<pc>333<k1>तलार<k2>तलार
{%Talāra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 22; LP; BL; HD), administrator of
<div n="lb">a city or prefect of the city police; same as {%Talavara, Talārī%} or
<div n="lb">{%Kotwāl. Talavara%} of early South Indian inscriptions means
<div n="lb">a {%Rājasthānīya%} (a Duke or a viceroy) according to some
[Page-334+ 40]
<div n="lb">commentators and the {%Kotwāl%} or a city magistrate according to
<div n="lb">others. A subdivision of high class Khatris of the Punjab is
<div n="lb">called {%Tālwār.%} Cf. {%Tala-rakṣa%} or {%Tal-ārakṣa;%} also called {%Ārakṣika%}
<div n="lb">and {%Daṇḍapāśika.%} See Bhandarkar's List, No. 579; {%IHQ,%} 1960,
<div n="lb">p. 266.
<LEND>

<L>5865<pc>334<k1>तलाराभाव्य<k2>तलार्-आभाव्य
{%talār-ābhāvya%}¦ (EI 11), tax for payment to the {%Talāra;%} ac-
<div n="lb">cording to some, {%Talāra%} is the {%Kotwāl%} and {%bhāvya%} or {%ābhāvya%} is
<div n="lb">what is called {%saṃbhāvanā,%} i. e. {%pāghḍī,%} and {%talār-ābhāvya%} is the
<div n="lb">{%pāghḍī%} money given to the {%Kotwāl%} (LP).
<LEND>

<L>5870<pc>334<k1>तलवर<k2>तलवर
{%Talavara%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 20, 28), a title of the nobility or of
<div n="lb">subordinate rulers in some cases (a {%Rājasthānīya%} according
<div n="lb">to Vinayavijaya's {%Subodhikā%} commentary on the Jain {%Kalpa-%}
<div n="lb">{%sūtra%}); but the designation of the administrator of a city or of
<div n="lb">the police officer in charge of a city, according to some sour-
<div n="lb">ces (Hemacandra explaining {%Talāra%} as {%Nagara-rakṣaka%}); cf.
<div n="lb">{%Talāra, Talārī,%} etc.; also {%Mahātalavara.%}
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p. 78), cf. {%Talavara%} mentioned in
<div n="lb">the list of royal officials.
<LEND>

<L>5874<pc>334<k1>तलवाटक<k2>तल-वाटक

<L>5901<pc>336<k1>टङ्क<k2>टङ्क

<div n="lb">general; regarded as equal to 4 silver {%fanams;%} name applied to
<div n="lb">both gold and silver issues 80 {%ratis%} in weight ({%JNSI,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XXII, pp. 197-98); silver coins of the Delhi Sulṯāns--96 or 100

<L>5908<pc>336<k1>तन्त्र<k2>तन्त्र

<div n="lb">South Indian inscriptions.

<div n="P">({%LP%}), cf. {%tantre nirūpita,%} ‘officially sent’.

<L>5917<pc>337<k1>तन्त्रिन्<k2>तन्त्रिन्

<div n="lb">of the army; a temple priest; a weaver. It has been sup-
<div n="lb">posed that the Tamil words {%Kaikkoḻar%} and {%Aṭavi%} came to signify
<div n="lb">both a soldier and a weaver on the analogy of the word {%Tantrin%}
<div n="lb">used in both the senses. Cf. {%Tantrimār,%} members of the army
<div n="lb">corps; a class of persons who perform worship in temples; a priest.

<L>5961<pc>340<k1>ठक्कुर<k2>ठक्कुर
{%Ṭhakkura%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 4; HD), supposed
<div n="lb">to be a title derived from a Turkish word ({%Tegin%}); occurs as a
<div n="lb">title in the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 290, 706, 738; probably, a
<div n="lb">fief-holder; sometimes mentioned in the list of subordinates;
<div n="lb">generally used as a title of particular persons indicating their
<div n="lb">rank or office. The significance of the word possibly varied
<div n="lb">in different localities and ages. Its foreign origin is sup-
<div n="lb">ported by its unpopularity in the South. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XIII, p. 297; Vol. XIX, p. 243.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), probably a fief-holder; mentioned as {%Pātra.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9), explained as ‘the lord-in-waiting’.
<LEND>

<L>5991<pc>341<k1>तिथि<k2>तिथि
{%tithi%}¦ (CII 3; IA 17), a lunar day; one mean {%tithi%} is equal
<div n="lb">to 0.9843529572 of a mean solar day and night; the mean
<div n="lb">{%tithis%} in a solar year are 371, and 3 {%ghaṭīs%} and 53.4 {%palas;%} gener-
<div n="lb">ally the term {%tithi%} means the end of a {%tithi,%} not its beginning
<div n="lb">or duration, and the week-day of a {%tithi%} is the week-day on
<div n="lb">which that {%tithi%} ends; the {%tithis%} given in the {%Pañcāṅga%} are
<div n="lb">apparent, not mean, and they are intended to be given from
<div n="lb">apparent sunrise.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%tiyadi, tedi%} (SITI), a date.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘fifteen’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 16), same as {%mahā-tithi,%} an auspicious {%tithi;%} cf. {%saptamī%}
<div n="lb">called the {%tithi%} of the sun-god and {%aṣṭamī%} that of the god Śiva
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. V, p. 168, note 4).
<LEND>

<L>6081<pc>346<k1>उभय<k2>उभय
{%ubhaya,%}¦ cf. {%ubhaiyam%} (SII 1), an offering.
<div n="P">{%Cf. ubhaya-paliśai%} (SITI), interest in two ways, i. e.
<div n="lb">in money and in kind.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a tax payable in gold; probably the same as
<div n="lb">{%ubhaya-mārga%} or the tolls collected on the highways in both the
<div n="lb">directions, i. e. inward and outward.
<div n="P">({%SII,%} Vol. III, p. 209), a gift to a temple or monastery
<div n="lb">in Tamil records.

<L>6099<pc>347<k1>उदकपूर्वम्<k2>उदक-पूर्वम्
{%udaka-pūrvam%}¦ (IA 7), also expressed as {%udak-ātisargeṇa,%}
<div n="lb">‘with libations of water’; refers to the custom of pouring water
<div n="lb">in the hand of the donee while making the ceremonial gift of an
<div n="lb">object which cannot be placed in the latter's hands. Cf. {%Dra-%}
<div n="lb">{%vyasya nāma gṛhnīyād=dadān=īti tathā vadet | toyaṃ dadyāt=tato%}
<div n="lb">{%haste dāne vidhir=ayaṃ smṛtaḥ ||%} ({%Agni Purāṇa,%} Ch. 209,
<div n="lb">verses 49-50).

<L>6132<pc>349<k1>उद्रङ्ग<k2>उद्रङ्ग
{%udraṅga%}¦ (IE 8-3; 8-5; EI 22; CII 3, 4; HRS), explained
<div n="lb">as ‘the fixed tax’, ‘the land tax’, ‘the principal tax’ or ‘the
<div n="lb">tax on the permanent tenants’; generally mentioned along
<div n="lb">with {%uparikara,%} i. e. minor taxes or the tax on temporary
<div n="lb">tenants; same as {%kḻpta. Udraṅga%} may have been paid in grains
<div n="lb">at least in soem regions since the {%Audraṅgika%} (collector of {%ud-%}
<div n="lb">{%raṅga%}) is sometimes separately mentioned together with the
<div n="lb">{%Hiraṇyasāmudāyika%} (collector of revenue in cash). In one
<div n="lb">case, the land is said to have been granted after making it
<div n="lb">{%udraṅga,%} i. e. {%s-odraṅga.%} See {%s-odraṅga%} (IA 10), {%draṅga, uttāra.%}
<div n="lb">Cf. {%mah-odraṅga%} in {%pravartita-mahodraṅg-ādi-dāna-vyasan-ānupajāta-%}
<div n="lb">{%santoṣa%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXII, p. 118, text line 40).
<LEND>

<L>6153<pc>350<k1>उम्बरभेद<k2>उम्बर-भेद
{%umbara-bheda%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 25), ‘violation of the closed
<div n="lb">door’; the right of royal officers to enter into a house with doors
<div n="lb">closed for realising taxes. This probably related to the houses
<div n="lb">of merchants who were away from their home-towns in the
<div n="lb">course of their business; cf. {%unmara%} or {%umbara;%} also {%prātibhedikā.%}

<L>6161<pc>350<k1>उन्मर<k2>उन्मर
{%unmara%}¦ (EI 30), Sanskritised form of Prakrit {%ummara%} (cf.
<div n="lb">{%umbara%}); threshold. Merchants, who were often absent from
<div n="lb">home for a long time, were sometimes made free from {%unmara-%}
<div n="lb">{%bheda%} (entry into their house) by royal officers probably be-
<div n="lb">cause they paid their dues on their return from business tours.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%prātibhedikā.%}

<L>6188<pc>352<k1>उपरिक<k2>उपरिक
{%Uparika%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3; BL; HD), a viceroy; the
<div n="lb">governor of a province. An {%Uparika%} was appointed by the
<div n="lb">emperor and he himself appointed the governor of the district
<div n="lb">(cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 130). He is sometimes styled
<div n="lb">{%Mahārāja%} and {%Rājaputra.%} Viśvarūpa on the {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%}
<div n="lb">I. 307, quotes a prose passage from {%Bṛhaspati%} where the re-
<div n="lb">quisite qualities of an {%Uparika%} are set out. See Vogel, {%Ant. Ch.%}
<div n="lb">{%St.,%} p. 123. The word literally means ‘one placed at the top’.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), cf. {%Auparika,%} a viceroy.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Bṛhad-uparika%} (IE 8-3).
<LEND>

<L>6189<pc>352<k1>उपरिकमहाराज<k2>उपरिक-महाराज
{%Uparika-mahārāja%}¦ (IE 8-3), an {%Uparika%} enjoying the
<div n="lb">title {%Mahārāja.%}
<LEND>

<L>6190<pc>352<k1>उपरिकर<k2>उपरिकर
{%uparikara%}¦ (IE 8-5; CII 3, 4; HRS), explained as ‘ad-
<div n="lb">ditional taxes’, ‘unfixed taxes’, ‘minor taxes’, or ‘tax paid
<div n="lb">by the temporary tenants’; cf. {%s-oparikara%} (IA 10), sometimes
<div n="lb">called {%parikara%} (cf. {%sa-parikara%} in place of {%s-opakriara%}). See
<div n="lb">{%upri.%}

{%upa-riṅkh%}¦ (EI 12), to spread.

<div n="lb">{%Inscriptions,%} pp. 57. ff.); same as {%bṛha-vāra.%} The word in the
<div n="lb">Telugu part of an inscription is explained as {%śanaiścara-vāra%} in
<div n="lb">the Sanskrit portion of the said record; sometimes wrongly
<div n="lb">supposed to stand for some other day, e. g. Friday (IA 23)
<div n="lb">or Sunday (Venkatasubbiah, {%op. cit.,%} p. 58). Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%}

<L>6409<pc>363<k1>वार<k2>वार
{%vāra%}¦ (BL), a board of administrators [formed by the
<div n="lb">{%śreṣṭhins, sārthavāhas%} and others].
<div n="P">({%IA%} 16), the solar day.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), method of reciting the Vedas.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. III, p. 17, note 1), probably, a week.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 30; SITI), a share of the produce.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), a multitude. Cf. also {%vāra-Nāka-Lokta-Gāñīk-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādīnāṃ,%} ‘belonging to Nāka, Lokta and Gāñīka collectively’
<div n="lb">({%JAS,%} Letters, Vol. XX, pp. 202, 204).
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1) cf. {%vārataḥ,%} ‘in consequence of an occasion.’
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23), same as {%vāra-goṣṭhī;%} a committee; cf. {%vāra-pra-%}
<div n="lb">{%mukha. Vāra%} is the same as Tamil {%vāriyam.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘seven’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. bāre%} (Chamba), ‘during or in the time of’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">to the supply of unpaid labour by the villagers in turn.
